column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Nears $100 Billion In Debt: What Does This Mean?;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsA few days after declaring its earnings
column3: Apple Inc.(AAPL) raised $10 billion indebt. Similar to the bond sales done in the past
column4: this will also be carried out in various tranches with maturities of up to 30 years.makeArticleAd();The bonds will include both fixed rate notes and floaters.Apple Raises Debt a Little Earlier Than UsualThere was nothing much to say about the new bond offering
column5: and it was much like other papers sold by the company every year.However
column6: this time
column7: the company raised bonds a little earlier than the tradition
column8: and it is now nearing $100 billion in debt
column9: according to Evan Niu ofThe Motley Fool.Usually
column10: these bond offerings are announced after the iPhone maker gives updates to its capital return program
column11: which is conducted some time in April or May. However
column12: the company needed to sell the bonds a little early this year due to various reasons. The California-based company started its ninth share repurchase program in the previous quarter
column13: and total share repurchases came at $11 billion.This depleted its cash reserves
column14: and totalcashat the end of the quarter came in at around $15.9 billion. This is the low end of the usual  range of $15 billion to $25 billion that the company keeps for operational and strategic needs
column15: notes Niu.As the company uses debt for capital returns purposes
column16: its total debt taken over the past five years has grown significantly large.By the end of 2016
column17: the iPhone maker had $87.5 billion in long-term debt and commercial paper. With the recently-raised $10 billion
column18: it will total somewhere around $97.5 billion. The debt has an investment-grade rating.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenHowever
column19: in the future
column20: Apple's credit rating profile may deteriorate with a rise in debt levels

column1: Why Apple Inc.'s Profit Dropped Last Quarter;2/8/2017;"Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) most recent quarter was quite good
column2: with the   company delivering revenue and earnings per share ahead of   expectations
column3: thanks in no small part to better-than-expected   iPhone revenue.Nevertheless
column4: despite the better-than-anticipated financial   performance
column5: the company's operating income dropped from $24.17   billion to $23.35 billion. Net income declined from $18.36   billion in the year prior to $17.89 billion.Apple's iPhone coupled with AirPods. Image source:     Apple.makeArticleAd();Apple is still raking in alotof cash -- most companies could only dream of generating roughly   $18 billion inannualnet income
column6: let alone bring in that much in a single quarter --   but investors should pay attention when profit declines. Let's go   over the key factors that drove Apple's operating and net income   figures down year over year
column7: even as the company achieved record   quarterly revenue.Lower gross profit marginApple saw its gross profit drop from $30.42 billion in the   prior-year period to $30.18 billion in the company's most recent   period. Although the company's revenue was up year over year
column8: cost of sales grew at a faster pace than revenue did
column9: resulting   in a decline in gross profit margin.Apple did note on its most recent earnings call that in the   prior-year period
column10: Apple's revenue ""included the benefit of a   one-off $548 million patent infringement payment."" Though not a   substantial part of Apple's $75 billion-plus in revenue in that   quarter
column11: CFO Luca Maestri did say that this payment boosted gross   margin in the year-ago quarter by 40 basis points
column12: or 0.4%.The gross-margin story isn't the only thing that drove Apple's   profits slightly lower year over year
column13: though.Higher operating expensesGross profit margin is an important part of overall   profitability
column14: but a company's operating expenses -- which   include product development costs as well as sales and marketing   costs -- are also key determinants of a company's   profitability.Though Apple only increased its sales
column15: general
column16: and   administrative expenses by just shy of $100 million year over   year
column17: its research and development spending surged to $2.87   billion -- up more than $400 million from the roughly $2.4   billion the company spent in the prior-year period.Apple's operating expenses grew 9% from $6.25 billion in the   prior-year period to $6.82 billion in the most recent quarter.   Since operating-expense growth was greater than revenue growth
column18: which was approximately 3.3%
column19: operating expenses became a larger   part of the company's revenue and thus negatively affected   operating profit margin.What does this mean for Apple investors?The key headwinds to Apple's operating profit right now seem   to be the company's continued increases in research and   development
column20: coupled with slow revenue growth.It's probably not a good idea for the company to let up on its   research and development investments
column21: as the investments made   today are what allow the company to have a chance of bringing   compelling new products to market tomorrow
column22: potentially driving   revenue and profit increases over the long term.In the near to medium term
column23: Apple's best bet of returning to   consistent operating profit growth is likely to be from faster   revenue growth. Hopes seem to be high that Apple's   next-generation iPhone models will drive a so-called ""super   cycle"" such as what the company enjoyed with the iPhone 6-series   of products beginning in late 2014.If that comes to pass
column24: Apple could see significant   year-over-year revenue growth in the first quarter of its coming   fiscal year.Looking out longer term
column25: though
column26: it's hard to predict if and   how the company will deliver sustainable profit growth. Can the   company's core product categories do it? Or will the company need   to enter or create new product categories beyond the iPhone
column27: iPad
column28: Mac
column29: and services to support such growth?These are questions that will only be answered in time.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column30: it can pay to listen. After all
column31: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column32: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column33: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column34: 2017Ashraf Eassahas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: 3 Reasons Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the King;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLast week
column4: e-commerce giantAmazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) released disappointing holiday sales figures that caused investors to question the firm and send AMZN stock down roughly 3%. While the company produced fourth-quarter earnings that surpassed expectations
column6: the firm's revenue and future guidance figures came in below estimates.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAmazon's lacklusterearnings resultsmay have shocked the broader market
column7: but investors would be wise to use AMZN stock's loss as a buying opportunity because shares of the company very rarely go on sale.Amazon has a lot of potential and its willingness to invest in the future makes it a great long-term bet. While AMZN stock is still expensive at just over $810 per share and a price-to-earnings ratio of 186
column8: the firm's share price could make its way above $900 by the end of the year.AMZN Stock: Three Reasons to Keep the Miss in PerspectiveIt's never a good thing when a company misses revenue expectations and issues worse-than-expected forward guidance. However
column9: it's important to take a look at why AMZN's fourth-quarter earnings shook out the way they did and whether it's a deal breaker for investors considering picking up Amazon stock.Some of the reason for the revenue miss can be explained by currency fluctuations
column10: whichhurtthe retailer's revenue figures by around $558 million. Amazon is also adjusting to its fast-growing marketplace and the number of merchants that have joined the firm's ""fulfilled by Amazon"" program.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThis has in-turn increased shipping costs
column11: but the long-term benefits of the growing number of ""fulfilled by Amazon"" merchants outweigh the short-term negatives. It allows Amazon to offer its Prime members a greater selection of items and will likely help AMZN grab an even larger marketshare.Speaking of Amazon Prime
column12: the loyalty program is another good reason for investors to get behind Amazon stock. Not only do Prime's subscription fees provide AMZN with a passive revenue stream
column13: but the program helps bind people to its ecosystem.Prime has expanded to include benefits like dash-buttons
column14: which allow people to reorder certain products at the click of a button
column15: and movie and music streaming. Prime members who use all of Amazon's services are not only more likely to buy additional Amazon products like the firm's virtual assistant Alexa
column16: but they will also shop at its website before considering rivals - even if it doesn't offer the lowest prices.AMZN is doing with retail whatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) did with technology: building a brand that people will continue to buy into because it is convenient and connected.Here's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Hit $200However
column17: while the company's dominance in retail is a big reason to buy AMZN stock
column18: one of the most compelling elements of the firm's business is Amazon Web Services - the firm's cloud computing arm. The cloud computing space represents a huge area for growth as the industry is relatively new
column19: but AWS has already become one of the largest players.AWS has been slowly making up a larger and larger percentage of Amazon's total sales
column20: and the fourth quarter was no exception. The firm's cloud computing arm has been growing rapidly over the last year and as the industry continues to expand
column21: investors can expect AWS to add to Amazon's bottom line in a larger and larger capacity.Bottom Line on Amazon StockAMZN stock's stumble last week has given investors an opening to add shares to their portfolios. While there was some weakness in the company's fourth-quarter results
column22: the firm is on track to continue growing and Amazon stock will likely deliver outstanding gains in the year ahead.As of this writing
column23: Laura Hoy was long AAPL and AMZN.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Gold Stocks That Will Shine Under TrumpThe post3 Reasons Amazon.com
column24: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the Kingappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Most Cash That Apple
column2: Inc. Has Ever Had;2/7/2017;"You'd think that after returning over $200 billion in cash to   investors through its capital return program over the past five   years
column3: that there'd be a sizable dent inApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) money mountain. You'd be wrong.To be clear
column4: Apple's cash position would certainly be about   $200 billion more if it weren't for the program
column5: but the fact   still stands that Apple generates so much cash that it simply   can't give that money back fast enough. Operating cash flow was   $65.8 billion in fiscal 2016
column6: which ended in September. Even   after deducting $12.8 billion in capital expenditures
column7: the Mac   maker enjoyed $53 billion in free cash flow -- leaving plenty to   cover the $12.2 billion paid out in dividends and dividend   equivalents and buying back $30 billion worth of stock. The same   is true for the most recent fiscal first quarter.Apple Store Pudong. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Here's the thing: It's also true for almost every year since   Apple started returning capital. Capital returns have exceeded   100% of free cash flow in only one fiscal year since the program   commenced (2014
column8: and only by about 12%). The net result is that   despite the massive amounts of capital being returned
column9: Apple now   has the most cash it's ever had on the balance sheet. For a   company that loves superlatives as much as Apple does
column10: it's   almost surprising that it didn't point this out on last month's   earnings call.Cash is kingAs of the end of 2016
column11: Apple was sitting on $246 billion in   total cash
column12: which is the highest its cash position has ever been.   Even if you were to factor in debt
column13: which is predominantly used   to fund the capital return program
column14: and look at Apple's cash   position on a net basis
column15: that's also the highest it's ever been.   Despite its best efforts to return as much as possible
column16: Apple's   cash keeps marching higher. Gross cash and net cash begin to   diverge in 2013 when Apple starts taking on debt
column17: but you can see   both are at all-time highs.Data source: SEC filings and author's calculations. Chart by     author. Calendar quarters shown.It's also true that Apple's cash is increasingly concentrated   abroad
column18: as the debt is used as a way to avoid repatriation taxes.   At this point
column19: 94% of Apple's total cash is held by foreign   subsidiaries. This figure was closer to 60% half a decade   ago.Data source: SEC filings and author's calculations. Chart by     author. Calendar quarters shown.What comes nextGiven this
column20: combined with the fact that Apple is currently   reviewing its capital return plans and will give investors an   update in April
column21: there seems to be plenty of room for Apple to   get even more aggressive if it wants to. When it launched the   capital return program
column22: it finally acknowledged years of   criticisms that the company had way more cash than it would ever   conceivably need -- and it currently has about $60 billion more   (or about 50%) net cash than when it started capital returns.The curve ball is the practical limit on how much debt Apple   should take on. If the company can convince the Trump   administration to deliver on that repatriation holiday promise

column1: What Happens to Qualcomm Inc. if the NXP Deal Gets Killed?;2/7/2017;"Shares ofQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) have plunged nearly 20% since the beginning of the   year due to a double whammy of bad news. First
column2: the U.S. Federal   Trade Commission filed anantitrust lawsuitagainst the chipmaker
column3: claiming that it  leveraged its   portfolio of critical wireless patents to push competitors out of   the market. Shortly afterwards
column4: Applesued Qualcommfor allegedly withholding ""rebate"" payments for its use of   Qualcomm modems.But that was just the tip of the iceberg -- Qualcomm has been   struggling with other similar antitrust lawsuits across the world   over the past two years. It was fined $975 million and forced to   slash its licensing fees in China
column5: fined another $854 million in   South Korea
column6: and could face up to $3 billion in additional fines   in Europe and Taiwan.Image source: Qualcomm.makeArticleAd();However
column7: the impacts of those fines and reduced licensing fees   are overshadowed by a much bigger long-term risk -- the potential   cancellation of its planned$47 billion acquisitionofNXP Semiconductors(NASDAQ: NXPI) . Let's see what could happen to Qualcomm if this   massive deal gets derailed.A brief look at Qualcomm's problemsQualcomm has two main business units -- the chipmaking one   (QCT) and the licensing one (QTL). The QCT unit
column8: which sells its   flagship Snapdragon mobile chips and baseband modems
column9: generates   most of its revenue. The QTL unit
column10: which owns a massive portfolio   of 3G/4G patents
column11: generates most of its profits.Both businesses have been under pressure over the past few   years. The QCT unit has been losing market share to cheaper chips   from challengers likeMediaTekand first-party ARM chips from big OEMs like Apple
column12: Huawei
column13: Samsung
column14: andXiaomi. The QTL unit is struggling with the aforementioned regulatory   scrutiny
column15: since many OEMs consider its cut (up to  5%) of   the wholesale price of each smartphone sold to be too high.To offset those declines
column16: Qualcomm is diversifying the QCT   business intoadjacent markets
column17: with specialized Snapdragon chips for wearables
column18: drones
column19: connected cars
column20: and other Internet of Things (IoT) devices. A   crucial part of this push is in the connected car
column21: which is   widely considered a next-gen computing platform. To gain a   foothold in this market
column22: Qualcomm acquired IoT and    automotive chipmaker CSR for $2.4 billion in 2015.Why Qualcomm needs NXPTo expand further
column23: Qualcomm agreed to buy NXPin order to   also expand into new market -- namely automobiles. NXP became the   top automotive chipmaker in the world after its $12 billion   purchase of Freescale in late 2015. NXP also holds leading   positions in the networking and safety systems markets. Qualcomm   expects the combined company to generate annual revenues of over   $30 billion (compared to Qualcomm's estimated revenue of $23.8   billion this year)
column24: and help it establish leading positions   across the mobile
column25: automotive
column26: IoT
column27: security
column28: RF
column29: and networking   markets.Qualcomm believes that the deal will grow its ""serviceable   addressable markets"" by about 40% to $138 billion in 2020
column30: and   that the deal will be ""significantly accretive to non-GAAP   earnings immediately"" after it closes. It expects the deal to   generate $500 million in annualized run-rate cost synergies two   years after the deal closes.This deal will clearly help the QCT pivot away from the   sluggish smartphone market. But it will also greatly expand the   QTL's patent portfolio
column31: which could enable Qualcomm to collect   licensing fees across a much wider range of industries.Why the deal could run into troubleThe FTC has already accused Qualcomm of charging competing   baseband modem makers higher license fees for its wireless   patents
column32: which made their modems pricier for smartphone makers to   use. Therefore
column33: the FTC is unlikely to approve a deal which could   give Qualcomm the same power over other growing markets like IoT   devices and connected cars.If the FTC lawsuit derails the NXP deal
column34: Qualcomm will be left   with a fading QCT business and a potentially crippled QTL one --   which would cripple the chipmaker's long-term growth prospects.   Some analysts have speculated that Qualcomm might need to divest   some businesses or split in two (along the QCT and QTL lines) to   gain regulatory approval -- but splitting its low-margin and   high-margin businesses could yield unpredictable results.However
column35: some analysts believe that the FTC will simply drop   the case
column36: since Maureen Ohlhausen -- a Republican who was   recently appointed as the interim chairwoman by President Trump   -- previously expressed her  strong opposition to the   lawsuit. During last quarter's conference call
column37: Qualcomm CEO   Steve Mollenkopf expressed confidence that the  deal would   close
column38: and that recent legal actions were merely ""driven by   commercial disputes.""The key takeawayAs a Qualcomm investor
column39: I'm disappointed with the recent legal   actions against the chipmaker. While those moves might force   Qualcomm to lower its licensing fees
column40: I'm not convinced that they   will derail the NXP deal. The risks have certainly gone up for   Qualcomm
column41: but I still believe that its forward P/E of 11 and 4%   forward yield could limit its downside potential.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column44: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column45: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Tech Stock Roundup: Industry Comments on Visa Ban;2/7/2017;"The technology sector has grown increasingly dependent on foreign talent over the years such that today it can't function without it. On the face of things
column2: this has been really good for innovation helping the U.S. maintain its technological lead over others. But digging down a bit deeper
column3: what this means is that the U.S. is increasingly incapable of producing this talent itself. This is not a good situation to be in
column4: particularly when you consider that countries like China are doing all they can to develop indigenous intellectual property.That's probably the reason President Trump's draft proposal according to Bloomberg reads as follows: ""Our country's immigration policies should be designed and implemented to serve
column5: first and foremost
column6: the U.S. national interestâ€¦ Visa programs for foreign workers... should be administered in a manner that protects the civil rights of American workers and current lawful residents
column7: and that prioritizes the protection of American workers - our forgotten working people - and the jobs they hold.""There are many conflicting views and opinions about H-1B visas that companies use to employ people from other countries when adequate resources in the fields of science
column8: technology
column9: engineering and math aren't available locally. But since foreign labor is usually cheaper
column10: critics say that companies tend to employ foreigners even when the skills are available thus depressing wages for the industry as a whole.Ron Hira
column11: an associate professor at Howard University
column12: has done extensive research on the topic. Supporters say there isn't room to control wage inflation since the program is highly regulated and technology companies like AmazonAMZN
column13: AppleAAPL
column14: FacebookFB
column15: AlphabetGOOGLand MicrosoftMSFT
column16: in fact
column17: pay handsomely.Whatever the opinion on the wage rate
column18: there's no denying that the jobs go to foreigners. If the trend continues
column19: high tech American employees will have a harder time finding jobs
column20: thus gradually closing down the institutions producing them. The per capita GDP attributable to such jobs will also go down as tech employees from abroad obtain American citizenship.It's also true that a country is in a position of absorbing others
column21: giving them a home
column22: a job
column23: etc. when it is itself in a position of strength. But when it can't find local tech workers
column24: it's definitely not in that position and may need some temporary measures to rejuvenate.There's also another side to the story. If tech companies are unsuccessful in their letters of appeal
column25: lawsuits and other measures they're taking against the President and the proposal is enforced
column26: they may decide to employ the same talent in international facilities. A company's main motivation and objective is to generate profit
column27: and there could be initial costs of setting up such international operations.The visa issue has been clubbed with another important one involving terrorism because the President has blocked all refugees from entering the U.S. for 120 days (the ban is indefinite for Syrian refugees possibly because of their acts of vandalism across Europe). Citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries like Sudan
column28: Iran
column29: Iraq
column30: Libya
column31: Somalia
column32: Syria and Yemen were also banned from entering the U.S. for 90 days. This seems like a relatively short period of time and what will be achieved in the interim remains unclear.In the meantime
column33: Attorney General Bob Ferguson
column34: a Democrat
column35: filed a complaint saying Trump's order is ""undermining the state's sovereign interests"" in violation of equal protection laws under the Fifth Amendment. Washington State also sued the President with support from Amazon and Microsoft.But don't imagine that the so-called refugees are helpless victims because they have plenty of powerful lobbies working for them. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) are getting ready to file lawsuits. What's more
column36: Google has created a ""crisis fund"" with $2 million and its employees have contributed a like amount that they are gifting the ACLU. Other funds are also on the way.But tech companies have plenty to say about both issues:Apple: CEO Tim Cook told employees that the company had communicated with the White House. ""I've heard from many of you who are deeply concerned about the executive order issued (Friday) restricting immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries. I share your concerns. It is not a policy we supportâ€¦Apple would not exist without immigration
column37: let alone thrive and innovate the way we do
column38: he wrote in an email.Google: CEO Sundar Pichai wrote in a memo to employees: ""It's painful to see the personal cost of this executive order on our colleaguesâ€¦We've always made our view on immigration issues known publicly and will continue to do so."" He also said that at least 187 Google staff were affected by the ban.Founder Sergey Brin: ""It's a debate about fundamental values and thoughtful policymaking and many of the other things
column39: I think
column40: that are apparently not universally adored but I think the vast majority of our country and legislators support."" Google has a problem with the orders
column41: including ""extreme vetting"" of immigrants. After planning their move for some days 2K+ Google employees from at least eight Google offices walked out on Monday afternoon.Facebook: Founder Mark Zuckerberg wrote on his Facebook page: ""Expanding the focus of law enforcement beyond people who are real threats would make all Americans less safe by diverting resources
column42: while millions of undocumented folks who don't pose a threat will live in fear of deportation."" In an official statement on Saturday
column43: Facebook said: ""We are assessing the impact on our workforce and determining how best to protect our people and their families from any adverse effects.""IntelINTC: Brian Krzanich: ""I have heard from many of you
column44: and share your concern over the recent executive order and want you to know this is not a policy we can support
column45: and ""First
column46: as the grandson of immigrants and the CEO of a company that was co-founded by an immigrant
column47: we believe that lawful immigration is critical to the future of our company and this nation.""One of Intel's first hires was Andy Grove
column48: who survived the Nazi occupation of Hungary and ran Intel for 11 years establishing it as the leader in microprocessor technology. He also said: ""At Intel we believe that immigration is an important part of our diversity and inclusion efforts"" and ""Inclusion is about making everyone feel welcome and part of our community.""Its official statement says
column49: ""We are providing support to potentially impacted employees
column50: all of whom are in this country lawfully. As a company co-founded by an immigrant
column51: we continue to support lawful immigration. We will continue to provide any impacted employees with Intel's full support.""A statement on the company website says that it supports ""legislative or administrative action to improve the immigration system for highly skilled employees."" Half its 106K employees work in other countries and its U.S. workers include roughly 3K foreigners on work visas for those with specialized skills. But the number of employees from the seven banned nations is not known. Intel explained its contribution to Trump's inaugural committee by saying that it gave Intel a seat at the table on issues important to the company.Microsoft: Microsoft's president and chief legal officer Brad Smith wrote in a letter to the Secretary of State Rex Tillerson that there are currently 76 U.S. visa holders within the tech firm and 41 dependents who are citizens of the seven countries mentioned in the order. ""These are not situations that law-abiding individuals should be forced to confront when there is no evidence that they pose a security or safety threat to the United States
column52: he said.Satya Nadella
column53: Microsoft's CEO
column54: said
column55: ""As an immigrant and as a CEO
column56: I've both experienced and seen the positive impact that immigration has on our company
column57: for the country
column58: and for the world"" while posting Smith's email to employees on LinkedIn. Microsoft is trying everything to keep its options open. On the one hand it is joining Washington state to sue Trump while on the other
column59: it is requesting the government to make an exception for ""responsible known travelers with pressing needs"" so people with passports from one of the countries listed in the order can return to the U.S. as long as they have a valid work or student visa and have not committed a crime in the U.S.Micorsoft is also asking that employees and students affected by the ban be allowed to travel outside of the U.S. for business reasons
column60: except to the seven countries on the list. It is also asking that people with passports from one of the countries be allowed to go home for family reasons on a case-by-case basis.Tesla: CEO Elon Musk
column61: one of only a few tech executives on Trump's business advisory team and manufacturing jobs initiative: ""The blanket entry ban on citizens from certain primarily Muslim countries is not the best way to address the country's challenges
column62: he tweeted on Saturday. ""Many people negatively affected by this policy are strong supporters of the US. They've done right
column63: not wrong & don't deserve to be rejected.""TwitterTWTRCEO Jack Dorsey called the impact of the order ""real and upsetting.""Netflix: CEO Reed Hastings said
column64: ""Trump's actions are hurting Netflix employees around the world
column65: and are so un-American it pains us allâ€¦ It is time to link arms together to protect American values of freedom and opportunity.""UberCEO Travis Kalanick told employees he would talk to Trump about it in President Trump's first business advisory group meeting. ""While every government has their own immigration controls
column66: allowing people from all around the world to come here and make America their home has largely been the U.S.'s policy since its founding. That means this ban will impact many innocent people
column67: Kalanick said.BoxCEO Aaron Levie who is Iranian-American said ""At the corporate level
column68: we are trying to take inventory on who could be impacted and ensuring that they stay within the country for now... We are really just getting a handle on the legal side of the situation
column69: what we can fight and ultimately how we protect employees in the process."" More broadly
column70: the order sends ""the wrong moral message to the world and within our own country
column71: Levie said. ""It's very unfortunate and very disappointing.""SlackCEO Stewart Butterfield said ""Immigration is unambiguously an economic benefit
column72: but that doesn't matter: do the right thing because it's right

column74: at 17
column75: sponsored by an elder sister. Two more siblings made it. Everyone else died.""Sam Altman
column76: president of Silicon Valley tech incubator Y Combinator said in a blog: ""It is time for tech companies to start speaking up about some of the actions taken by President Trump's administration... The tech community is powerful. Large tech companies in particular have enormous power and are held in high regard. We need to hear from the CEOs clearly and unequivocally. Although there is some business risk in doing so
column77: there is strength in numbers-if everyone does it early this coming week
column78: we will all make each other stronger.""CompanyLast WeekLast  6 MonthsAAPL+5.85%+20.10%FB-0.98%+5.29%GOOGL-2.95%+2.39%MSFT-3.22%+12.51%INTC-3.83%+4.79%CSCO+1.10%+1.92%AMZN-3.06%+5.53%Other stories you might have missed-CorporateApple in India: Apple will be assembling some iPhones in Bengaluru
column79: the capital city of the south Indian state of Karnataka according to the state's IT minister Priyank Kharge. Taiwan's Wistron is setting up the unit that is expected to commence operations in the first half of 2017 (or by April-end according to some news sites).Apple has been trying to get concessions from the Indian government but progress on that front is not clear as of now. India is an important market for Apple
column80: which sold 2.5 million iPhones in the country in 2016. An estimated 750 million smartphones will be sold in India by 2020
column81: so one can understand why Apple CEO Tim Cook said that India is ""the place to be.""Apple Manufacturing In U.S.: Terry Gou
column82: CEO of Apple's largest contractor Foxconn
column83: has said that the company
column84: along with top customer Apple
column85: is considering the setting up of a display panel manufacturing unit in the U.S. that could create up to 50K jobs. The decision followed Softbank CEO Masayoshi Son's announcement about a $50 billion investment fund for the U.S.The Nikkei reported that another Pennsylvania plant was also in the works
column86: but it would be involved in molding functions.  Foxconn-controlled Smart Technologies may also move production to the U.S. if President Trump is able to renegotiate the North American free trade agreement.Barclays Downgrades Apple: Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz doesn't have high expectations of the iPhone 8 because the maturing of the smartphone market means fewer upgrades and a tendency to buy lower-priced
column87: older models. He also believes that ""long-term growth opportunities related to India
column88: services
column89: the enterprise
column90: artificial intelligence
column91: and maybe even the cloud still exist;"" however
column92: he does not ""expect these potential 'what's next?' opportunities to emerge as major needle movers over the next 12 months for Apple's model.""  He therefore downgraded the shares from overweight to sector weight.Ford Snaps Up Apple Executive: Musa Tariq
column93: Apple's global marketing and communications director for retail
column94: is joining Ford as its chief brand officer. Tariq's experience includes initiatives to enhance the retail experience at Apple's 490 stores. As Ford evolves as a company making vehicles in a self-driving world
column95: it will be increasingly blending technology and auto
column96: so it's easy to see that the brand might need repositioning. Steering the company through these changes seems to be the role Tariq will play.Ajit Pai Is FCC Chairman: Net neutrality opposer Ajit Pai has been appointed Chairman of the FCC by the Trump administration. Pai was one of two Republicans on the five-member board
column97: so his elevation won't require senate approval. He replaces Tom Wheeler
column98: who resigned soon after Trump won the elections. Streaming companies like Netflix
column99: Apple and Amazon won't be too pleased although Netflix indicated that its fan following provided it a certain amount of leverage with carriers. The truth is
column100: it already has arrangements with carriers that allow them to charge it differential rates
column101: contrary to the principles of net neutrality.Facebook Gets New VR Chief: Facebook has made an important hire in Hugo Barra
column102: who has spent the last three years revving up the marketing machinery at Xiaomi (the success of the Mi3 and Redmi smartphones are attributed to him) and serving as Google's Android chief before that. Facebook's VR plan is more on the high end
column103: which has somewhat impacted the adoption of the Rift
column104: so it's easy to see how it could benefit from experience.Barra will replace Brendan Iribe as Oculus head and will also head up all VR efforts at Facebook. Iribe will move to the PC division
column105: to speed up PC-based VR development. As part of his recent testimony defending Oculus technology
column106: Zuckerberg said earlier that VR will take five to ten years to go mainstream and that Facebook will probably have to spend another $3 billion before it gets where it wants to go. So it clearly has long range plans.Microsoft to Invest $1 Billion in Cloud Security: Microsoft has said that it will continue to invest a billion dollars into cloud security over the next few years and some say this is excluding acquisitions (such as Aorato for enterprise security
column107: Adallom for general cloud security applications
column109: for protection of data and files) and investments through its venture capital arm.The adoption of cloud infrastructure by enterprises to a great extent hinges on the security of offerings. This along with the far greater competition in the cloud than in desktop computing makes security very important for Microsoft. Since the company now has a synchronized operating system across platforms in windows 10
column110: it can hope to bring increasingly secure offerings and thereby pick up market share.Microsoft Bond Sale: Soon after raising $19.75 billion in bonds in Aug 2016
column111: Microsoft sold another $17 billion worth. The seven-part offering will be used for general corporate purposes and to help repay $26 billion in short term debt used to acquire LinkedIn.Moody's assigned a Aaa rating to the issue on the basis of a business model that will remain exceptionally robust as it continues to transition from on premise licensing to cloud based software subscription and service offerings. Investors haven't taken bond issues by tech companies badly because it's well known that they have huge cash piles parked overseas. The practice may change going forward if tax reform brings more of this cash back home.Microsoft Creates CTO Position: Kevin Scott
column112: former SVP of infrastructure and operations at LinkedIn
column113: will fill the newly created position of chief technology officer at Microsoft to push adoption of Microsoft products and services at LinkedIn customers and members. He will report directly to CEO Nadella. Scott previously worked at Google and AdMob.Nadella Joins Starbucks Board: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella will join Sam's Club CEO Rosalind Brewer and LEGO Brand Group executive chairman JÃ¸rgen Vig Knudstorp on Starbucks' board of directors
column114: if the shareholders approve the appointments at the annual general meeting in March. The appointments will expand the size of the board from 12 to 14 as long-time director Jamie Shennan will retire before the meeting.Snap IPO Reveals Google Cloud Deal: Inside documents filed by Snap was a deal with Google to use its cloud computing platform to run the Snapchat app; not just that
column115: there is a minimum purchase agreement of $400 million a year
column116: although in the first four years
column117: up to 15% may be moved to a subsequent year. Snap doesn't make a whole lot of money just yet
column118: (just $404.5 million in 2016) but its service is very popular and using Google's cloud could help it scale.Google Is Top Brand Again: Brand Finance
column119: one of the firms providing a list of leading brands
column120: says that Google has claimed the top position for the first time in 5 years
column121: replacing Apple. Google's strength is seen in its prowess in search
column122: which is the mainstay of its advertising business and where it remains ""largely unchallenged"". Apple is seen as repeatedly underperforming expectations and its inability to ""demonstrate that genuinely innovative technologies desired by consumers are in the pipeline"".Google Hires VR Employee: Just a few months after Google launched its Daydream View VR headset (basic features and head strap packed into a stylish package that retails for just $49)
column123: the company has hired away Claude Zellweger
column124: who headed HTC's VR unit. Zellweger led the team responsible for the Vive VR headset
column125: so this is probably an indication that Google has big VR hardware plans.Alibaba Leading Funding Round in India's Paytm: Alibaba is leading a $200 million funding round in Paytm Ecommerce
column126: which was spun out of One97 Communications. One97 also offers the Paytm Digital Wallet
column127: in which Alibaba and its financial arm own a high stake. Alibaba is not entering the Indian ecommerce market directly at this stage but through startups like this one and Snapdeal. Other big players include Amazon and Flipkart.Activision's Consumer Products Division: Activision has created a division to make more out of its popular video games and has appointed Tim Kilpin former president and chief commercial officer of Mattel
column128: to head the unit. Activision's goal is to develop consumer-type products based on its video game franchises (toys and apparel for example) so Kilpin
column129: with his experience developing the hugely popular ""Monster High"" dolls (Mattel's first intellectual property in more than 30 years) will come in handy.Legal/RegulatoryFacebook Fined in Oculus Case: A jury has decided that ZeniMax will receive $500 million from Oculus owner Facebook as it was guilty of copyright infringement
column130: the failure to comply with a non-disclosure agreement
column131: and for the misuse of Oculus trademarks. The amount to be paid is split up as follows: $200 million for violating a non-disclosure agreement
column132: $50 million for copyright infringement and $50 million for improper use of ZeniMax trademarks.It will also pick up $150 million in damages from Brendan Iribe and $50 million in damages from Palmer Luckey
column134: the court ruled that the Rift maker wasn't guilty of trade secret theft
column135: a point that will be used by Oculus to frame its appeal.Google Privacy Policy Under EU Scrutiny: Google made a significant change to its privacy policy back in June. The change
column136: while enabling users to more easily see and delete the information that Google has on them
column137: also alters Google's age-old policy to separate data on Gmail and YouTube from its widely used DoubleClick business. The change therefore empowers Google to build better customer profiles and thereby serve more targeted ads. Oracle
column138: which is part of a coalition called Fairsearch that tries to make life as difficult as possible for Google
column139: brought it to the attention of regulators last year and they are now looking into the matter.Amazon Would Rather Settle with EU: Amazon's parity clause that forced ebook publishers to always offer it the same terms as rival platforms has been under EU scrutiny. The investigation started in Jun 2015 with the goal of determining whether the facility prevented other distributors from competing with Amazon by offering new and innovative products and services. Now that the EU has opened it up for feedback from rivals and customers
column140: Amazon is attempting to settle the matter with publishers so it isn't called upon to pay a fine
column141: which could be as high as 10% of its global turnover.New Technology/ProductsApple Watch Patent: Apple has won a patent for a modular metal band for its Watch. The modules can be used to house batteries
column142: haptic devices that provide a sensation to the user
column147: speakers and a range of health sensors including thermometers
column149: blood pressure sensors and sweat sensors. The limited space in the wearable to serve individual customer needs was the reason for developing the band.Apple Mac Chip Could Hurt Intel Business: Both Boomberg's Mark Gurman and Ian King and RBC analyst Amit Daryanani have given views on how an Apple developed co-processor(codenamed T310 for Macs based on ARM technology can hurt Intel's chip business. According to Bloomberg
column151: which went into development last year
column152: will gradually take over the functions of the Intel processor
column153: paving the way for Apple's processor independence.But chips generally take 3-4 years to get into mass production
column154: so Daryanani's view that it will not impact Intel's business in 2017 and also possibly in 2018 makes sense. He says that if Intel is totally designed out
column155: it will be a $2-3 billion hit to annual revenue
column156: $750 million to $1 billion hit to operating income with a 12-16 cent impact on the annual EPS.Intel Go: Intel is boosting its automotive efforts by creating a new division called Intel Go to solve hardware problems like computer vision
column158: 5G wireless connectivity and AI technology. It will also offer related software solutions. Intel holds the view that the car is the next computing hub and it intends to do all it can to grab a greater dollar share. As cars incorporate more electronics and move towards complete automation
column160: partnerships and investments may be expected to put it in front and center of the new opportunity as it unfolds.Google Instant Apps: First announced at the 2016 Google I/O conference
column161: Instant Apps are a workaround between full apps and the web. Single-use or infrequently-used apps sometimes have to be downloaded because the mobile web browsers of companies aren't that great. Since unnecessary downloads are nothing but wasted memory and space
column162: Google will stream parts of the apps from its own servers
column163: so neither the download nor the mobile web is required. The company is now rolling out the service to select users.Slack's Answer to Microsoft: The Slack Enterprise Grid designed for larger and more complex businesses offers identity management technology
column164: data loss prevention and advanced security systems. The Slack solution is also compliant with regulatory requirements in healthcare and finance sectors
column165: which may be partly responsible for its swelling user base.The company said that it now has 1.5 million paying users

column168: which connected the chat feature with the Office 365 cloud suite
column169: thereby facilitating collaboration. The two are now competing head-on.M&A and CollaborationsCisco Buys AppDynamics: Cisco paid $3.7 billion for AppDynamics
column170: an application performance management company just before it was scheduled to float its IPO. The purchase price was more than double the amount the company hoped to raise at its IPO and almost double the $1.9 billion valuation at its last funding round. Cisco has been trying to build the software and services side of the business
column171: with particular focus on the emerging Internet of Things. The acquisition will surely provide the ""end to end visibility and intelligence from the network through the application"" that it is looking for and could nudge up software revenue from the current 29%
column172: but the price tag looks high.Alibaba Affiliate Buys MoneyGram: Alibaba's payments arm Ant Financial is buying Nasdaq-listed MoneyGram for $880 million. MoneyGram focuses on peer-to-peer transactions and includes cross-border currency transfers. It also claims to have 350K physical locations across 200 countries. Ant Financial handles nearly 90% of digital payments in China and has also made strategic investments in India-based Paytm as part of its international push. MoneyGram will go a long way in furthering this objective.Some NumbersApple Watch Market Share: According to Strategy Anlaytics

column1: Tuesday Apple Rumors: LG UltraFine 5K Shielding Fixes Router Issue;2/7/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of the LG UltraFine 5K  glitch fix. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Tuesday.makeArticleAd();LG UltraFine 5K:The new shielding on the LG UltraFine 5K  fixes the problems when near a router
column4: reportsAppleInsider. The updated version of the LG UltraFine 5K includes additional shielding to protect it from signals sent by wireless routers. These signals could cause problems with the display that would result in it crashing. The problem was noticed by users and LG set out to fix the issue. There still isn't news on how owners of the older model without additional shielding should have theirs sent in for repairs. This device is the main replacement for the Thunderbolt Display discontinued by AAPL.macOS 10.12.4 Beta:The second beta for macOS 10.12.4 is now available to developers
column5: 9to5Macnotes. This new beta includes changes to Apple's PDF API
column6: Siri and Dictation. It also lets users try out Night Shift mode for Mac devices. Night Shift has been a feature on iOS devices for a while now and it is finally coming to the company's desktop and laptop computers. It lets the display shift in color as time progress to make using it at different times in the day easier.New MacBooks:The new beta for macOS 10.12.4 includes references to the next version of the MacBook
column7: reportsMacRumors. The second macOS 10.12.4 beta includes information to identify three different motherboards that aren't in the tech company's current line of devices. This likely means they are for the upcoming MacBook update that will likely appear later this year. The information also leans toward them being for laptop devices and not desktop ones.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postTuesday Apple Rumors: LG UltraFine 5K Shielding Fixes Router Issueappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc.'s Mac Is Back on Track;2/7/2017;"For a while there
column2: Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) Mac business was really struggling. Not only was   it a victim of a generally weak personal-computer market
column3: but a   stale product line in the face of aggressive moves from competing   computer vendors also led the company to underperform the broader   market.Apple MacBook Pro computers. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();That
column4: by the way
column5: is a nice way of saying the company lost   market share.Last October
column6: though
column7: Applefinallylaunched new MacBook Pro machines. It updated both its 13-inch   and 15-inch MacBook Pro lines
column8: and because of all the new   features it packed into these updated systems
column9: the company   charged higher prices for them than it did for the   prior-generation models.Now that Apple's first-quarter financial results are out --   the first quarter in which the company would recognize revenue   for the new systems -- investors can get an idea of how well   customers have received the new systems.And
column10: perhaps unsurprisingly
column11: things are looking good.Putting Mac back on a growth pathApple reported shipping 5.37 million Macs in the first quarter   of its fiscal year 2017
column12: netting $7.24 billion in revenue from   those sales. Mac unit shipments were up from the 5.31 million   Apple shipped in the prior-year period
column13: amounting to 1.1%   growth.That's not a huge amount of growth
column14: but considering the 10%   unit decline that Apple's Mac business suffered last year
column15: that's   an improvement.Though unit growth was positive but anemic
column16: the revenue growth   story was completely different. Apple's Mac revenue in its most   recent quarter was up 7% year over year
column17: implying a solid   increase in Mac average selling prices.""The Mac not only returned to growth but generated its highest   quarterly revenue ever
column18: Apple CEO Tim Cook proclaimed on the   company's first-quarter earnings call.It's still early in the current MacBook Pro product cycle
column19: but   it seems customers were willing to pay extra for the added   features and technologies Apple added to its latest MacBook Pro   machines.Apple knows what it must doI'd hazard a guess that it won't take any miracles or   game-changing innovations to allow Apple's Mac product line to   continue to at least perform in line with the personal-computer   market. Apple simply needs to make sure it provides regular   updates to its Mac products so the lineup doesn't get stale.These regular updates can be as simple as adopting the latest   processors and adding other technological improvements
column20: though   obviously the bigger and more interesting the changes -- think   the Touch Bar
column21: the Force Touch trackpad
column22: and so on -- the   better.The Mac doesn't make up a huge portion of Apple's annual   revenue. Mac sales made up less than 10% of Apple's fiscal   first-quarter revenue
column23: though this percentage is bound to   increase as Apple moves past the peak iPhone quarter. And when   taken in conjunction with Apple's other non-iPhone products
column24: it's   still a reasonable contributor to revenue.Further
column25: much has been said about the strength of Apple's   ecosystem and the company's ability to build products that work   well together. If the company can sell more Macs
column26: then that might   also translate into customers who will switch to -- or stick with   -- Apple's iPhone.Apple should do its very best to make sure all of the elements   of its ecosystem are strong
column27: to maximize the potential value it   can extract from said ecosystem.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column28: it can pay to listen. After all
column29: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column30: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column31: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column32: 2017Ashraf Eassahas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: 3 Mutual Funds to Buy on Apple's Robust Earnings;2/7/2017;"The tech sector has performed favorably in recent times on the back of encouraging earnings results.Although Trump's proposed trade and immigration policies are expected to weigh on big technology companies
column2: hiscorporate tax repatriation planscould benefit technology companies that hold a lot of cash overseas. These tech companies could repatriate that cash and use it for investments
column3: dividends and buybacks.Tech behemoth Apple IncAAPLmade a strong rebound on the back of strong fiscal first-quarter earnings results. The good show was driven by impressive iPhone 7 and 7 Plus sales. Following these promising trends
column4: investing in technology mutual funds with a significant holding in the iPhone maker and other tech giants will be a prudent decision.Q1 Earnings in FocusApple's fiscal first-quarter earnings of $3.36 per share and revenues of $78.4 billion easily topped the respective Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.22 and $76.9 billion. On a year-over-year basis
column5: earnings and revenues registered growth of 2.4% and 3.3% respectively. Services
column6: which include revenues from Internet Services
column7: App store
column8: Apple Music
column9: AppleCare
column10: Apple Pay
column11: licensing and other services
column12: surged 18% year over year to nearly $7.2 billion.Additionally
column13: total iPhone unit sales came in at about $78.3 million
column14: up 5% year over year. Revenues from iPhone also grew 5% from the year-ago quarter to $54.4 billion (69.4% of total revenue). Moreover
column15: optimism of the tech behemoth's forthcoming series of iPhone upgrades in the coming months encouraged some analysts to raise their price targets.Apple Rally Boosts Tech SectorGains in Apple came as a breather for the broader technology sector. The iPhone maker remained the biggest company in the index in terms of market capitalization. Along with Apple some other big tech companies like MicrosoftMSFT
column16: AlphabetGOOGL
column17: NetflixNFLXand FacebookFBreported solid earnings results.Microsoft's earnings per share (EPS) and revenues for fiscal Q2 beat our estimates
column18: while Alphabet reported higher-than-expected revenues for the Q4. Both Netflix's and Facebook's top and bottom line for the Q4 beat our respective estimates.For the overall Technology sector
column19: we now have Q4 results from 84% of the sector's total market cap.Total earningsfor these companies are up +7.4% from the same period last year on +5.4% higher revenues
column20: with 71.1% beating EPS estimates and 78.9% beating revenue estimates.In the past three months
column21: the tech sector jumped 9.8%
column22: remaining one of the best performers among the S&P 500 sectors. In the last one month
column23: the tech sector rose 2.7%
column24: way above the S&P 500's gain of 0.7%. Additionally
column25: mutual funds related to this sector registered strong returns. According to Morningstar
column26: technology mutual funds have returned 10.6% over the last three months.Buy These 3Mutual FundsHere

column16: DIA's low point in its 52 week range is $155.26 per share
column17: with $201.3001 as the 52 week high point - that compares with a last trade of $201.07. Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average Â».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column18: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column19: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column20: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column21: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column22: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had   notable inflows Â»"

column1: Here's How Apple Inc. Plans On Doubling Services Revenue Over 4 Years;2/7/2017;"If you've been paying close attention
column2: you'll notice thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has been very conscientiously trying to shift   investor focus away from things like iPhone unit sales in favor   of recurring revenue sources like services.That's why the iPhone maker even introduced a non-GAAP metric   for installed base-related purchases in early 2016
column3: only tostop reporting itjust a few quarters later (likely due to the SEC cracking down on   companies abusing non-GAAP metrics). The iPhone sold rather well   over the holiday quarter
column4: setting a fresh quarterly record
column5: but   Apple is still very much wanting investors to better appreciate   its services business.iCloud. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();For 2016
column6: Apple's services revenue hit a new milestone
column7: crossing $25 billion in revenue for the first time. Services   should even be large enough to be a stand-alone Fortune 100   company in 2017. Not one to rest on its laurels
column8: Apple is   ambitiously hoping todoubleservices revenue over the next four years.150 million subscriptions and countingOn the earnings call
column9: CEO Tim Cook noted that Apple now bills   over 150 million paid subscriptions through the various content   platforms that it operates. That includes both Apple's own   services as well as third-party subscriptions. This is a new   metric that Apple has not disclosed previously
column10: and it will be   important to see this number grow (if Apple continues providing   updates
column11: that is). There was no update on how many Apple Music   subscribers the company now has
column12: but the most recent update from   December was 20 million.Apple Music. Image source: Apple.More color surrounding these subscriptions would go a long way   toward analyzing the services business. I have no shortage of   questions. Are those 150 million subscriptions all discrete   users
column13: or are there multiple subscriptions per user? What's the   average monthly recurring amount? What categories (such as video
column14: audio
column15: or other) are seeing the most interest? Has there been any   uplift from thereduced 15% cuton long-term (longer than one year) subscriptions? Many   enterprise-oriented apps utilize subscription models; how much is   the enterprise contributing to subscriptions?When asked how Apple will get to its goal
column16: CFO Luca Maestri   did add some additional detail:And what is particularly interesting to us is to see that     the number of people that are transacting on our stores is     increasing strong double digits
column17: and we're also seeing that the     [average revenue per user] per paying customer is increasing     double digits
column18: right? So it's a combination of the two
column19: obviously the quality and the quantity of content that we make     available in our services improves all the time. And we also     see that as people getting to the platform and start     transacting on the platform
column20: and we keep track of their     behavior over time
column21: we actually see that they tend to spend     more and more over time.Interestingly
column22: Maestri also noted that iCloud storage and   AppleCare are growing ""very well"" and are at all-time highs as   well. Apple last cut iCloud storage prices in late 2015
column23: making   the service more competitive with rivals (iCloud storage used to   be overpriced). Meanwhile
column24: services like iCloud Photo Library   increase the need for cloud storage. On the AppleCare front
column25: more   customers tend to buy Apple's extended warranty when newly   designed products come out due to the higher initial repair   costs
column26: and those new MacBook Pros with Touch Bars are both new   and pricey.Take what you can getHere's another way to look at it: Product sales are unlikely   to be major growth drivers at this point since the businesses are   already so large. The only new product that could theoretically   start taking off is Apple Watch
column27: but we know the smartwatch   market is in the dumps and Apple still aggregates its wearable in   the ""Other Products"" segment. It's unlikely that Apple Watch will   suddenly become a $25 billion business within the next couple of   years (the entire Other Products segment is under $11   billion).If total revenue remains relatively flat
column28: but services can add   another $25 billion in sales over the next few years
column29: that would   represent over 10% growth. I'll take that.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column30: it can pay to listen. After all
column31: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column32: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column33: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column34: 2017Evan Niu
column35: CFAowns shares of Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the following options:     long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95     calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Biometrics And Payments: Companies Are Using Your Fingerprints For Cybersecurity;2/7/2017;"The endless catalog of alphanumeric passwords
column2: pins numbers
column3: and rising online security breaches and frauds is one of the harsh realities of the digital payment ecosystem. In order to strengthen the security of transaction mechanisms while retaining convenience
column4: the payments industry is fast exploring alternative methods
column5: biometrics being one of them.Biometrics is a unique way of identifying a person using biological traits such as fingerprints
column6: hand geometry
column7: DNA
column8: IRIS scan
column9: voice waves
column10: and facial recognition.With its unique ability to reduce rejection rates of authentication
column11: combat cybersecurity threats
column12: overcome user disdain for stronger passwords and provide a smoother user experience
column13: more and more companies are embracing the use of biometrics to add an extra layer of safety to their operations.makeArticleAd();According to astudy
column14: biometrics is fast becoming a part of consumer lives with approximately 190 million mobile devices (smartphones and wearables) enabled with some form of biometrics as of 2016 and such installation is projected to exceed 600 million devices by 2021.It is furtherestimatedthat there will be 770 million biometric authentication apps downloaded annually by 2019. These figures highlight the growth in the biometric technology
column15: its market size
column16: and adoption rate.The biometrics market isexpectedto reach more than $30 billion by 2021
column17: backed by a boost from consumer electronics
column18: particularly smartphones. According to areportby PricewaterhouseCoopers
column19: â€˜biometrics and advanced authenticationâ€™ lists among the top five cybersecurity spending priorities for the next 12 months.Hereâ€™s a look at some of the companies in the payments industry which have adopted some form of biometrics.Apple
column20: Inc. (AAPL)has been a trendsetter of fingerprint scanners for authentication since 2013. ItsTouch IDis now available across itsdevicesfor making payments via ApplePay. In fact
column21: areportpoints out that Apple Pay will â€œpush the number of biometrically authenticated transactions to nearly 5 billion by 2019
column22: up from less than 130 million in 2015.â€One of the recentpatentsgranted to Apple pertains â€œto capacitive fingerprint sensing systems
column23: and more particularly to the use of an electrostatic lens to increase the resolution of a capacitive sensing system.â€Samsung Electronics Co.
column24: Ltd. (SSNLF)provides an alternative to the traditional password with Samsung Pass. WithSamsung Pass
column25: instead of less-secure passwords
column26: users are offered to use a fingerprint scan or iris scan for authentication purposes. Samsung Pay offers fingerprint authentication and is working on NextG biometric sensors to make Samsung Pay and its devices more secure.A 2016studybyVisa
column27: Inc. (V)in Europe reveals that â€œtwo-thirds of consumers want to use biometrics when making payments while three-quarters see two-factor authentication
column28: where a form of biometrics is used in conjunction with a payment device
column29: as secure.â€ Back in September 2015
column30: VisaintroducedEMV Chip-based biometrics trial to allow cardholders to use fingerprint readers in lieu of passwords at ATMs owned by South Africaâ€™s Absa Bank.In October 2016
column31: MasterCard Incorporation (MA)launchedan exciting pilot project to boost the security of transactions at checkout counters in stores by using facial recognition by simply taking a â€˜selfieâ€™ to authenticate payments. In case of a web store
column32: the authentication is done via finger scan or selfie recognition.PayPal Holdings
column33: Inc. (PYPL)made its first move into the biometric space in 2014 when itcollaboratedwith Samsung Galaxy to be able to pay on mobile and in-store using fingerprints. In 2016
column34: Lenovo partnered with PayPal
column35: Intel and Synaptics to secure online transactions with a finger touch. PayPal in the App Store also supports Touch ID authentication.Alipaythe worldâ€™s largest third-party platform operated byAnt Financial Services Groupthat had spun-off from Alibaba(BABA)in 2011 began toprovidefacial recognition as a simpler and more secure login method to its customers in December 2015. Last year
column36: Ant Financial Services Group announced the acquisition of EyeVerify
column37: â€œthe creator of Eyeprint ID
column38: a patented
column39: secure mobile eye verification technology.â€ Theaccuracyprovided by Eyeprint IDâ€™s is 99.99%
column40: the same as Touch ID. In January 2017
column41: Ant Financial announced of its acquisition of MoneyGram International
column42: Inc. (MGI).Final WordGiven the fact that people are complacent with easy and repeated passwords
column43: the job for digital hackers has become easier
column44: making it harder for service providers to provide security. Areportby Verizon points out that â€œ63% of confirmed data breaches involved leveraging weak

column1: Apple Inc. Talks iPhone Upgrade Rate;2/7/2017;"Apple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone 6s product line
column2: launched in September   2015
column3: ultimately underperformed the company's wildly successful   iPhone 6 product line in terms of sales. A key reason for this
column4: Apple CEO Tim Cook told investors at the time
column5: was due to the   company's seeing fewer customers opting to upgrade their iPhones   during the iPhone 6s cycle than it did during the iPhone 6   cycle.""From an upgrade perspective
column6: during the first half of [fiscal   2016]
column7: the upgrade rate for the iPhone 6s cycle has been slightly   higher than what we experienced in the iPhone 5s cycle two years   ago
column8: but it is lower than the accelerated upgrade rate that we   saw with iPhone 6
column9: Cook explained back on the company's April   2016 earnings call.Apple iPhones. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();On Apple's most recent earnings call
column10: CFO Luca Maestri   provided some insight into what the upgrade rate is looking like   for the current iPhone 7 product cycle -- let's take a closer   look.More of the same
column11: but that's not badMaestri explained that the percentage of Apple's iPhone   installed base that has upgraded to the company's latest iPhone   7-series smartphones ""has been very similar to"" what the company   saw with the prior-generation iPhone 6s-series smartphones.Although last year's iPhone 6s cycle proved to be a bit   disappointing
column12: this news is much better delivered this time   around than it was last year for several reasons.First
column13: Apple's iPhone installed base has likely grown year   over year
column14: so a constant upgrade rate applied to a larger   installed base should mean that more phones get sold -- clearly a   positive for Apple.Next
column15: investors often focus on year-over-year trends. Last   year
column16: the upgrade rate that Apple saw with the iPhone 6s relative   to the iPhone 6 negatively affected the company's financial   results year over year. This year
column17: a flat upgrade rate relative   to the prior generation means that the year-over-year financial   result comparisons won't be as tough.And
column18: finally
column19: while the percentage of the iPhone installed   base that migrates to the latest iPhones might be flat generation   over generation
column20: Apple seems to be getting a boost by selling a   richer product mix.As I notedhere
column21: Cook told investors that the company is selling more iPhone 7   Plus phones as a percentage of total iPhone 7-series (i.e.
column22: ""new   product"") sales than it did of its prior-generation iPhone 6 Plus   or iPhone 6s Plus. The Plus models are more expensive than their   non-Plus counterparts
column23: so this is a positive for Apple's iPhone   product mix and
column24: ultimately
column25: revenue.Can Apple accelerate that rate in the future?Maestri offered some additional insight into the factors that   impact the upgrade rates of Apple's new iPhones.""The point that I think I need to make when you think about   upgrade rates
column26: clearly
column27: this issue of the strong dollar doesn't   help us
column28: Maestri began.He then went on to suggest that if the company weren't forced   to raise iPhone pricing in certain countries because of foreign   exchange movements
column29: the company could potentially ""sell   significantly more and significantly faster from an upgrade cycle   standpoint.""Beyond the foreign exchange situation
column30: Maestri also pointed   out that ""the more [Apple is] able to innovate with new   generations of products
column31: clearly that plays a role in the upgrade   rate.""The rumors swirling about Apple's next-generation iPhone   models suggest that the improvements could be much more   significant generation-over-generation than what the company   delivered with the iPhone 7-series. Time will tell if they are   enough to catalyze the iPhone upgrade rate that Apple sees.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column34: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Apple Inc.â€™s Ultra Accessory Connector: Donâ€™t Panic! (AAPL);2/7/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of the biggest PR headaches forApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is connectors. Last year
column3: the company ditched the 3.5 mm headphone jack on the iPhone 7
column4: then eliminated virtually every legacy port in favor of USB-C on the new MacBook Pro. Those moves required a slew of dongles
column5: adapters and connectors
column6: generating a litany of complaints.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonWhen news broke yesterday that the company was adding support for a new Ultra Accessory Connector - or UAC - panic ensued. Smaller than either USB-C or Lightning
column7: speculation that AAPL might be preparing to switch to UAC quickly spread.Apple fans (and accessory makers) can take a deep breath. AAPL has confirmed Ultra Accessory Connector is the new name for an old standard
column8: and it's adding UAC to its MFi (Made-for-iPhone) program at the request of headphone manufacturers.The Ultra Accessory ConnectorSpeculation that AAPL might surprise everyone with a new Apple port began with a9to5Macreport. The site uncovered a developer preview withsupport for a new Ultra Accessory Connectorthat ""in some cases will replace the use of Lightning and USB connectors."" UAC is smaller than both USB-C and Apple's own Lightning port.Naturally
column9: given AAPL's laser focus on making its devices thinner
column10: that rapidly ramped up speculation the company could be preparing to move the iPhone and iPad to UAC from Lightning.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThe Vergewas quick to chase down the UAC story. According to its sources
column11: the Ultra Accessory Connectoris not part of a plan to introduce a new Apple port. Instead
column12: it's the official name for an old connector that has been in use by various companies. For example
column13: Nikon Corp (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NINOY) uses it as a connectivity option with digital cameras.The Vergesays that headphone manufacturers asked AAPL to add support for the Ultra Accessory Connector in its MFi program.Why the Panic Over UAC?AAPL has gained a reputation for ditching existing ports for new versions
column14: especially when that new Apple port is smaller
column15: letting it shrink its devices. AAPL fans have been particularly riled up over the last six months. First came the decision to eliminate the 3.5 mm headphone jack in the iPhone 7 in favor of Lightning or wireless headphones.Next
column16: when Apple released the long-awaited new MacBook Pro
column17: it replaced all legacy ports with the new USB-C. Those decisions have meant the expense and inconvenience of dongles and adapters to make old accessories work.And in 2012
column18: AAPL created the mother of all headacheswhen it switched from the Dock Connectorit had used since the launch of the iPod
column19: to the Lightning Port. That move let Apple make the iPhone thinner
column20: but made a decade worth of speakers
column21: chargers and other accessories incompatible with the new generation of devices. Manufacturers had to revamp their product lines to incorporate the new Apple port and consumers fumed.Xiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock -- What Happened?So you can understand the concern when news of the Ultra Accessory Connector leaked.UAC Is a Ripple Effect From the iPhone 7 Headphone JackAt this point
column22: it looks as though the Ultra Accessory Connector is just the latest aftershock from that controversial decision to kill the headphone jack with the iPhone 7. While many iPhone buyers are shrugging and simplygoing wireless
column23: there is still demand for wired headphones.And even wireless needs to plug intosomethingto recharge. A growing number of manufacturers are offering USB-C headphones
column24: but that means the cable is incompatible with those Lightning-equipped iOS devices. AsThe Vergepoints out
column25: having AAPL support the Ultra Accessory Connector lets those companies stick a  Lightning-to-UAC and USB-C-to-UAC dongle with their headphones to keepeveryonehappy â€¦ except the people who hate dongles.As of this writing
column26: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!Is Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?The postApple Inc.'s Ultra Accessory Connector: Don't Panic! (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."
