column1: Did Intel Corporation Just Reveal That It Will Be Inside of the Apple Inc. iPhone 8?;2/7/2017;"OnIntel's(NASDAQ: INTC) most recent earnings call
column2: CFO Robert Swan   provided some insight into the company's gross profit margin   guidance for the full year of 2017.Intel guided to full-year gross profit margin of 62% on a GAAP   basis for 2017 -- a 110 basis point (1.1%) improvement from the   60.9% gross profit margin that it reported for 2016.A pair of Apple iPhones. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Interestingly
column3: Intel tells investors to expect gross profit   margin of 62% in the first quarter of 2017
column4: which suggests that   the company isn't expecting margins to improve throughout the   year. This is a little bit surprising
column5: as Intel usually enjoys   the benefit of revenue leverage during the second half of any   given year relative to the first half
column6: since industrywide   personal computer sales tend to be higher in the second half of   the year compared to the first.Swan explained what's going on
column7: and from that explanation
column8: the   chipmaker appears to be betting on having won cellular modem   orders for the next-generationApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone.The CFO speaksSwan said that ""headwinds"" to the company's gross profit   margin in 2017 compared to 2016 will come in the form of   increased non-volatile memory product sales
column9: as well as from   modem sales. The executive was quick to explain that   increased memory and modem sales lead to ""good growth
column10: increasing   profitability
column11: [and] good earnings."" That said
column12: he also conceded   that those products carry lower gross profit margins than the   rest of the company's business.The way to think about it is this: It's generally better for a   company to sell $100 worth of product at 60% gross profit marginand$30 worth of product at 30% gross profit margin -- diluting the   average gross profit margin percentage to 53% -- than to just   sell the $100 worth of product at 60% gross profit margin
column13: assuming all else is equal.What does this have to do with the iPhone 8?Circling back to the topic at hand
column14: let's go over why this   commentary might suggest that Intel is inside the next   iPhone.If we look at the trend in Intel's cellular modem revenue
column15: we   see that the company saw an initial ramp-up of shipments during   its third quarter
column16: with sales accelerating in the fourth quarter.   This is consistent with Apple's iPhone ramp-up plans: it builds a   bunch of phones in anticipation of the launch
column17: sells even more   phones in the quarter following the launch
column18: and then it sees   iPhone sales cool off in the following quarters -- until the   cycle begins anew.If Intel doesn't expect to be in the next-generation iPhone
column19: then investors should expect the company to see a substantial   drop in cellular modem revenue during the second half of 2017.   (In this case
column20: Intel would only be shipping modems into older
column21: discounted iPhone 7 models.)In that case
column22: cellular modemswouldn'tbe a headwind to gross profit margin improvement for Intel during   the second half of 2017 relative to the first half of 2017
column23: since   its cellular modem volumes/revenue would naturally decline --   proving atailwindto average gross profit margin
column24: not aheadwind.It seems likely
column25: then
column26: that Intel expects to be inside of at   least some of Apple's next-generation iPhone models.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Intel wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: The Unlikely S&P 500 Rally Is Still Well Intact (Deserved or Not);2/7/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEDITOR'S NOTE: Sam Collins will return on Feb. 21.makeArticleAd();The bulls may have been firmly in charge of the market on Friday
column3: inspired by a strong employment report for January. As has been the case so many times since December though
column4: the rally lacked follow-through. TheS&P 500'sclose of 2
column5: 292.56 yesterday was 4.86 points down from
column6: or 0.21% below
column7: Friday's last trade.And that was more or less the story for theNasdaq Compositeand theDow Jones Industrial Average. The Nasdaq fell 3.21 points to end the session at 5
column9: while the Dow slumped 19.04 points
column11: to close at 20
column12: 052.42. None of the major indices made their way into new-high territory
column13: though all of them remain within striking distance of record-high levels.Energy stocks were the day's big loser
column14: giving up 0.9% even though crude oil eked out a gain of 0.36% on Monday
column15: to close at $53.20 per barrel; investors were more concerned about the dollar's strength and what it may mean for oil stocks.Schlumberger Limited(NYSE:SLB) did the most damage
column16: with a 1% stumble.At the other end of the spectrum
column17: technology stocks finished the session with a tiny gain of 0.1%.Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) carried the weight there
column18: with a 1% gain of its own.The weakness was broad too. For the NYSE
column19: 59% of its listings lost ground
column20: and 37% advanced The Nasdaq's breadth was similarly bearish
column21: with 60% of its issues losing ground versus 35% of them rising on Monday. Even so
column22: depth - selling volume - was modest. The NYSE's total trade was only 3.11 billion shares
column23: down a bit from Friday's action. The NYSE's and the Nasdaq's bullish/bearish volume ratios essentially mirrored both indices' advancer/decliner ratios.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99Still
column24: a handful of names overcame marketwide weakness.Hasbro
column25: Inc.(NASDAQ:HAS) was one them. Shares of the toymaker jumped 14% following the company'sfourth quarter earnings reportthat topped expectations.The overall market remains in its tepidly bullish mode
column26: framed as much by horizontal boundaries as it is by rising lows and rising highs. For the S&P 500
column27: that horizontal floor is at 2253. More recently though
column28: the index has found support at a modestly meaningful rising support level
column29: and it remains above the 20-day moving average line.To start the next leg of bullishness though
column30: the S&P 500 will need to clear the 2
column31: 301 ceiling where it peaked two weeks ago.Click to EnlargeThe Nasdaq Composite is also knocking on the door of a breakout. Monday's high of 5
column32: 668 is right below the high from two weeks ago.Click to EnlargeWhile momentum is bullish
column33: there's no denying stocks are technically overextended and struggling to tack on more gains with any amount of consistency. The S&P 500 is now 6% above the 200-day moving average line after having rallied 10% since the early November low. That's a tough act to follow
column34: particularly this time of year.February is generally a tough month
column35: and even tougher when it's the first February of a four-year Presidential term. The S&P 500 essentially breaks even this month (and then only because it finishes strong following a mid-month lull)
column36: and when it's the year after an election
column37: February averages a 1.6% loss.Still
column38: until the indices actually start to break under key technical levels
column39: the undertow has to be considered bullish even if valuations are reaching uncomfortable levels again. The S&P 500 is now valued at a trailing P/E of 21.2. That doesn't leave much room for gains
column40: which is why they've been so slow-going of late.Today's Trading LandscapeTo see a list of the companies reporting earnings today

column42: click here.As of this writing

column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Is Still Finding Growth;2/7/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMicrosoft Corporation(NYSE:MSFT) used to be a one-trick
column3: maybe two-trick pony less than 10 years ago. My how things have changed.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Under founder Bill Gates
column4: DOS and then Windows operating systems were on virtually every computer that wasn't anApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) machine. And that dominance continued unabated until the dotcom bubble burst.It wasn't the ensuing crash that hurt
column5: it was the fact that tech had reached a point of inflection.From then on
column6: it wasn't just about owning a fiber-optic switching company with a triple-digit price-to-earnings ratio. One of the sayings from those heady times was
column7: if it doesn't have a triple digit P/E
column8: it's not worth buying.The crash meant the internet and tech itself was growing up. There was plenty of consolidation that happened after the dotcom crash. Some worked out
column9: some didn't. But it was necessary for companies that were going to survive to find a way to pivot into the new marketplace.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99It was also around that time that Microsoft was embroiled in a major antitrust case with the U.S. Government. This meant that MSFT had to change on many levels
column10: just to survive. It was crucial to find a way out of this
column11: because most of the government computers were running Windows
column12: and if Microsoft couldn't find a bright path through the case
column13: it may well lose a very lucrative long-term contract.By 2006
column14: Gates was out of day-to-day operations and his No. 2
column15: Steve Ballmer
column16: took over. While he started strong
column17: it wasn't long until it was apparent that doing the same thing a little differently was not going to cut it as technology was expanding rapidly and interconnections were popping among different tech fields.In 2014
column18: the current CEO
column19: Satya Nadella
column20: took the helm and began to completely reorganize the company
column21: shedding unprofitable and unwieldy divisions and focusing on the future of the company. That meant cleaning up the mess created by the acquisition of the mobile phone business ofNokiaand building a robust cloud-based business for both operating systems and for client storage.It certainly helped that he was previously head of MSFT R&D. But some were still skeptical of his approach
column22: especially in the early days
column23: when the new divisions weren't getting much traction and the established businesses were left wanting - remember Windows 8?Now three years into his role
column24: Nadella has gone from potential goat to real hero. And the most recent earnings number prove out his strategy. He has remained focused and disciplined
column25: and it has paid off.Microsoft has committed $1 billion into cybersecurity investment for its services as well as R&D. The company is reporting 600
column27: 000 attacks a week
column28: up from about 20
column29: 000 just three years ago. But it's not as much the threat as the opportunity. According to tech sitetechemergence.com
column30: there's an artificial intelligence-based cybersecurity market that will be worth $8.3 trillion market by 2035 in the U.S. alone.And given the fact that the U.S. government is one of MSFT stock's biggest clients
column31: security is crucial.Why GoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Deserves More PatienceGoing hand in hand with this is the impressive growth of Azure
column32: Microsoft's cloud-based operating and storage system. Revenue growth year over year is running around 93% and Azure is getting big enough to compete with Amazon Web Services
column33: the cloud division ofAmazon.com
column34: Inc(NASDAQ:AMZN).Recent earnings were solid overall and there's no reason to think MSFT stock has seen its best days already. And while its 30 P/E may look expensive
column35: AMZN is trading at a P/E of 185. And MSFT also delivers a solid 2.4% dividend as well.Richard Band'sProfitable Investingadvisory service helps retirement savers outperform the market without losing a minute of sleep along the way. His straightforward style and low-risk value approach has won seven Best Financial Advisory awards from the Newsletter and Electronic Publishers Foundation.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryThe postMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Is Still Finding Growthappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How Apple
column2: Inc.'s Share Repurchases Are Driving Record Results;2/6/2017;"Many investors don't fully appreciate just how powerfulApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) share repurchase program is
column3: or how tangible its   benefits are. This is one of (if notthe) most accretive capital return programs out there
column4: simply by   virtue of its size.Most of the time
column5: companies opt to merely offset the dilution   associated with stock-based compensation to employees. But Apple   buys back its stock hand over fist
column6: and the result is a   significant reduction in shares outstanding. Look no further than   Apple's share count since its capital return program started back   in late 2012.makeArticleAd();AAPL Shares Outstandingdata byYCharts.To date
column7: Apple has now cumulatively repurchased an incredible   $143.7 billion in less than five years. That's larger than the   market caps of many mature megacap companies (those worth over   $100 billion). As of right now
column8: Apple's board has authorized $175   billion in share repurchases
column9: and the company provides annual   updates to its capital return program every April.Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author. Calendar quarters     shown.The company has tended to allocate more of its capital return   program toward repurchases
column10: confident that shares are   undervalued. I'd expect the board to do likewise for 2017.Image source: Apple.Record EPS
column11: brought to you by share buybacksApple noted that it set several records last quarter
column12: including revenue records for many of its most important   businesses. Earnings per share also hit a new all-time quarterly   record of $3.36
column13: despite the fact that net income was down   modestly in dollar terms at $17.9 billion.MetricQ4 2015Q4 2016Net income$18.4 billion$17.9 billionDiluted EPS$3.28$3.36Shares used in diluted EPS5.59 billion5.33 billionData source: SEC filings. Calendar quarters shown.In no uncertain terms
column14: the aggressive share repurchase   activity led to a meaningful reduction in shares outstanding
column15: which is what allowed Apple to post its highest quarterly EPS   ever. That's what I call earnings accretion. For shareholders
column16: a   record bottom line is as tangible as it gets.Ideally
column17: Apple continues its capital return program with the     same emphasis on share repurchases. But in order to continue at     the same rate
column18: Apple may need to repatriate some cash since it     is now approaching $100 billion in total debt
column19: including     commercial paper and its recent $10 billion bond offering.     Since the capital returns have largely been funded with debt
column20: and there is a limit to how much debt Apple can take on
column21: Apple's domestic cash could be the most significant limiting     factor to continued repurchases.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column22: it can pay to listen. After all
column23: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade

column1: Apple
column2: Inc. Is Now Approaching $100 Billion in Debt;2/6/2017;"Just days afterApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) earnings release last week
column3: the company raised a   cool $10 billion in debt. Like prior bond sales
column4: this one   consisted of numerous tranches with maturities of up to 30 years
column5: and included both fixed-rate notes as well as some floaters.   There wasn't really much that was notable about the bond offering   itself; it's comparable to the paper that Apple sells every   year.PrincipalFixed or FloatingmakeArticleAd();RateMaturity$500 millionFloating3-month LIBOR plus 8 basis points2019$500 millionFloating3-month LIBOR plus 20 basis points2020$1 billionFloating3-month LIBOR plus 50 basis points2022$500 millionFixed1.55%2019$1 billionFixed1.9%2020$1.5 billionFixed2.5%2022$1.75 billionFixed3%2024$2.25 billionFixed3.35%2027$1 billionFixed4.25%2047Data source: Prospectus.However
column6: it was done a bit earlier the usual this time around
column7: and Apple is now approaching $100 billion in debt.It's the time of the seasonTypically
column8: Apple conducts these bond offerings shortly after   providing updates to its capital return program
column9: which is usually   alongside its April earnings release. They usually occur in April   or May. But Apple needed to sell the bonds slightly earlier this   year for a few interrelated reasons.Apple Store in Sydney. Image source: Apple.Apple entered into its ninth accelerated share repurchase   program last quarter
column10: and total share repurchases were $11   billion. That took a big bite out of Apple's domestic cash   position
column11: and the company exited the quarter with $15.9 billion   in domestic cash. That's the low end of Apple's comfort zone;   Apple usually keeps its domestic cash in the range of $15 billion   to $25 billion for operational and strategic needs.Note how Apple's domestic cash has dwindled in recent years   due to aggressive capital return activity. (This chart does not   reflect the recent bond offering.)Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author. Calendar quarters     shown.The company simply blew through its domestic dollars a little   faster than usual this year with share repurchases.$100 billion and countingSince debt largely funds Apple's massive capital returns
column12: the   debt load that it has taken on over the past five years is   commensurately large. At the end of 2016
column13: Apple had $87.5 billion   in long-term debt (including the current portion) and commercial   paper
column14: which is just short-term unsecured debt. The recent $10   billion bond offering will now bring that figure up to around   $97.5 billion.The offering was still able to fetch investment-grade credit   ratings
column15: but it goes without saying that the more debt that Apple   takes on over time
column16: the worse its credit rating profile becomes.   Meanwhile
column17: there's been a lot of talk about a potential tax   repatriation holiday from the Trump administration. If Apple is   able to bring home a meaningful chunk of the $230.2 billion that   now sits overseas
column18: it could theoretically extinguish some of that   debt and strengthen the balance sheet. That could effectively   give Apple a few more years to continue its debt-funded capital   return strategy.Until then
column19: Apple will just have to keep selling paper.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Monday Apple Rumors: AAPL May Release Augmented Reality Glasses This Year;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is more news of augmented reality glasses. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.makeArticleAd();Augmented Reality Glasses:A continuing rumor claims that Apple will release a pair of augmented reality glasses later this year
column4: reportsBGR. This rumor comes from Robert Scoble
column5: who previously made similar claims. According to Scoble
column6: the new device from AAPL will come out at the same time the company announces another major event. He claims this may be the opening of the spaceship campus
column7: or the revealing of the iPhone 8. Scoble is also predicting the tech company will release a completely see through iPhone this year.iOS 10.3 Beta:AAPL has released the second beta of iOS 10.3 to developers
column8: MacRumorsnotes. The new beta can be downloaded via the company's Developer Center or from an over-the-air update. The release of the beta comes two weeks after the release of the first iOS 10.3 beta to developers. The new beta includes the Find My AirPods feature and changes to the company's file system. Several other changes are other present in the beta.watchOS 3.2 Beta:The second beta for watchOS 3.2 is now available
column9: reports9to5Mac. The new beta includes several new features that will be coming to the Apple Watch. This includes a Theater mode that silences the device while watching movies. The feature also turns off raise-to-wake on the smartwatch. It also brings SiriKit to the Watch
column10: which will allow developers to add Siri compatibility to their apps.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: AAPL May Release Augmented Reality Glasses This Yearappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Who Are Uber's Biggest Competitors?;2/6/2017;"Uber
column2: the massive
column3: omnipresent ride-sharing company

column23: or if you want to ride with a large group). You can select which type of ride you want with a slider tool at the top of the app.As for rates

column1: Twilio Inc (TWLO) Q4 Earnings Preview;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTo sayTwilio Inc(NYSE:TWLO) has taken investors on something of a roller coaster ride over the course the past eight months would be a considerable understatement. Twilio stock rallied from its June IPO price of $15 to a high near $71 by September
column3: only to peel back to a low of less than $26 in January.makeArticleAd();Source:Web Summit Via FlickrSince hitting that low
column4: TWLO stock has gained more than 20% â€¦ right in front of the Twilio earnings report due after Tuesday's close.The conundrum: Twilio has yet to trade based on any semblance of ""value."" It has been and continues to be driven by a perception of potential
column5: and that perception is altered on a pretty regular basis. Hence the big swings in just a few short months.The good news is
column6: Tuesday's Q4 earnings report will likely answer some of the question that investors have been asking about the company's future.The bad news is
column7: owners of Twilio stock may not like those answers.Twilio Q4 Earnings PreviewTwilio
column8: for those not familiar with it
column9: has turned cloud computing technologies into a robust telephony and messaging tool. Anything an individual business could want to do with
column10: or through
column11: a smartphone or app
column12: TWLO can make it happen securely
column13: en masse
column14: via the cloud.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99It's a relatively young company
column15: too. Twilio has only been in business since 2013
column16: and a publicly traded company since the middle of last year.Revenue growth hasn't been a problem at any point
column17: though. For the quarter ending in September
column18: the top line of $71.5 million was up 61% on a year-over-year basis
column19: and estimates for a top line of $74.2 million are 44% better than Q4 2015's sales.What has been a sore spot
column20: though
column21: is earnings - or a lack thereof. Twilio isn't profitable
column22: and isn't expected to be anytime soon. Analysts anticipate a loss of 5 cents per share on Tuesday
column23: though that would be a slight improvement on the 10-cent loss booked in the same quarter a year earlier.3 Things TWLO Stock Holders Need to Chew OnClearly Twilio stock is still a story stock
column24: rocked more by rhetoric and assumption than by actual results. Results - relative results - will set the tone for the rhetoric
column25: though
column26: and that rhetoric will largely be shaped by three overarching ideas.In no particular order â€¦An 'Even If' Valuation:The market is mostly OK with the lack of earnings thus far
column27: and the unlikelihood of a swing to a profit in the foreseeable future. As was noted
column28: the story aspect of this company has been more than compelling enough to keep trades interested.They're becoming increasingly suspicious
column29: however
column30: that even if Twilio were to turn a typical 10% profit on its revenue
column31: the valuation still makes no sense. At its current annual revenue run rate of $290 million
column32: $29 million worth of income still doesn't make sense of the company's current market cap of $2.8 billion.Its Relationship With Facebook:The Twilio platform integrates (quite nicely) with Messenger and WhatsApp
column33: fromFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column34: which accounts for roughly a fourth of the company's revenue now thatMessenger was added to the mix last year. But that's not guaranteed revenue going forward.As Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brendan Barnicleobserved following the Q2 Twilio earnings report:""Variable revenue ($8.1 million) was down 14% sequentially and dropped to 12.6% of revenue from 16%. While some investors may worry about the decline
column35: we believe that it largely reflects the lumpiness of revenue from WhatsApp
column36: Twilio's largest customer and the main component of variable revenue.""Slowing Growth/Outlook:As was noted
column37: traders had been willing to pay a premium for TWLO stock because its red-hot growth rate presumably would catch up with the stock's valuation
column38: and even spur a profit. The anticipated top line for its fourth quarter is barely better than its Q3 revenue
column39: and even analysts that expect a top-line beat aren't looking for a big one - only about $3 million.Here's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Hit $200To that end
column40: Twilio needs to serve up some plausible Q1 and full-year (2017) revenue guidance that's better than the current figures of $77.85 million and $352.6 million
column41: respectively.Bottom Line for Twilio StockThough TWLO shares may finally look like they're on the mend after paying the usual post-IPO price - a major setback - between September and December
column42: it's still a bit too soon to make such an assumption. The rally since early January may still be nothing more than a relief rally in the wake of amajor inflow of new TWLO stock that had been tied up until December 22nd.The pressure remains on the company to prove its worth. Tuesday's report will either do so
column43: or it won't
column44: and it looks to be a 50/50 proposition at this time.Look for fireworks either way.As of this writing
column45: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWhy Valeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc (VRX) Stock Will Finally StabilizeAdvanced Micro Devices
column46: Inc. (AMD) Stock: 2 Reasons to Steer Clear7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018The postTwilio Inc (TWLO) Q4 Earnings Previewappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Fitbit Inc (FIT) Needs to Sell Itself
column2: But Probably Wonâ€™t;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLess than two years after clearing $50
column4: Fitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) stock trades around $6. A series of disastrous earnings reports has sent Fitbit stock tumbling. The most recent was the disclosure of preliminary Q4 results last week
column5: which imply a nearly 20% decline in sales year-over-year in the key holiday quarter.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitCompetition fromApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column6: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column7: andGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN)
column8: among others
column9: appears to be a key problem for the company
column10: particularly in the U.S. The resulting decline in growth has had a substantially negative effect on FIT stock.That's not going to get better.Lately
column11: Fitbit has been compared toGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO)
column12: another company that drove explosive growth mostly off a single product only to see sales nosedive. The question is whether in this day and age
column13: a single-product company can support the expense necessary to compete with behemoths like Apple and Samsung. The answer
column14: at least from Fitbit and GPRO
column15: appears to be no.And that would seem to argue for a sale of FIT to one of those larger players. The problem for Fitbit stock investors
column16: however
column17: is that such a move seems unlikely - at least before it's too late.Why FIT Should Sell ItselfIn response to the lower demand in Q4
column18: FIT is cutting costs. It's laying off 6% of its staff
column19: part of an overall effort to cut $200 million a year in operating expense. That's a substantial amount of savings
column20: given that Fitbit stock has a market cap under $1.4 billion at the moment.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketBut what's less important than what is being saved is what's left: some $850 million in fiscal 2017
column21: according to the company. It's a huge amount of money for what
column22: at its core
column23: still is a single-product company. Yes
column24: FIT is adding software to create a ""platform""
column25: and its product line goes beyond its most popular wearable. But compared to the diversification of an Apple or a Samsung
column26: there's no comparison.Fitbit has to build an expense base to support one product; its competitors (even Garmin) support multiple products. That matters not only in terms of cost
column27: but in terms of sales. It's easier for Apple to cajoleBest Buy Co Inc(NYSE:BBY) to push the Apple Watch when Best Buy is also selling millions of dollars' worth of MacBooks and iPhones. FIT doesn't have that leverage
column28: and expecting it to compete with electronics giants seems simply foolhardy.As for the cost structure
column29: even with the $200 million in reduced spend
column30: FIT is guiding for a loss next year. (That loss excludes the cost of stock grants issued to Fitbit executives
column31: no less.) With one product
column32: there's no ability to spread out expense for everything from salespeople to R&D to IT. FIT is likely going to spend $240 million in 2016 just on sales and marketing - for one product!That expense rose 23% through the first three quarters - the cost of trying to be David against multiple Goliaths. But the story seems likely to end much more poorly for Fitbit stock.Why Fitbit Stock Won't Sell ItselfFrom that standpoint
column33: a sale of FIT stock to a larger player would seem to make sense. Apple
column34: Samsung or Garmin all would make sense. The Fitbit brand remains strong
column35: and an acquirer almost certainly could cut hundreds of millions of dollars itself. A slimmer (pardon the pun) FIT would thus add a nice amount of profit
column36: even assuming a premium paid to acquire Fitbit stock.There are a couple of problems with this scenario. The first is that Fitbit stock has a dual-class system. FIT is thus controlled basically by its two founders and venture capital firm True Ventures. One of those founders
column37: CEO James Park
column38: saidin the release accompanying the preliminary fourth-quarter figures that the company simply was in ""a temporary slowdown and transition period"".As long as Park
column39: along with True Ventures and co-founder Eric Friedman
column40: believe the weakness is only temporary
column41: Fitbit won't sell itself. And if Park is wrong
column42: and Fitbit is surpassed by larger players
column43: by then
column44: it will likely be too late.3 Reasons Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Is Much More Than Its Main PlatformAnother issue
column45: counterintuitively
column46: is FIT's huge cash balance. The company expects to have $700 million in cash at the end of Q4 - over half of its market capitalization. But that cash also limits the premium an acquirer will pay for Fitbit stock. The enterprise value at the moment - what the market says the business is worth - is about $670 million. Assuming Fitbit could get twice that price from an acquirer
column47: it would have to sell itself for only about $9.30 per share.So hopes of a FIT acquisition rest
column48: essentially
column49: on the co-founders of the company agreeing to sell the business for more than 80% less than it was worth less than two years ago. That's a highly unlikely outcome. Park and Friedman are going to believe Fitbit can turn around - it'stheircompany. They turned their idea into a business worth over $10 billion not that long ago; it's silly to think they would then sell it for a bit over $1 billion at this point.And maybe FIT can turn itself around
column50: which would certainly drive upside in Fitbit stock. But it seems a very difficult path. While it's hard to think of a billion-dollar company as a ""little guy
column51: Fitbit is a little guy when compared to its competition. And in this day and age
column52: it's awful tough for the little guy to go at it alone.As of this writing

column1: Is Fitbit Inc. a Bear Trap or Bull Trap?;2/6/2017;"Shares ofFitbit(NYSE: FIT) recently fell to an all-time low after the fitness   tracker maker released dismal fourth quarter preliminary earnings   and bleak guidance for fiscal 2017. The company now expects its   fourth quarter revenue to fall 18%-20% annually
column2: missing its   prior guidance for 4% growth and representing its first   year-over-year decline since its IPO.Image source: Fitbit.makeArticleAd();On the bottom line
column3: it expects a non-GAAP net loss of   $0.51-$0.56 per share
column4: compared to its prior guidance for a   profit of $0.14-$0.18 per share. That's a big drop from its   profit of $0.35 in the year-ago quarter
column5: and represents its first   unprofitable quarter. Fitbit says it sold 6.5 million devices   during the quarter
column6: which represents a 21% decline from a year   earlier. Non-GAAP gross margin is also expected to be ""materially   below"" its prior forecast of 46%
column7: which already represented an   all-time low.And that pain won't end anytime soon. Fitbit expects to   generate just $1.5-$1.7 billion in revenues in fiscal 2017
column8: which   would represent a 26% decline (at the midpoint) and miss the   consensus estimate of $2.4 billion. It will also remain in the   red with a non-GAAP net loss of $0.22-$0.44 for the year
column9: well   below expectations for a profit of $0.64. Lastly
column10: it announced   that it would lay off 110 employees
column11: or 6% of its workforce
column12: to   reduce its operating expenses.With numbers this bad
column13: it's easy to hate this stock. But some   contrarian investors might also argue that the stock has fallen   too fast and too far. Let's take a closer look at the bullish and   bearish cases for Fitbit
column14: and see why it could burn both   sides.Why Fitbit could be a bear trapFitbit has been averypopular target for short sellers over the past year. As of this   writing
column15: 43% of its shares are being shorted. But when short   interest is that high
column16: anypositive news about Fitbit -- a new product
column17: aggressive cost   cutting measures
column18: or acquisition buzz -- could trigger a short   squeeze.With an enterprise value of $680 million and an EV-to-sales   ratio of just 0.3
column19: Fitbit is very cheap. That makes it a   lucrative buyout target forApple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column20: Garmin(NASDAQ: GRMN)
column21: or other companies looking to expand into the   wearables market. By buying Fitbit
column22: Apple could expand its   wearables reach beyond the Apple Watch
column23: which failedto turn smartwatches into mainstream gadgets. Garmin could buy   Fitbit to broaden its fitness tracker portfolio and further   diversify its business away from its weaker automotive GPS   unit.Image source: Fitbit.Fitbit has also been diversifying its business with mobile   payments and  its acquisitions of Pebble's assets and   Vector's smartwatches -- indicating that it could soon create   feature-rich smartwatches tethered to an app ecosystem. That   ecosystem could bolster Fitbit's user loyalty figures while   diversifying its top line. It could also sign more corporate   wellness partnerships to secure more bulk enterprise orders.   Fitbit expects its financial performance to ""stabilize"" in the   second half of 2017 as it reduces its operating expenses   (especially sales and marketing) by $200 million -- so the stock   could bottom out soon.Why Fitbit could be a bull trapHowever
column24: the numbers all suggest that Fitbit is still   struggling to carve out a niche between low-end rivals likeXiaomi
column25: sports performance challengers like Garmin
column26: and high-end   smartwatch makers like Apple. Fitbit is still the largest   wearables maker in the world with 23% market share
column27: according to   research firm  IDC. But its market share rose just 1.6   percentage points between the third quarters of 2015 and   2016.That topped Xiaomi
column28: Garmin
column29: and Apple's year-over-year growth
column30: but it didn't outpace the growth of the ""others"" category --   which grew from 37% to 45%. This indicates that the market is   becoming saturated with smaller players
column31: which could drive down   price expectations.Meanwhile
column32: downsizing in the face of fierce competition is   rarely a winning strategy. By reducing its sales and marketing   spend
column33: Fitbit could be marginalized by other wearables makers   throughout the year. A 6% workforce reduction also might not be   enough to strengthen its bottom line growth. Looking ahead
column34: Fitbit will likely acquire additional companies in a desperate   bid for growth
column35: but inadvertently ""diworsify"" its business   instead.My verdict: It's a bull trapFitbit looks undervalued
column36: but its disastrous fourth quarter   numbers indicate that its core business model is crumbling
column37: and   that mainstream demand for wearables hasn't been as robust as   analysts had predicted. I believe that investors should stay far   away from this fading stock
column38: but I'll still keep an eye out for a   silver lining when it reports its full fourth-quarter earnings on   Feb. 22.10 stocks we like better than FitbitWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column41: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column42: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Fitbit wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column43: 2017Leo Sunhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple and Fitbit. The Motley Fool has     the following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Hereâ€™s How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Hit $200;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) delivered excellent earnings news Jan. 31 that pushed Apple stock to its highest level since the summer of 2015.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's great news for long time owners of Apple stock who've had to suffer through a deluge of naysayers proclaiming its lack of innovation. More than a few have even suggestedinvestors dump AAPL stockand buyMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) stock in its place.Hey
column3: I like Microsoft and I think what it'sdoing in the cloudis going to help it continue to grow over the next decade
column4: but it's not in the same league when it comes to revenue and profit growth. Microsoft does
column5: however
column6: have a business model that's transitioning from one-time product sales to ongoing monthly recurring revenue
column7: something many observers have noted is happening at Apple.Yes
column8: Apple did sell more than78 millioniPhones in the first quarter
column9: roughly five million more than it sold in the same quarter a year earlier
column10: but it was the service revenue that had everyone in a tizzy.Jim Cramer likened the Apple business model tothe Gillette business model
column11: where consumers buy a single razor and keep buying new razor blades; only in Apple's situation the iPhone is the razor and services such as the App Stores are the razor blades.You gotta love recurring revenue. Cramer does:""What has dogged Apple's stock for ages
column12: what has kept its share price so low
column13: at least in terms of its valuation
column14: is the 'Blackberry-ization' issue
column15: Cramer said onMad MoneyFeb. 1. ""The notion that in the end
column16: the iPhone is just a device and device companies eventually get wasted asBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) did.""7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThere's no question recurring revenue is good for a company's top and bottom line and should be welcome news for owners of Apple stock
column17: but is it enough to drive Apple stock through its all-time high of $134.54 and upward to $200?That's debatable.While Apple's services revenue hit$7.2 billionin the first quarter
column18: 18% higher than a year earlier
column19: it's still only 9% of the company's overall revenue
column20: or 100 basis points higher than a year earlier.By comparison
column21: Microsoft's second quarter saw its service and other revenueincreased 29.7% to $7.5 billion. The only problem with that for Microsoft is the gross margins are 40% compared to 67.5% for its product revenue
column22: which accounted for 68.5% of its overall revenue.You want your recurring revenue gross margins to be higher than your product margins
column23: not lower; because if that's the way the world is headed
column24: both stocks are looking at lower profits in the future.Apple doesn't break down its gross margins between products and segments. Overall
column25: its gross margin in Q1 2017 was 38.5%
column26: 160 basis points less than in Q1 2016. Microsoft's overall gross margin in its latest quarter was 58.9%
column27: considerably higher than Apple's.That would seem to suggest Microsoft's in a better position when it comes to service revenue. It is both growing this aspect of its business faster than Apple and making more from every dollar of revenue. From this perspective
column28: Apple is doomed.A quick look farther down the income statement
column29: however
column30: provides some clarity: Apple's operating margin in Q1 2017 was 29.9%; Microsoft's Q2 2017 operating margin was 25.7%
column31: or 420 basis points less than Apple.The biggest reason for this difference: Microsoft spends about three times as much per year on research and development as Apple does; Apple spent 4.7% of its revenue in the trailing 12 months on R&D compared to 14.4% for Microsoft. And when you're talking about billions of dollars of annual revenue
column32: the difference adds up quickly.Which brings us back to Apple's growing service revenue: InvestorPlace contributor Brad Moon highlightedthe positives of Apple's services revenuerecently. A couple of his points stick out for me.Don't Bet Against the Dow Jones Industrial AverageFirst
column33: the App Store had $3 billion in revenue in December - a record. Secondly
column34: Apple paid out more than $20 billion to developers in 2016. Extrapolate December's App Store sales over 12 months and you get $36 billion in revenue. Subtract $20 billion paid to developers in 2016 and that leaves a gross profit of $16 billion and a gross margin of 44%
column35: which is pretty darn healthy considering very little R&D is required to keep that up and running.Can recurring revenue take Apple stock to $200? I believe it can. When
column36: however
column37: is another story.As of this writing
column38: Will Ashworth did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Big Buyout Deals That Could Crush Investors9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99The postHere's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Hit $200appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Xiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock â€” What Happened?;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOnly a few years ago
column3: Xiaomiwas worryingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) investors. Xiaomi had become the world's third-largest smartphone manufacturer and was expanding into other products like fitness trackers
column4: TVs and video streamers. It was valued at $45 billion
column5: hired a prominent executive away fromAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google and planned an expansion into America.makeArticleAd();Source: XiaomiToday? It has dropped out of the top five smartphone vendors list
column7: marketshare in China has plummeted
column8: the Google exec has jumped ship and some analysts are valuing the company as low as $3.6 billion.What happened to Xiaomi and is its threat to Apple truly neutralized? Or are the troubled Chinese tech giant's plans merely on hold?Xiaomi's Rapid RisePrivately held Xiaomi was founded in 2010
column9: released its first smartphone in 2011 and rapidly gained popularity in China. The company offered high-quality in its smartphones
column10: with low pricing -a combination that led to it being the top-selling smartphone brand in China by 2014.It came seemingly out of nowhere to capture thethird place spot for worldwide smartphone salesthat year as well. The feat was especially impressive given that Xiaomi was not selling its phones in the U.S. market.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99Like Apple
column11: Google andSamsung Electronics Co Ltd(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column12: the company wanted to expand into consumer electronics in general. That effort included the inexpensive Mi Band fitness tracker that vaulted Xiaomi intosecond place worldwide for wearable salesby 2015
column13: behind onlyFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT).The company pursued a strategy of investing in hardware startups
column14: buying into dozens of companies making everything from smart lighting to headphones and TVs. While these products are not always Xiaomi-branded
column15: they are designed to all work well together.It also added software and services to the mix.Chinese CompetitionThe success of Xiaomi spurred homegrown competition. Other Chinese manufacturers stepped up to the plate and followed Xiaomi's formula. However
column16: they did a better job of marketing to increasingly demanding Chinese consumers by charging a little more but offering more striking designs. One of these companies -Huawei- was good enough that Googlepartnered with it to build the Nexus 6P smartphone in 2015. Xiaomi's phones seem lower quality than these competitors and rather than innovative
column17: its designs are often seen as being too similar to Apple's.At this point
column18: Xiaomi has been leapfrogged by its Chinese smartphone rivals. While Xiaomi has dropped off the global top five smartphone manufacturer list
column19: China's Huawei
column20: OppoandVivocurrently hold the third
column21: fourth and fifth places.American ObstaclesKey to Xiaomi's ambitions were an expansion into the U.S. market. To lead that effort
column22: thecompany hired Hugo Barra- the VP who oversaw Android product management - from Google.However
column23: Xiaomi's U.S. push has failed to materialize. There are dozens of products Xiaomi offers online through itsMi Store(which carries only a fraction of Xiaomi's and its partner companies' gear)
column24: including eight different smartphone models
column25: multiple smart TVs
column26: VR headsets and even a self-balancing electric scooter. U.S. customers are limited to being able to buy a few sets of earbuds
column27: a pair of headphones
column28: a battery pack and a Bluetooth speaker.A big part of the problem in moving into the U.S. market is that Xiaomi has taken advantage of China's relatively lax approach to patents. In late 2014
column29: it wasbanned from selling smartphones in Indiaas a result of a patent infringement ruling (it has since resumed Indian operations). If Xiaomi tried to push into the U.S. with its smartphones at this point
column30: there's a good chance Apple and other tech companies would sue it into oblivion.In an attempt to defend against this scenario
column31: Xiaomi has begun buying up patents. Last year
column32: it purchased 1
column33: 500 patentsfromMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) relating to areas like wireless communication
column34: multimedia and video
column35: and the cloud.No Longer a Threat to Apple?At this point
column36: Xiaomi is a paper tiger that isvalued at as little as $3.6 billion. In 2015
column37: it sold 70 million-plus smartphones
column38: missing its initial goal of 100 million and then the revised goal of 80 million. It's refusing to say how many it sold in 2016
column39: but that silence speaks volumes.Hugo Barra bailed on the companya few weeks ago
column40: joiningFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB). A few months before leaving
column41: he toldReutersthat lower smartphone sales wouldn't impact the companybecause it made no money on them:""Basically we're giving [handsets] to you without making any moneyâ€¦ we care about the recurring revenue streams over many years. We could sell 10 billion smartphones and we wouldn't make a single dime in profits.""The problem with that approach is that as of 2015
column42: smartphones still accounted for 95% of the company's revenue. All those other products and services just don't seem to be sticking.Barra also told reporters not to expect Xiaomi to release a smartphone in the U.S. in 2017.3 Reasons Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Is Much More Than Its Main PlatformXiaomi CEO Lei Junposted a letter to employeeson Facebook in January. In it
column43: he admitted the company had pushed ahead too fast
column44: cutting into its long-term growth
column45: but says the worst is over.The company's revenue target is RMB 100 billion (roughly $14.5 billion) -the same as its 2015 target. In trying to be so much
column46: so fast
column47: Xiaomi has set itself up for some very challenging times. If treading water is the goal it has set for itself
column48: Apple doesn't have much to worry about.As of this writing
column49: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryThe postXiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock - What Happened?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Tech Companies Take a Stand Against Trump's Immigration Ban;2/6/2017;"Immigration has been a driving force behind many of the   leading technology companies in the United States.Some
column2: includingMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column3: are led by CEOs who were not born in this   country while over 200 companies on the Fortune 500 were started   by immigrants or their children. In addition most top tech brands   are global
column4: with offices all over the world
column5: and talent working   domestically that was not born in the U.S.At least partly because of that nearly 100 technology   companies including Microsoft
column6: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column7: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column8: Facebook
column9: Twitter
column10: and many others have filed a legal brief in the U.S. Court of   Appeals for the 9th Circuit opposing President Donald Trump's   temporary immigration ban keeping people from seven predominantly   Muslim countries from entering the U.S. In the brief the   companies argue that the ban ""inflicts significant harm on   American business.""makeArticleAd();Trump signed an executive order banning immigration from     seven predominantly Muslim countries. Image source: Getty     Images.What are they opposing?In one of his first acts as president
column11: Trump signed an   executive order banning refugees and visa-holders from seven   predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States.   That order has been stayed by aU.S. District judgeand an appeals courtdeclined to immediately reinstatethe presidential order. The technology companies
column12: many of which   operate and employ workers in and from the impacted countries   filed their brief to show their opposition to the president's   actions.""Immigrants make many of the Nation's greatest discoveries
column13: and create some of the country's most innovative and iconic   companies
column14: the brief states. ""America has long recognized the   importance of protecting ourselves against those who would do us   harm. But it has done so while maintaining our fundamental   commitment to welcoming immigrants -- through increased   background checks and other controls on people seeking to enter   our country.""The companies that signed the brief acknowledged what Trump   was
column15: at least on the surface
column16: trying to accomplish with the   executive order.""We share your goal of ensuring that our immigration system   meets today's security needs and keeps our country safe
column17: said a   draft of that letter obtained byBloomberg News. ""We are concerned
column18: however
column19: that your recent Executive Order   will affect many visa holders who work hard here in the United   States and contribute to our country's success.""Tech requires global talentPutting aside any political questions
column20: the tech industry   opposes Trump's immigration ban in part because it takes global   talent to compete. The U.S. simply does not produce enough   workers -- specifically coders who write the software that powers   the products made by these companies -- to meet demand.To fill those needs companies across the U.S. use H1B visas to   receive special dispensation to hire workers who otherwise would   not be able to legally work in the country. A H1B visa
column21: according   toMyVisaJobs.com
column22: allows U.S. employers to temporarily employ foreign   professionals in specialty occupations for three years
column23: extendable to six years. ""To qualify for H1B Visa
column24: the foreign   professional must hold a bachelor's or higher degree from an   accredited college or university in the specialty occupation
column25: according to the site. In some cases specialized training can be   substituted for a degree.Technology companies dominate the list of employers using   workers on H1B visas. Data compiled by MyVisaJobs.com shows that   in 2016 Infosys held the top spot
column26: having sponsored 25
column27: 405 visas.   while Microsoft
column28: Apple
column29: and Alphabet were all in the top 25.It's about more than self interestIt's easy to see the business reasons behind why these   technology companies oppose Trump's immigration restrictions.   Most
column30: if not all of the companies that filed the brief would be   impacted by having employees unable to travel and in some cases   the executive order would impact hiring.For at least some of these companies
column31: however
column32: the opposition   goes beyond pure business logic. Many of these brands were either   founded by immigrants or by the children of immigrants and   immediate business concerns aside
column33: they simply want a world where   new immigrants to the U.S. can be free to move here and found the   next Microsoft
column34: Apple
column35: or Alphabet.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 5 Must-Read Quotes From Skyworks Solutions' Latest Investor Call;2/6/2017;"Analog semiconductor manufacturerSkyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS) recently reportedstrong fiscal first-quarter resultsthat came in ahead of management's guidance. Traders cheered the   report
column2: sending shares up by double digits.While Skyworks' press release had a lot of good information to   share
column3: the company's conference call is also a great source of   additional insights. Below are five must-read quotes from the   call.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();On diversifying the businessOne of the biggest knocks against Skyworks is that the company   is overly reliant onApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . That argument holds water today
column4: as the Mac   maker still accounts for more than 40% of Skyworks' total   revenue.However
column5: management affirmed on the call that the company is   growing quite well with all of its customers
column6: not just Apple.   Here's what CEO Liam Griffin had to say about the company's   growth excluding its ""largest customer"":Our growth and success outside of our largest customer has     been outstanding. Huawei became the No. 2 account for us this     last quarter. They're going to continue to be one of our     leaders. We have our customer in Korea who will continue to     grow significantly into 2017. And our largest customers will     set up very well for us as well
column7: as we address some very     complex architectures with compelling products. So we feel     really good about that on the mobile side.And then let me remind you that the broad market portfolio
column8: from infrastructure to IoT [Internet of Things] to early stages     of automotive
column9: all look good
column10: and the staff there are     double-digit year over year.CEO Griffin also rattled off several examples of new-design   wins or expanding relationships with these other customers.   Specifically
column11: he called out relationships with companies such asComcast
column12: Netgear
column13: Ubiquiti Networks
column14: Xiaomi
column15: ""multiple tier 1 OEMs
column16: among others.On returning to year-over-year growthApple's decision in 2016 to reduce its channel inventory   levels had a big impact on Skyworks. In fact
column17: Skyworks revenuedeclinedyear over year in each of the last three quarterly reports
column18: which   isn't something that growth investors like to see.Thankfully
column19: CFO Kris Sennesael says that the days of declining   sales growth are over:I think we've weathered a bit of a storm here in 2016 and     most of the clouds there have abated. And it's not just market     shifts. We're gaining share
column20: we're creating new content
column21: we're     expanding in IoT and in broad markets
column22: and it's meaningful
column23: and     it's sustainable. We're confident that the second half for us     ... should be a double-digit growth rate year-over-year.For the upcoming quarter
column24: management is guiding for revenue   growth of 8% and earnings-per-share growth of 12%. That's got to   make bulls smile from ear to ear.On the next phase of growthIt is possible that smartphone sales are nearing a plateau
column25: so   Skyworks likes to remind investors that a few technologies will   be hitting the mass market soon that could drive the company's   next phase of growth. Specifically
column26: management remains   uber-bullish on the opportunities that will be opened up once 5G   network technology and autonomous driving become a part of   everyday life.Here's CEO Griffin talking about the potential of 5G network   technology:[M]arket projections suggest 5G data rates will approach 10x     the speed of current 4G and LTE systems. To put this in     perspective
column27: downloading a full-length HD movie in 3G took 1     day. In 4G the same file took minutes. On a 5G network
column28: this     content will be downloaded in mere seconds.And Griffin commenting on the extreme data needs of autonomous   vehicles:Looking out over the next few years
column29: the amount of data that     will be delivered to and from the car is estimated to be 5 to     10 times more than the bandwidth used by today's smartphone.     For instance
column31: a single autonomous car is expected to     consume 4
column32: 000 gigabits of data per day in real-time     diagnostics
column33: positioning
column34: vehicle-to-vehicle communications.     And that's equivalent to the daily data consumed by more than     2
column35: 000 smartphone users in 2017.On taking care of shareholdersSkyworks has been returning its excess capital to shareholders   for years in the form of buybacks and dividend payments. Here's   CFO Sennesael commenting on the company's recent actions to   continue to reward shareholders:We are definitely committed to continuing to return cash to     the shareholder with our dividend program and our share buyback     program. We returned $106 million in Q1
column36: repurchasing 1.4     million shares in Q1.And so we have now put in place a new $500 million program.     Historically
column37: we have been returning 40%
column38: 50% of our free cash     flow to the shareholders
column39: and so that's something that we will     continue to do so.All in all
column40: Skyworks delivered an excellent quarter
column41: and   provided shareholders with plenty of reasons to remain   optimistic.10 stocks we like better than Skyworks     SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Prime Air Drones Surprise in Super Bowl Ad;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf you were one of the estimated 100 million+ viewers of Super Bowl 51
column4: you saw some drones. There were the 200 quadcopters fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) that were part of Lady Gaga's halftime show. Those we were expecting
column5: but another drone that showed up was a surprise.Amazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) chose the Super Bowl to tease Amazon Prime Air - packages delivered to your home by AMZN drones.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonA big part of the Super Bowl experience is the advertising. This is the one time of year when viewers actuallywantto see commercials. And with those viewersestimated at over 100 million
column7: companies that forked out over $5 million for a 30-second spot make a big splash.Heck
column8: even in Canada
column9: the networks wereforced to run American adsinstead of substituting local commercials.And those 100 million-plus viewers saw a very short teaser commercial with anAmazon drone hoveringoutside the window of a woman who had just ordered some snacks: Amazon Prime Air.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatAccording to the voice of Alexa
column10: AMZN's personal digital assistant
column11: we can ""Look for delivery soon.""History of Amazon Prime AirHow can you talk about the history of a service that doesn't yet exist? In the case of Amazon Prime Air and its use of Amazon drones
column12: there's already a big backstory to talk about. AMZNhas a websitewhere it describes the services
column13: shows off a number of Amazon drone videos and even has an FAQ section that spikes out many of the details about Amazon Prime Air.""We're excited about Prime Air - a delivery system from Amazon designed to safely get packages to customers in 30 minutes or less using unmanned aerial vehicles
column14: also called drones. Prime Air has great potential to enhance the services we already provide to millions of customers by providing rapid parcel delivery that will also increase the overall safety and efficiency of the transportation system.""The Amazon Prime Air storykicked off in 2013
column15: when AMZN CEO Jeff Bezos took the wraps off a top secret project with Amazon drones on60 Minutes. Delivery of items under five pounds that would fit in the quadcopter's bucket would take place in under 30 minutes. At the time
column16: Bezos told viewers to expect Amazon Prime Air within four to five years.Last December
column17: a milestone was reached when AMZN claimedthe first Amazon drone delivery- an Amazon Fire TV and a bag of popcorn. As part of an Amazon Prime Air trial in the U.K.
column18: the company's drones had begun autonomously delivering packages to a very small group of consumers.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!At the end of the year
column19: the company hit the news again when it was discovered it hadfiled a patent for a flying warehousethat would serve as an airborne base for Amazon drone deliveries.When Can You Expect an Amazon Drone atYourWindow?Despite the Super Bowl ad and Alexa's promise that Amazon Prime Air is coming soon
column20: it's a little early to get excited yet. In particular
column21: there are regulatory hurdles to overcome. FAA restrictions on drones that aren't flying in line-of-site operation were the primary reason why the Amazon drone trial is taking place in the U.K. instead of here. AMZN even put up a small disclaimer on its ad:""Prime Air is not available in some states (or any really). Yet.""But the fact that it spent the big Super Bowl ad bucks and showed off that Amazon drone to millions of viewers shows AMZN is serious about this. Amazon Prime Air may not be launching tomorrow
column22: but the company is determined to get people excited about drone delivery. The campaign to turn Amazon drone delivery into the next big thing has officially begun.As of this writing
column23: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceIs Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postAmazon.com
column24: Inc. (AMZN) Prime Air Drones Surprise in Super Bowl Adappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: Google's Brand Is Not More Valuable Than Apple's;2/5/2017;"Last week
column3: Brand Finance came out with itsannual listing of brand valuations. In a somewhat shocking finding
column4: the consulting group declared   thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) had lost its supremacy toAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary Google.Alphabet is a phenomenal company with a long track record of   innovation
column5: and the Google brand is extremely powerful.   Nevertheless
column6: it still isn't in the same league as Apple's brand   in terms of total value.Is Apple turning sour?While Brand Finance still rates Apple as the second most   valuable brand in the world
column7: it appears to have a fairly negative   view of the iPhone maker. According to the recent report:makeArticleAd();However
column8: Apple's evangelists are beginning to lose their     faith. The snaking queues of early adopters have shrunk almost     to the point of invisibility. Apple has failed to maintain its     technological advantage and has repeatedly disillusioned its     advocates with tweaks when material changes were expected.Put simply
column9: Apple has over-exploited the goodwill of its     customers
column10: it has failed to generate significant revenues from     newer products such as the Apple Watch and cannot demonstrate     that genuinely innovative technologies desired by consumers are     in the pipeline. Its brand has lost its luster and must now     compete on an increasingly level playing field not just with     traditional rivalSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF)
column11: but a slew of Chinese brands such as     Huawei and OnePlus in the smartphone market
column12: Apple's key source     of profitability.As a result of this assessment
column13: Brand Finance reduced its   estimate of the Apple brand's value by 27% year over year
column14: to   $107.1 billion. Meanwhile
column15: it estimated Google's brand value at   $109.5 billion
column16: up 24% from $88.2 billion a year ago. Brand   Finance cited Google's dominance in search
column17: among other things
column18: to justify the big increase in its brand value.Consumers are paying more and more for iPhonesBrand Finance's declining opinion of the Apple brand is   contradicted by consumers' willingness to pay more and more for   iPhones. Last quarter
column19: Apple reported record quarterly iPhone   sales of 78.3 million units. Even more impressively
column20: the average   selling price (ASP) reached a new record of $695.The iPhone's ASP hit a new record last quarter. Image     source: Apple.In the same quarter two years ago
column21: right after Apple released   the hugely popular iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus
column22: the iPhone's ASP   had surged 8% year over year
column23: to $687. Apple's ability to   continue growing that ASP over the past two years
column24: despite facing   stiff foreign exchange headwinds in both years
column25: is a testament to   the massive value of its brand.Indeed
column26: the cost of high-quality smartphones is coming down.   Leaving aside Samsung
column27: several Chinese manufacturers have become   known for designing high-quality smartphones and selling them at   near-breakeven prices in recent years. Apple's ability to command   a huge price premium over competitors -- which extends beyond   smartphones to PCs and (to a lesser extent) tablets -- indicates   that its brand is as strong as ever.Apple is a profit machineAccording to Brand Finance
column28: Apple has failed to maintain a   technological lead over Samsung and other rivals. In fact
column29: many   tech pundits have argued in recent years that Samsung has   overtaken Apple in terms of innovation.Assuming that the two companies are on a relatively even   technological footing
column30: they should be able to produce roughly   similar earnings. However
column31: that's not even close to being   true.Last quarter
column32: Apple barely retook the lead in terms of   smartphone shipments with 78.3 million
column33: compared to 77.5 million   shipments for Samsung
column34: according to Strategy Analytics. Yet Samsung's mobile-division operating profit totaled just   $2.1 billion for the quarter. By contrast
column35: Apple's operating   profit was more than 10 times higher at $23.4 billion.On a full-year basis -- or looking just at the smartphone   business -- Apple's advantage is somewhat smaller. But any way   you slice it
column36: Apple generates many times more profit than   Samsung. (In its most recent fiscal year
column37: Apple's operating   profit was $60 billion
column38: compared to about $10 billion for   Samsung's mobile division.)If Apple doesn't have superior technology relative to Samsung
column39: its brand must be doing most of the heavy lifting to generate $50   billion of additional operating profit on an annual basis. That's   more than double Alphabet'stotalannual operating profit of $23.7 billion.Google may be a powerful brand. However
column40: it doesn't come close   to the value of the Apple brand
column41: which has turned the   traditionally low-margin technology hardware business into a   long-term cash cow that churns out tens of billions of dollars of   profit every year.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column42: it can pay to listen. After all
column43: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column45: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Apple Inc. Has Big Plans for Its Fast-Growing Services Business;2/4/2017;"Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) is primarily a hardware company. Most of its   revenue comes from the sale of iPhone
column2: iPad
column3: and Mac products.   Beyond those key product categories
column4: the company generates   meaningful revenue from its Apple Watch family of smartwatch   products
column5: as well as from the various accessories
column6: such as its   well-received AirPod line of wireless earbuds.Apple music running on different Apple products. Image     source: Apple.makeArticleAd();However
column7: one of the most exciting parts of the company's   portfolio is the services business
column8: which the company says   ""includes revenue from Digital Content and Services
column9: AppleCare
column10: Apple Pay
column11: licensing and other services.""This segment has been on a robust growth path for quite some   time
column12: with revenue here growing 10% in the company's fiscal year   2015 and then a whopping 22% in fiscal year 2016. In the   company's most recent quarter
column13: it reported that services revenue   was up another 18% year-over-year.This isn't a small business
column14: either -- at least in absolute   terms. It generated more than $24 billion in the company's last   fiscal year
column15: making up more than 10% of the company's   consolidated revenue. To really put it into proper perspective
column16: services was Apple's second-largest business by revenue in 2016   -- bigger than the iPad and Mac.On the company's most recent earnings call
column17: CEO Tim Cook made   public the company's vision for services over the next four   years
column18: and it's quite ambitious.Doubling revenue in just four years""Services are becoming a larger part of our business
column19: and we   expect the revenues to be the size of a Fortune 100 company this   year""
column20: Cook said.Cook then went on to say that Apple ""feel[s] great about this   momentum"" and that the company aims to ""double the size of [its]   Services business in the next four years"".Of course
column21: what Apple's goals are and what happens aren't   necessarily the same thing
column22: but the fact that management is   willing to put a growth figure out there -- a hard number that   investors will now hold Apple accountable for -- speaks to the   company's confidence.What would a doubling of this business mean?Put simply
column23: doubling the business from the revenue levels seen   in 2016 would mean that
column25: Apple's services business will   be bringing in about $48 billion. If Apple can get the business   to that scale and then grow it at a modest rate from that point   forward (perhaps 5% to 10% annually)
column26: then that would do wonders   for Apple's longer-term revenue growth prospects.What's not entirely clear
column27: however
column28: is how that growth will   translate into incremental profitability. CFO Luca Maestri said   on the call that
column29: on average
column30: the gross profit margin of Services   businesses ishigherthan the corporate average
column31: so an increase in Services mix should   help Apple on the gross profit margin front.That said
column32: as Apple scales up its services revenue
column33: it will   likely need to drive up operating expenses associated with the   business
column34: as well. While I do expect nice growth in profitability   from a boost in services
column35: the incremental gross profit isn't all   flowing to the bottom line.At the end of the day
column36: if Apple hits its growth target with   respect to this growing segment
column37: it should be less dependent on   the iPhone and could ultimately see earnings multiple expansion   as software/services companies tend to be valued more by   investors than pure hardware plays.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
