column1: Are Garmin Ltd. (GRMN) and Fitbit Inc (FIT) the Perfect Long/Short Play?;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRecent statistics from the two wearable rivals suggest thatGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN) is winning the war againstFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT)
column3: making a hypothetical long/short play between the two stocks a very interesting proposition.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitHowever
column4: thinking about buying Garmin and shorting Fitbit stock - and actually following through with it - are two entirely different beasts.I have never shorted a stock and likely never will; I'm just not built that way. Whenever I'm asked byInvestorPlace
column5: or any of the other financial publications I write for
column6: to do a ""sell"" piece on a stock or a group of stocks
column7: I always have a tougher time coming up with recommendations.I like to write about stocks that I would consider owning; negative spin doesn't enter my psyche. I can do it
column8: it's just harder.This brings me to GRMN stock and FIT stock
column9: the crux of this story.Why Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Can't Fall Much Lower Than ThisIn Q3 2016
column10: Garmin shipped 1.3 million wearable devices
column11: a 12.2% year-over-year increase. That compares to an 11.0% YOY increase for Fitbit. In Q2 2016
column12: Garmin shipped 1.6 million wearable devices
column13: a 106.7% increase over the same quarter a year earlier
column14: while Fitbit shipped 5.7 million wearable devices
column15: a 28.7% increase over the same quarter a year earlier.So
column16: in the nine months ended September 2016
column17: Garmin shipped 3.8 million wearable devices
column18: a 40.7% increase year over year. Meanwhile
column19: Fitbit shipped 15.8 million wearable devices
column20: a 21.5% increase year over year.Between Q1 2015 and Q3 2016
column21: Garmin's market share dropped by 40 basis points to 5.7%. During the same 18-month period
column22: Fitbit's market share dropped 980 basis points to 23.0%.Fitbit Stock Continues to DeclineSamsung Electronics(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) and the many others that compete for the 50% market share not held by Fitbit
column23: Xiaomi
column24: Garmin
column25: andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) stand to benefit the most.Garmin is a big company and wearables are but one of many revenue streams. A 40-basis-point decline isn't a big deal for a company that generated $2.2 billion in revenue in the first nine months of fiscal 2016
column26: an increase of 5.8%. If not for its auto segment (its largest by revenue)
column27: which saw a 17% decline year over year to $656.0 million
column28: 2016 has been a winner.Over at Fitbit
column29: the top line has been outstanding
column30: with revenue growing 39.3% through the first nine months of the year to $1.6 billion. However
column31: it's the bottom line that gets a little wonky.In the quarter ended Oct. 1
column33: Fitbit's operating profit declined 33.1% to $44.4 million; for the nine months ended October 1
column35: operating income declined 69.3% to $72.9 million. R&D
column36: sales and marketing
column37: and G&A expenses all have seen huge increases in 2016 as Fitbit struggles to remain on top of a wearables market that's slowing faster than anyone expected.InvestorPlacecontributor Aaron Levitt recently discussed Fitbit stock in relation to aslowing wearables market; he was pretty blunt in his assessment of the job CEO James Park is doing guiding the company through a rough patch that's seen FIT stock decline by 65% over the past year.""Both eMarketer and IDC both cite smartwatches as the big reason for the declines
column38: wrote Levitt. ""Consumers just can't see the need for them as they overlap on features already found in smartphones. And when adding their heftier price tags
column39: smartwatches are a fading fad.""So
column40: what does Fitbit do to counter the fact that wearables' 2016 growth will be less than half the 60% projection at the start of the year? It buys not one
column41: but two companies that make smartwatches.Bottom Line on Fitbit and GarminIf Fitbit continues to waste money on bad acquisitions and wasteful overhead that doesn't move the needle
column42: you can bet that Fitbit's comfy cash position - $672 million in cash and marketable securities as of Q3 - will be gone faster than you can shake a stick at.So
column43: should you go long on Garmin? Absolutely. With$1.1 billionin cash and marketable securities
column44: no debt
column45: and an operating margin of almost 21%
column46: GRMN stock is a long-term hold.3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionAs for shorting FIT stock
column47: I'm of two minds on this.Yes
column48: theshorts represent almost 36% of its floatand its margins are about one-third Garmin's
column49: but with $3 in cash it's got to be attractive to somebody in the industry - maybe even Garmin. That should keep Fitbit stock from dropping much farther.So
column50: I wouldn't recommend investors buy or short Fitbit stock. Neither proposition looks like it will be a winner any time soon.More From InvestorPlaceThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsHere's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Reclaim Its ThroneWhy Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Could Be ScrewedThe postAre Garmin Ltd. (GRMN) and Fitbit Inc (FIT) the Perfect Long/Short Play?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Will NEVER Be About P/E;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of the biggest negatives surroundingAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) is the company's sky-high price-to-earnings ratio. According to Google Finance
column5: AMZN stock currently trades at an eye-popping 191 times its trailing earnings of $4.36 per share.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut Amazon has at least given investors the courtesy of growing profits to try to somewhat justify the lofty valuation. That 191x is on trailing 12-month earnings of $4.36 per share. In fiscal 2015
column6: AMZN earned $596 million
column7: or $1.25 per share. In 2014
column8: it lost $241 million
column9: which translates into 52 cents per share.It's obvious Amazon stock investors care about growth
column10: not valuation. AMZN's sky-high P/E has been in place for years
column11: and will likely continue for some time.And that's actually OK. Here are two important reasons why:Amazon Revenue GrowthAmazon is still one of the best growth stories in today's market.When the company releases 2016's final numbers Thursday
column12: Feb. 2
column13: analysts expect Amazon to post revenue of $137 billion. That's an improvement of more than 25% versus 2015's top line - a difficult feat when you're talking about 12-digit sales. And Amazon's $107 billion in revenue last year was 20% better than 2014.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryWe live in a world in whichS&P 500constituents are doing well if they're posting just single-digit increases on the top line. You can blame this at least partly on the strong U.S. dollar
column14: which is weighing down American multinationals. But the fact remains that meaningful growth is a scarce quality in today's stock market - especially among blue-chip stocks.Thus
column15: AMZN stock is an easy way for investors to get access to big growth with relatively little risk.And Amazon is hardly running out of fuel. The company has only begun to expand into grocery and apparel - two huge categories. Trillions of dollars are spent worldwide each year at physical stores. That's not to mention the other gains Amazon still could make via the smart home
column16: Amazon Web Services cloud offerings and other newer initiatives.Analysts predict Amazon's revenue will increase another 22% in 2017
column17: hitting $168 billion. So again - the growth story is still well intact.But it's not all about growth. Many AMZN stock bulls argue that we're just looking at earnings the wrong way.Amazon Earnings: Better Than They Seem?One thing that separates Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos from many other executives is his ability to look at the really
column18: reallylong-term. He's also willing to spend billions of dollars on ideas
column19: and is OK with hitting a few duds if it means spawning great new ideas.Remember the company's smartphone? The Amazon Music Importer? How about a website called Askville? I'm guessing you might remember the Fire smartphone
column20: but not the other two. Amazon lost $170 million on its smartphone alone.This kind of risk taking is an inherent part of Amazon's culture. It's the line of thinking that prodded the company to introduce some of its biggest winners to date
column21: like cloud services
column22: Prime shipping and the Kindle.Thus
column23: many investors look at AMZN stock in a different way. They look at the company's operating profit
column24: then they add back its substantial research and development costs to get a ""truer"" sense of profitability.Admittedly
column25: that changes the picture dramatically.Apple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL)In its most recent quarter
column26: Amazon produced net income of $252 million
column27: which across 485 million diluted shares became diluted earnings of 52 cents per share. At the time
column28: AMZN was trading at $822 per share. If we annualize that profit (not a perfect measure
column29: as quarterly earnings fluctuate - this is just for an example)
column30: we're looking at a P/E of 395.But Amazon also reported operating profits of $575 million
column31: and spent $4.14 billion on R&D - a significant expense. Add those together
column32: and you get $4.715 billion
column33: or $9.72 per share. Annualize that
column34: then divide the share price by that
column35: and you get a P/E of about 21.Let's take the actual numbers. Amazon currently trades for 190 times trailing 12-month earnings
column36: as we said above. However
column37: over the past four quarters
column38: Amazon spent $15.11 billion on R&D and posted operating profits of more than $4 billion. That comes to $40.19 per share combined
column39: and puts AMZN stock at a P/E of just more than 20.That's a lot of creative accounting
column40: so take that with a spoonful of salt. But it's an interesting argument.Bottom Line on AMZN StockAmazon continues to be one of the best growth stories in today's market. As long as that continues
column41: investors aren't going to care about the headline P/E ratio. It just doesn't matter. AMZN stock has doubled several times over despite it.Amazon is solidly profitable
column42: even if the bottom line isn't as large as investors typically would like. But those earnings are being reinvested back in the business - which is what a high-growth company like Amazon should be doing anyway.As of this writing
column43: Nelson Smith did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceWhy Amazon.com

column1: Apple Inc. Bulls: Beware These Charts! (AAPL);2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares ofApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rallied a strong 6% on Wednesday following the company's latest earnings report. While the rally was impressive
column3: AAPL stock is now bumping into some critical technical resistance that bulls and bears alike should be aware of.makeArticleAd();Simply put
column4: Apple's near- to possibly medium-term upside is limited at best.Apple's revenues in the latest quarter came in at a record $78.4 billion
column5: which in part was helped by strong holiday demand for the new iPhone 7 series. These numbers are impressive
column6: and I continue to be a longer-term believer in the company - particularly around the potential of AAPL being able to monetize deeper on the devices ecosystem through more services.When Ilast discussed shares of Appleon Dec. 28
column8: I offered that if AAPL stock could clear above the $118 price level
column9: then a next upside target around $123 would come into sight. Apple met and surpassed this target on Wednesday following the earnings announcement.From that perspective
column10: Apple shares have now reached an important upside price target.AAPL Stock ChartsLet's take a step back and look at the multiyear weekly chart of AAPL stock. We see that despite the big swing lower from the 2015 highs into the mid-2016 lows
column11: and most recently back up toward the 2015 highs
column12: Apple has
column13: largely speaking
column14: not really accomplished much since early 2015.Click to EnlargeBulls
column15: however
column16: note that the May 2016 lows coincided with critical technical support made up of horizontal support (lower purple-dotted line) as well as the 200-week simple moving average (red). Equally important
column17: on the other hand
column18: is that after Wednesday's post-earnings rally
column19: AAPL is now within a few points of these aforementioned previous all-time highs from 2015. Through a technical lens
column20: this could offer up as much resistance as the 2015 lows offered support.In other words
column21: before Apple stock can sustainably break to new all-time highs
column22: a consolidation phase most likely is in order.Looking at the daily chart
column23: we see that since mid-November 2016
column24: AAPL stock has now rallied approximately 25%
column25: which is not a small move for the stock to accomplish in a matter of two-and-a-half months.Click to EnlargeA simple yet accurate observation through the lens of technical analysis is that old all-time highs are not easily overcome on the first try
column26: particularly if the stock has not consolidated below or near those previous all-time highs for some time.Apple's current chart thus is in dire need of some consolidation before it can make a better attempt at fresh all-time highs on a more sustainable basis.How to Trade Apple Stock HereI see two specific trades setting up:If AAPL stock breaks and holds below Wednesday's intraday lows around $127
column27: then the stock could be played from the short side for a mean-reversion move back into the mid- to low $120s. Alternatively
column28: options traders could also look to sell out-of-the-money call spreads on the stock at that time.Quicker traders could look to buy AAPL stock for fast profits should the stock push and hold above Wednesday's intraday highs around $130.50 for a move toward the 2015 highs around $133.Either way
column29: upside in AAPL stock through a multiweek/multimonth lens is likely limited. Trades should be constructed accordingly.Like what you see? column1: 5 Top Dividend Aristocrats to Buy in February;2/2/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();The Federal Reserve maintained interest rates in February
column2: providing no update on the next hike. The Fed's reluctance in raising rates should stand in good stead for dividend aristocrats.President Donald Trump's travel ban
column3: in the meanwhile
column4: could result in a possible rise in erratic share price movement this month. The stock market has also
column5: traditionally
column6: seen weak results this month
column7: especially after an election. In such a scenario
column8: investing in dividend aristocrats  seems prudent as they provide higher total returns with lower volatility
column9: which are undoubtedly the 'holy grail' of investing.Fed Leaves Rates UnchangedAs widely expected
column10: the Fed has kept rates unchanged following a two-day policy meeting on Feb 1. The central bank kept its benchmark overnight lending rate target at a range of 0.5% to 0.75%. The bank had lifted rates by a quarter percentage point in December
column11: marking the second hike in more than 10 years.In fact
column12: the central bank penciled three quarter-point moves this year in December. More importantly for investors
column13: the central bank didn't drop any hints of raising rates in the March meet
column14: placing the probability of such a move at only 18%
column15: according to CME Group.In this case
column16: high qualitydividend stockshave become more appealing as their stock prices don't suffer when rates aren't rising. Conversely
column17: bond markets
column18: which tend to benefit from a rise in interest rates
column19: have lost its lure.Trump Stirs Up a TempestThe Fed's positive view of the economy and Apple Inc.'sAAPLstellar earnings helped stocks rally a little higher on Feb 1. However
column20: investors have not yet recovered from the blow of Trump's immigration ban. An executive order by Trump banned immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries
column21: including legal residents and visa holders. Trump had earlier fostered expectations that his administration will be business friendly and therefore should bode well for the equity market. This decision has drawn congressional criticism and widespread protests. These protectionist measures may also cloud the path for pro-business initiatives as several world and corporate leaders condemn the ban.Airlines bore the brunt as well as several airports across the country saw violent protests
column22: disrupting operations to a great extent. Tech firms also faced obstacles in sourcing labor from foreign lands. Trump's first press conference since July also disappointed investors due to lack of policy detail. He severely criticized pharmaceutical companies over high drug prices
column23: dealing a blow to leading biotech stocks.Such uncertainties make dividend paying stocks more attractive as they tend to outperform when the broader markets are subject to gyrations. Notably
column24: the month of February has traditionally seen weak numbers just after the election.February: Traditionally a Weak MonthFebruary has been the weakest month for stocks over the past four decades
column25: averaging just a 0.06% gain. In fact
column26: in post-election years
column27: February tends to be weaker. The average return has decreased 1.85% since 1977.Lest we forget
column28: markets have gone 74 days without a 1% daily decline
column29: hence
column30: the seasonality pattern increases the odds of a wider decline in February.Why Dividend Aristocrats? 5 Solid ChoicesDividend aristocrats outperform other dividend payers on better quality business. This category of stocks reflect a solid financial structure and healthy underlying fundamentals. Such stocks are immune to market vagaries and have also raked in excellent risk-adjusted returns over the last decade. In fact

column1: 3 Tech Stocks Paying Better Dividends Than Apple;2/2/2017;"Technology stocks
column2: once the domain of high-flying growth investors
column3: are becoming an increasingly generous source of dividends for income investors. The information technology sector led the market by total dividends paid both for the third quarter of 2016 and for the 12 months that ended September 30
column4: according to a FactSet analysis of the 419 dividend payers in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Apple (symbolAAPL) was tops in the IT sector
column5: paying $12.2 billion in dividends over the 12-month stretch.But just because Apple handed out the most money to its shareholders doesn't mean it's the best source of income in the sector. In fact
column6: Apple's stock currently yields just 1.8%
column7: even less than the S&P 500's 2.1%. So we set out to find mature tech stocks with solid business outlooks that offer superior yields to Apple. Our search turned up three blue-chip names. How blue? Like Apple
column8: all three of our picks are components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Take a look.makeArticleAd();Cisco SystemsCisco Systems
column9: which makes the routers
column10: switches and modems that form the backbone of the internet
column11: is poised for better-than-expected sales growth
column12: analysts say. A recent survey of its customers by UBS Securities revealed that spending on Cisco products remains a top budgetary priority. The tech company gets good marks for being easy to work with
column13: and two-thirds of respondents said it has the best overall security offering. The growth of cloud-based computing (storing data and applications on remote servers) and the Internet of Things (the expanding digital interconnectivity of everyday items
column14: from cars to refrigerators) are long-term tailwinds for the company and the stock. UBS has a ""buy"" rating on Cisco shares.Analysts
column15: on average
column16: expect Cisco's earnings to rise by just a penny this fiscal year ending July 30
column18: according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Sales are forecast to slip 1.9% in fiscal 2017. The more bullish case for Cisco stems from projections for the following fiscal year (ending in July 2018)
column19: when profits are projected to climb 5% to $2.49 a share
column20: and revenue is expected to gain 2.4%.Cisco's dividend
column21: which dates back to 2011
column22: has increased annually. The company disbursed $5 billion in common dividends for the 12 months ended Oct. 31. That was supported by $12 billion in free cash flow
column23: or cash left over after spending the money required to operate and expand the business.SEE ALSO:10 Stocks Every Retiree Should OwnIntelConsumers are increasingly forgoing desktop computers for mobile devices. As a result
column24: PC sales have become a slowly melting iceberg. Market research firm Gartner found that PC sales fell for eight consecutive quarters as of the third quarter of 2016. That has forced Intel
column25: the world's largest maker of the central processing units that serve as a PC's brain
column26: to find new ways to generate revenue growth.The expansion of cloud-based services has been a boon to Intel
column27: thanks to its market-share dominance in server chips. True
column28: Intel faces changes in customer demands and competition from rival Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)
column29: but analysts at Stifel say it's responding well. ""Intel has been acquiring technologies and recruiting outside managerial talent to prepare for the changing market
column30: Stifel analyst Kevin Cassidy
column31: who rates Intel shares a ""buy
column32: said in a recent note to clients.Analysts expect 2017 earnings to rise to $2.79 from $2.72 a share in 2016
column33: according to Thomson Reuters. Revenue is forecast to increase 1% to $60.1 billion. Intel paid its first cash dividend in 1992
column34: and the company resumed annual dividend hikes two years ago. Intel's payout ratio
column35: or dividends as a percentage of earnings
column36: is a conservative 37% and below even the S&P 500's average ratio of 40%.SEE ALSO:3 Reasons to Own Apple Stock in RetirementMicrosoftMicrosoft is another tech company that's benefiting from the rise in cloud computing. An increasing number of customers now pay a recurring subscription fee to use its software rather than purchasing it outright. It's proving to be a hot area of growth. ""The closely watched commercial cloud business -- which includes Office 365
column37: Azure and Dynamics 365 -- continued to grow at a torrid rate
column38: reaching over $14.0 billion in annualized revenue in the second quarter [which ended December 31
column40: William Blair & Co. analyst Jason Ader said in a recent note to clients.Importantly
column41: the analyst expects Microsoft to become more profitable over time because of its ""disproportionate growth in its commercial cloud business
column42: which is being boosted by rapid customer adoption of Office 365 and Azure."" Azure is Microsoft's cloud-computing platform
column43: and Office 365 is the subscription version of its popular Office applications. Cloud-based services can have higher profit margins than traditional licensed software.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters project earnings to rise to $2.97 a share for the current fiscal year ending June 30
column44: from $2.79 in fiscal 2016. Revenue for fiscal 2017 is expected to increase 4.9% year over year
column45: to $96.5 billion. For its second quarter
column46: which ended December 31
column47: Microsoft generated $1.3 billion in free cash flow after disbursing $3 billion worth of dividends. The company has paid a dividend to its shareholders since 2003. By contrast
column48: Apple resumed paying a regular quarterly dividend only in 2012
column49: following a 17-year layoff.SEE ALSO:10 Best Dividend-Paying Stocks for 2017"

column1: Is Apple (AAPL) A Double From Here?;2/1/2017;"I talked yesterday about the Fed.  As I said
column2: I think we'll find that the Fed will shift gears again to stay behind the curve on inflation
column3: to let the economy run a little hot.  They met today and it was a non-event. They said nothing to build momentum on their rate hike from December.The news of the day has been Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) earnings.  People over the past couple of years have been calling for the decline in Apple.  They've said it's topped.  They can't innovate in the post-Steve Jobs era.  The iPhone was magic. But reproducing magic isnâ€™t easy.  Once you put a computer in everyone's pocket
column4: there's not much more they can do to it with it. These are all of the quips about Apple's peak.  They may be right.  But Apple's peak
column5: at least as a stock
column6: is greatly exaggerated.They reported a huge positive surprise on earnings yesterday after the close.  The stock was up 6% on the day.  But even before that
column7: I suspect it has become a much loved stock in the past two months in the ""smart money"" investor community.We should see in the coming weeks
column8: as big investors disclose their positioning for the end of Q4
column9: Apple will have returned to a lot of portfolios again.  Warren Buffett
column10: an investor that has made his fortune buying when others are selling
column11: built a big stake at the lows of the year last year.  And it's a perfect Buffett stock.Itâ€™s incredibly cheap compared to the market.The stock still trades at 15x earnings.  Much cheaper than the market.  Apple trades at 13x next yearâ€™s projected earnings.  The S&P 500 trades at 16.5x.  What about Apple's monster cash position?  Apple has even more cash now -- a record $246 billion. If we excluded the cash from the valuation
column12: Apple market cap goes down from $675 billion to $429 billion.  That would equate to Apple trading at closer to 9x earnings. Though not an â€œapples to applesâ€ that valuation would group Apple with the likes of these S&P 500 components that trade around 9 times earnings
column13: like:  Dow Chemical
column14: Prudential Financial
column15: Bed Bath & Beyond
column16: a Norwegian chemical company (LBY)
column17: and Hewlett Packard Enterprise. It's safe to say no one is debating whether or not Hewlett Packard is at the pinnacle of its business. Yet
column18: if we strip out the cash in Apple
column19: AAPL shares are trading closer to an HPE valuation.Add to that
column20: Apple now has afresh catalystcoming in
column21: Trump policies. The new President Trump is incentivizing Apple (and others) tobring offshore cash hoards back homewith a flat 10% tax.  And Apple makes money â€“ a lot of it.  Acut in the corporate tax ratewill be a boon for earnings.  Two years ago
column22: Carl Icahn argued that Apple should use (a lot more of) their cash to buyback shares â€“ and
column23: with that
column24: valued the stock at double its current levels.makeArticleAd();For help building a high potential portfolio for 2017
column25: follow me in ourBillionaireâ€™s Portfolio
column26: where you look over my shoulder as I follow the worldâ€™s best investors into their best stocks.  Our portfolio more than doubled the return of the S&P 500 in 2016.  You can join mehereand get positioned for a big 2017."

column1: Apple
column2: Inc. Earnings: 3 Answers From CEO Tim Cook;2/1/2017;"Ahead ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) first-quarter earnings report on Tuesday
column3: investors were primarily looking for the company to show that it   can reverse its recent declining iPhone business. And Apple didexactly this
column4: reporting 5% year-over-year growth in both iPhone unit and   revenue growth
column5: helping the company's total revenue increase 3%   year over year. Even better
column6: the company said it expected more   growth in its second quarter.But beyond Apple's financial performance
column7: investors likely had   other questions on their minds -- questions more suitable for   management's earning call following the release. To this end
column8: I   laid outthree questions Apple management would hopefully   addressduring the call. As it turns out
column9: Apple management addressed all   three of these important topics.Apple CEO Tim Cook. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Here's how Apple CEO Tim Cook and his management team answered   these three questions on Tuesday:1. How confident is management in its product pipeline?While the iPhone did return to growth in Apple's first   quarter
column10: it was still relatively slow growth. The iPhone's   headwinds have put the pressure on the company to develop new   products to help accelerate growth. While investors obviously   shouldn't have expected Apple to spill the beans on anything   specific on Tuesday
column11: Tim Cook did express confidence in the   company's pipeline of upcoming products.In Apple's first-quarter earnings press release
column12: Cook said   Apple is ""very excited"" about the products in its pipeline. And   during Apple's earnings call
column13: Cook showed even more enthusiasm
column14: saying
column15: ""we've got some exciting things in the pipeline; I feel   really
column16: really good about it.""2. What could Apple's services revenue growth look like going   forward?Services continue to grow in importance to Apple
column17: and the   company's first quarter was no exception. Services revenue   climbed 18% year over year
column18: growing to about 9% of total sales
column19: up from about 8% last year. And even this growth understates how   sharply the segment is climbing
column20: as the company's services   segment benefited from a one-off $548 million patent-infringement   payment in the year-ago quarter.App Store sales are helping fuel services growth. Image     source: Apple.Going forward
column21: Cook said (here's aReuters transcriptof the earnings call) that he expects services to become even   more integral to Apple's business:Services are becoming a larger part of our business
column22: and we     expect the revenues to be the size of a Fortune 100 company     this year. Our services offerings are now driving over 150     million paid customer subscriptions. This includes our own     services
column23: and third-party content that we offer on our stores.     We feel great about this momentum
column24: and our goal is to double     the size of our services business in the next four years.These expectations for Apple's services segment translate to a   forecast of about 20% annualized growth over the next four   years.3. If there's a tax break for repatriation
column25: does Apple plan   to take advantage of it?With President Donald Trump saying he plans to offer a one-off   tax holiday for U.S. companies to repatriate their overseas funds   at a lower tax rate
column26: investors have good reason to be interested   in what Apple's CEO thinks of this. After all
column27: of Apple's $246.1   billion in cash and marketable securities
column28: an incredible $230.2   billion is outside of the United States.Fortunately
column29: Cook talked about this potential holiday
column30: signaling he expected Apple to take full advantage:I am optimistic given what I'm hearing
column31: that there would     likely be some sort of tax reform this year
column32: and it does seem     like there's people in both parties that would favor a     repatriation as a part of that. So I think that's very good for     the country and good for Apple.But Cook said investors will have to wait to see how   repatriated funds would be allocated:What we would do with it -- let's wait and see exactly what     it is -- but as I've said before
column33: we are always looking at     acquisitions. We acquired 15 to 20 companies per year for the     last four years
column34: and we look for companies of all sizes
column35: and     there's not a size that we would not do based on just the size     of it. It's more about the strategic value of it.Beyond acquisitions
column36: Apple could obviously allocate funds   toward other capital investments in its own business
column37: a dividend   increase
column38: a special dividend
column39: share repurchases
column40: or even all of   the above.While these were some of the more important topics covered   during the call
column41: management also covered more details on the   company's services business
column42: its regional results
column43: the smartphone   market
column44: and more. Investors can find a copy of the earnings call   on Apple's investor-relations website.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column45: it can pay to listen. After all
column46: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column48: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: What Happened in the Stock Market Today;2/1/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Stocks barely budged on Wednesday despite an interest rate   announcement by the Federal Reserve and a flood of fresh earnings   reports. Through all of that
column2: theDow Jones Industrial Average(DJINDICES: ^DJI) and theS&P 500(SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) indexes each finished only marginally   higher.makeArticleAd();Today's stock market:IndexPercentage ChangePoint ChangeDow0.14%26.85S&P 5000.03%0.68Data source: Yahoo! Finance.Financial stocks and gold stocks saw elevated investor   attention on a day when the Federal Reserve decided to keep   long-term interest rates unchanged. Neither group broke far away   from broader market averages
column3: though
column4: and both theFinancial Sector SPDR Select ETF(NYSEMKT: XLF) and the leveragedDirexion Daily Gold Miners Bull 3X ETF(NYSEMKT: NUGT) were essentially unchanged.On the other hand
column5: earnings season produced large price swings   in a few individual stocks
column6: includingApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) andPitney Bowes(NYSE: PBI) .Apple returns to growthApple shares soared 7% to lead the Dow higher after the   company demonstrated that its growth days arefar from over. Revenue rose 3% following three consecutive quarters of   declines on strong demand for its latest iPhone models. Average   selling pricesjumpedthanks to a clear preference on the part of consumers for the   larger iPhone 7 Plus
column7: and that success helped the company trounce   its earnings guidance.The tech titan generated $3.36 per share of profit compared to   expectations of $3.17 per share. ""We're thrilled to report that   our holiday quarter results generated Apple's highest quarterly   revenue ever
column8: and broke multiple records along the way
column9: CEO Tim   Cook said in a press release.iPhone 7 Plus. Image source: Apple.Cook and his team drew attention to the company's booming   services business that includes iTunes and App Store purchases.   The segment passed $25 billion of revenue over the prior 12   months and is now responsible for nearly 10% of overall sales.   This quarter's gain was just below 20%
column10: which suggests Apple has   a good shot at doubling services revenue by fiscal 2020.In the meantime
column11: the company guided toward another quarter of   iPhone-led growth ahead
column12: as revenue should come in at $52.5   billion while gross profit margin holds steady at just below 40%   of sales.Pitney Bowes misses expectationsPitney Bowes slumped 18% followingsurprisingly weak quarterly results. The office services specialist reported a 5% sales decline as   it produced adjusted earnings of $0.53 per share. Both the top-   and bottom-line figures were significantly lower than Wall Street   and management had forecast.""Our fourth quarter and full-year results were not what we   wanted or expected
column13: CEO Marc Lautenbach said in a press release.   Executives were especially disappointed with their performance in   the software solutions business
column14: which saw a 7% sales decline and   a 16% drop in operating earnings. The miss helped push revenue   down by 4% for the full year so that Pitney Bowes came in below   the lowered outlook it announced in early November.Looking ahead
column15: management believes it has put most of the   sales disruptions
column16: and a good portion of its restructuring   charges
column17: behind it. However
column18: Lautenbach and his team sounded a   similar tone three months ago when they pulled back their 2016   outlook after anespecially weak third quarter. Investors aren't keen to give the company much slack after two   consecutive outings headlined by disappointing operating results
column19: so the stock took a justifiable beating on Wednesday.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Wednesday Apple Rumors: APPL Releases New AirPods Update;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of an update for the AirPods. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Wednesday.makeArticleAd();AirPods Update:AAPL has released a small update for its AirPods
column4: reportsAppleInsider. The new update was quietly pushed out by the company to solve issues with the wireless headphones. The tech company hasn't said what these bug fixes are. However
column5: it is likely that they addressed issues with device synchronization and connectivity. The update downloads when the AirPods are in the charger
column6: the charger is plugged in and the linked iPhone is nearby with a Wi-Fi connection.Original Content:Apple CEO Tim Cook says that the company may be looking into making original TV content
column7: MacRumorsnotes. According to the AAPL CEO
column8: the company has its ""toe in the water"" due to its experience with Apple Music. Cook didn't say much else about the company's original content efforts. However
column9: he did note that the company's TV set-top box has come a long way and says that it may give them a ""clear platform"" to work with.Immigration Ban:Tim Cook is considering taking legal action over President Donald Trump's recent immigration order
column10: reportsThe Wall Street Journal. The executive order signed by Trump on Friday banned refugees from seven countries from entering the United States. Cook argues that this has affected hundreds of the company's employees. He didn't say exactly what legal action AAPL may take against the order
column11: but said it should be ""constructive and productive.""Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postWednesday Apple Rumors: APPL Releases New AirPods Updateappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc.'s iPhone 7 Plus Is a Smash Hit;2/1/2017;"The first quarter of anApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) fiscal year is usually the company's peak quarter
column2: as it follows the launch of Apple's latest flagship iPhone   device. The iPhone generates the bulk of the company's revenue
column3: and so the quarter in which Apple sees the most iPhone shipments   is the quarter in which it sees its greatest revenue.Apple's iPhone 7 Plus. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Although there were rumors that Apple was seeing relatively   tepid demand for its latest iPhone models -- the iPhone 7 and the   iPhone 7 Plus -- the company's financial performance tells a   different tale.Apple reported shipping a record 78.29 million iPhones in the   first quarter
column4: handily beating its previous quarterly record of   just shy of 75 million units. CEO Tim Cook said that it saw   ""exceptional demand"" for iPhones that ""beat [Apple's] own   internal expectations.""This robust unit demand didn't come at the expense of average   selling prices
column5: either -- iPhone average selling prices in the   quarter came in at just a hair under $695.Just as the iPhone business is the star of the company's most   recent earnings report
column6: the iPhone 7 Plus appears to be the star   of the iPhone business.iPhone 7 Plus is a smash hitCook said that the iPhone 7 is the company's ""most popular   model
column7: but he highlighted the fact that the company saw   ""especially strong demand for iPhone 7 Plus.""Demand was so strong
column8: in fact
column9: that Cook says that the iPhone   7 Plus made up ""a higher portion of the new product mix than   [Apple has] ever seen with Plus models in the past.""To further drive the point home
column10: even given the   stronger-than-expected unit shipment performance during the   quarter
column11: Apple reported that ""demand for iPhone 7 Plus exceeded   supply throughout the quarter"" and that the company only ""came   into supply/demand balance in January.""And
column12: finally
column13: it's worth pointing out that Apple is seeing   this unexpectedly strong iPhone 7 Plus demand even though it   priced the devices at a $20 premium to where it had priced   previous iPhone Plus models (which previously carried $100   premiums over their non-Plus counterparts).Clearly
column14: Apple's customer base likes what the company did with   the iPhone 7 Plus and was willing to pay a premium for the added   features.In the past
column15: Apple had differentiated its Plus models with   larger
column16: sharper displays as well as some very minor camera   enhancements (i.e.
column17: optical image stabilization). However
column18: this   time around
column19: in addition to the usual points of differentiation
column20: Apple included a dual-lens camera on the iPhone 7 Plus which   enabled an interesting optical zoom feature.The key lesson here is that if Apple brings interesting   innovations and features to premium products and tries to charge   a premium for those features
column21: then it may very well get paid for   those features.Open sesameAt this point
column22: it's obvious what Apple should do next --   introduce even higher-priced iPhones with even more interesting   features and points of differentiation. Apple shouldn't go wild   adding in every feature under the sun
column23: but its product definition   and marketing teams should now have the freedom to go ahead and   build products with higher cost structures that are intended to   sell at higher price points.Such products
column24: launched in conjunction with models priced at   the more ""typical"" price points
column25: could be quite successful for   the company. In fact
column26: current rumors suggest that Apple is   planning to launch two straightforward successors to this year's   iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus
column27: and then higher up in the product   stack
column28: the company may launch an iPhone with a curved OLED   display and other goodies.If the upcoming OLED iPhone is a fundamentally compelling   product -- and I think it will be -- then I could see Apple   successfully charging even more for it than it does for its top   iPhone 7 Plus models.The next couple of years could be very interesting for Apple's   iPhone product line and
column29: ultimately

column1: Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock Wonâ€™t Stop at $12;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News

column4: semiconductor giantAdvanced Micro Devices
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD)
column6: has come back over the past two years
column7: proving the doubters wrong. With gains of 400% over the past year
column8: AMD stock haspunished those who bet against it. But is it now time to take profits?makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrNope.AMD stock had a slow start to 2017
column9: off about 6% before Tuesday night's fourth-quarter earnings report
column10: is back in the black thanks to a Wednesday surge after showing off some of the operational dominance it sported in a rip-roaring 2016.Expectation for the QuarterFor the quarter that ended December
column11: Wall Street expected the company to report a loss of 2 cents per share on revenues of $1.07 billion. AMD beat on both fronts
column12: recording revenues of $1.11 billion and a loss of just 1 cent per share.Recent results fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) hinted that Advanced Micro might be in for a Street-beating quarter.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018On Friday John Vinh

column14: which reflected less-bad personal computer trends
column15: suggests strong growth for the sector. Notably
column16: Vinh cited AMD as benefiting from ""strength in gaming and high-end PCs."" To that end
column17: the analysts also said the improvements in high-end PCs could reduce concerns about high-end GPU inventory at desktop graphics card manufacturers.Well
column18: a beat is what we got
column19: and that came on the power of AMD's graphics chips
column20: which saw revenues grow 15% year-over-year.The Key to AMD: GPUsGPU
column21: or Graphics Processing Unit
column22: is a big business for AMD. Those chips render images
column23: animations and video for display on computer's screens. And the strength of that business has been a key component of AMD's turnaround. In the third quarter
column24: reported in October
column25: AMD posted a 23% year-over-year jump in revenue of $1.3 billion. The company benefited from strong growth in its popular Radeon line GPUs as revenue from that segment rose 11% year over year.This quarter
column26: GPUs helped once more. Revenues in Computing and Graphics grew 28% year-over-year
column27: thanks in part to higher average GPU selling prices.The company recently announced that its FirePro server GPUs have been selected byAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) to power its cloud platform in 2017. All told
column28: AMD's GPU strength has begun to gain traction in different verticals
column29: which should help it narrow the market share gap with leaderNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA).Bottom Line for AMD StockAMD's report was full of other positives
column30: such as an expansion of gross margins from 30% to 32%
column31: and slight gains in its Enterprise
column32: Embedded and Semi-Custom business (4%).Still
column33: graphics and high performance are the name of the game.AMD stock surged 14% higher on Wednesday's reaction to fourth-quarter results
column34: putting shares at highs last seen in 2017. The stock has returned more than 400% in 12 months - better than the 20% one-year gain in theS&P 500.And even still

column1: Apple
column2: Inc. Earnings: Why Shares Are Trading Higher;2/1/2017;"Following the company's first-quarter earnings report on   Tuesday
column3: shares ofApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) are up sharply on Wednesday. At the time of this   writing
column4: Apple stockis trading at about $123
column5: up more than 5% for the trading day.   The move helped the stock hit a new 52-week high. Apple stock's   move higher on Monday adds to the increasingly bullish sentiment   toward the stock recently. In the past six months
column6: shares are up   about 23%
column7: easily outperforming the S&P 500's 5% gain during   the same period.Investor optimism toward Apple stock recently is likely due to   a wide range of factors
column8: including its conservative valuation
column9: speculation about a major redesign for Apple's expected iPhone   launch this fall
column10: and Samsung's recall of its Galaxy Note 7. But   one trend in Apple's business is likely serving as a primary   driver for the company's rising stock price: a rebound in iPhone   sales.iPhone 7. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Rebounding iPhone salesTo understand why recently rebounding iPhone sales are so   important to investors
column11: it's important to realize how steeply   iPhone sales were declining on a year-over-year basis just a few   quarters ago.MetricQ3 2016Q2 2016iPhone unit sales growth (YOY)(15%)(16%)iPhone revenue growth (YOY)(23%)(18%)Total revenue (YOY)(15%)(13%)Fiscal quarters shown. Data retrieved from Apple's earnings   releases. Table by author.At the iPhone segment's worst point last year
column12: unit sales and   revenue in the company's fiscal third quarter of 2016 declined   15% and 23%
column13: respectively
column14: dragging total revenue 15% lower   compared to the year-ago quarter. As Apple was reporting   significant year-over-year declines in its largest product   segment
column15: investors were concerned about how the product segment   would perform over the longer term.But as early as Apple's fourth-quarter earnings report in   October
column16: it was clear that the tech giant's iPhone business could   soon end a three-quarter streak of year-over-year declines in   total revenue. The company guided for first-quarter revenue to be   between $76 billion and $78 billion
column17: up from $75.9 billion in the   year-ago quarter. Considering that iPhone accounts for over 60%   of Apple's trailing-12-month revenue
column18: this meant management was   optimistic about the company's new September-launched iPhone 7   and 7 Plus.Sure enough
column19: iPhone sales rebounded.Fiscal quarters shown. Data retrieved from Apple's earnings     releases. Chart by author.Apple's first-quarter earnings release this week confirmed the   company's return to iPhone growth
column20: with Apple reporting   year-over-year iPhone unit and revenue growth of 5%
column21: helping the   company's total revenue rise 3%.Can iPhone growth persist?The big question going forward
column22: of course
column23: is whether Apple's   iPhone business can keep growing. In the near term
column24: it looks like   management expects another quarter of growth. Apple said it   expected total second-quarter revenue to be between $51.5 billion   and $53.5 billion
column25: up from $50.6 billion in the year-ago quarter.   With iPhone accounting for the bulk of Apple's total revenue
column26: this guidance for growth in total revenue likely means management   expects growth for the iPhone
column27: too.Beyond Apple's second quarter
column28: however
column29: it's not as certain   that Apple's iPhone sales growth can be sustained throughout   fiscal 2017. However
column30: a return to growth for iPhone 7 -- a   product with a three-year-old form factor -- is promising news
column31: highlighting how well the company's products continue to resonate   with customers.Combining Apple stock's conservative valuation with growth in   the company's biggest product segment
column32: it's easy to see why   investors are optimistic about the stock's potential

column1: Facebook Inc (FB) TV App Is More Trouble Than You Think;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) opened for trade Feb. 1 at an all-time high - a market cap of $365 billion - on the strength of its dominance in mobile apps. But the big news is that Facebook is about to challenge the video league leaders with a mobile app for existing streaming boxes like theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) TV. The question is
column3: what will this do for FB stock?makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockMoving into TV through an app rather than a device makes sense
column4: given the failure of the original Facebook phone and its overwhelming success with apps for others' phones.FB is already bankrolling the creation of videos for the video tab of itsmobile app.So where does Facebook fit its service into the evolving market
column5: and what does its presence as a broadcaster mean to its claims not to be a media company?FB Stock: TV vs. PhoneThe company is already a presence in video thanks toFacebook Live
column6: which allows live streaming of video on the service and it has aPresidential endorsement.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatFB has prepared to offer longer videos by introducing ""mid-roll"" ads - ads that play in the middle of a video - to its line-up
column7: making the service more TV-like.Over time
column8: this might allow Facebook to compete directly withAmazon.com
column9: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column10: Netflix
column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) andAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column12: NASDAQ:GOOGL) YouTube in the growing market for streaming services.The problem is that there is a big difference between the experience you get on a mobile phone and what you want on a TV screen. A phone is active
column13: a TV is passive. A phone may support videos of a few minutes
column14: while people will watch TV for hours-and-hours.There is an assumption in the breathless reporting of Facebook's latest move that TV is easy; that it's just something you throw money at. Given the success of Netflix in generating subscribers and Emmys
column15: and Amazon in generating Prime members and Oscar buzz
column16: that is an easy mistake to make.Worth the Candle?For Facebook stock
column17: this may not be as huge a deal as analysts think.Netflix revenue is only a fraction of FB stock's. Analysts expect Facebook to deliver over $27 billion in 2016 revenue when it reports after the market closes Feb. 1. This is against roughly $9 billion for Netflix. NFLX also brings just 3% of that revenue to the bottom line
column18: while FB stock brings nearly one-third of revenue to its net income line.Entering the world of creating television poses another risk. CEO Mark Zuckerberg has repeatedly saidhe doesn't run a media company
column19: that his is just a communications service. Media companies have responsibilities to truth and accuracy that
column20: say
column21: phone companies don't have - responsibilitiesthat can limit profitability.If Facebook is going to license content from media suppliers
column22: whether live or scripted
column23: it becomes a media company
column24: subject to political and public scrutiny for its programming choices
column25: on a global basis. This is a dance FB stock shareholders should fear
column26: because it costs money to play
column27: and carries risk.Can Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Jump Over These Hurdles?But Facebook may now have no choice in the matter. The big screen is the last frontier for internet services
column28: it's where everyone is heading. FB stock does not want to be left behind.The Bottom Line on Facebook StockWhile most analysts are jumping for joy over the Facebook TV app news
column29: I am a lot more cautious. This move has enormous implications for the entire company
column30: for how it's perceived and (more important) what it costs to run.FB
column31: like Alphabet
column32: prefers to manage itself through algorithms. Algorithms scale in ways people do not. Facebook is starting to bow to pressure on the media front
column33: hiring Campbell Brownto coordinate media alliances. Now it's about to become a TV network
column34: or at least a streaming service.What will that mean to its profitability and growth? I think they both slow
column35: because people aren't algorithms and talent has temper that code does not have. Politics can kill the media star.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column36: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in AMZN
column37: GOOGL AAPL
column38: and FB.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayThe postFacebook Inc (FB) TV App Is More Trouble Than You Thinkappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Will the Apple Inc. HomeKit Beat Amazonâ€™s Alexa? (AAPL);2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) announced HomeKit - its strategy for becoming the center of the smart home - in June 2014.Amazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) revealed its Alexa-powered Echo smart speaker that November.makeArticleAd();Source: Apple/AmazonWhile there are currently several dozen HomeKit compatible smart home products
column4: Amazon's Alexa is now connected to thousands of smart products and services and has spread from the Echo to third-party devices.On the surface
column5: it looks as though Amazon has outmaneuvered and thoroughly trounced Apple. But despite the seemingly insurmountable lead and momentum
column6: AAPL could still end up beating AMZN in this smart home race.Here's how.Apple Chose the Closed Approach With HomeKitApple tends to be extremely cautious. Its software is designed to be user-friendly and secure. iPhone apps can't just be downloaded from anywhere; they need to go through the official App Store and that requires approval by AAPL. Third-party hardware needs to be certified by Apple before it can be marketed as being iOS-compatible.It's that ""walled"" approach that hasmade the iPhone more securethan smartphones runningAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Android operating system.With the iPhone and Siri - Apple's voice assistant - at the center of Apple's smart home strategy
column7: that focus on security
column8: compatibility and ease of use carried over toHomeKit. Manufacturers who want to make their smart devices HomeKit-compatible face a daunting series of requirements.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!As pointed out in a recent Reuters article ondiffering smart home approaches
column9: this includes being forced to buy a special HomeKit chip
column10: being limited to approved (and more expensive than average) Bluetooth and Wi-Fi chips and even extends to manufacturing being limited to factories that are certified by Apple. End-to-end encryption is mandatory. Once a HomeKit product is ready
column11: it faces extensive testing by Apple engineers to ensure compatibility.Thenit may be sold. That process alone can take three to five months.So you have additional costs
column12: the procedural red tape and a delay. It's easy to understand whyApple currently lists only 75 or so HomeKit-compatible devices. And half of those are either different color options or regional variations of the same product.Amazon Alexa Is Open for BusinessAmazon took a radically different approach with its Echo speaker and Alexa. The company openly courted third-party companies to develop Alexa ""skills"" or software-enabled interactions with an Amazon Alexa-powered device.A skill can be the ability to tell Alexa to order anUber. It could also be telling Alexa to turn on your home's smart lights or to start your electric car. The process is simple. Amazon provides an example showinghow to build an Alexa skill in 60 minutes
column13: and that includes the time needed to create a developer account. Submit the skill to AMZN for a quick verification
column14: and it's published.That's how Amazon Alexa tripled its available skills in just three months last year
column15: hitting 3
column16: 000 in September. If that sounds impressive
column17: by CES 2017 in January
column18: it had hit more than 7
column19: 000 Alexa skills.In addition to skills
column20: Amazon also encourages third parties to integrate Alexa functionality into their products. That way
column21: consumers get the Alexa experience without requiring an Echo speaker.That's a far easier process than Apple HomeKit certification. A ""Works with Alexa"" label takes about 10 days to obtain (it can even be issued by third party labs) and doesn't require special chips. According to the Reuters post
column22: that has resulted in over 250 products that are Alexa-certified. We saw some of these at CES
column23: including third-party speakers with Alexa and even home appliances with built-in Alexa capability.Smart Home Security: Apple Strength
column24: Amazon Alexa VulnerabilityThe differing approaches of AMZN and AAPL have led to Alexa rapidly leaping to a massive lead over HomeKit in the smart home. However
column25: there is one scenario where this could change rapidly.Security is increasingly becoming an issue for smart
column26: connected devices. Apple's HomeKit approach emphasizes security
column27: to the point of forcing the use of specialized chips and even certified manufacturing facilities.Amazon's Alexa strategy
column28: on the other hand
column29: leaves its platform relatively exposed. Amazon told Reuters it can't guarantee the security of third-party devices running Alexa. Those thousands of Alexa skills also integrate with third-party services that may have their own vulnerabilities.Trade of the Day: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock No Longer a Home RunAll it would take is one catastrophic hacking for a PR disaster that turns consumers off Alexa. As CNET puts it in a review of thehacking risks for different smart home standards: ""Don't assume that a device has high security standards just because it works with Alexa.""Bottom LineThere's no disputing the fact that Amazon completely caught Apple and others off guard with its stealthy approach of sneaking Alexa into the home using its Echo connected speaker.Before the Echo
column30: it was generally assumed that a smartphone would be the natural smart home controller. Making Alexa integration so open has also paid off for AMZN
column31: resulting in a formidable lead in the smart home in a very short time. That lead may well turn into complete domination of the connected home. But Amazon's open approach may also prove to be its Achilles heel.Should hackers turn their attention to Amazon Alexa
column32: the resulting headlines may flip the equation and put the much more secure Apple HomeKit on top in the long run.As of this writing
column33: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Pops Following Vindicating Q1 EarningsFriday Apple Rumors: Designer Creates Interesting iPhone 8 ConceptCan Apple Inc. (AAPL) Afford a War With Qualcomm
column34: Inc. (QCOM)?The postWill the Apple Inc. HomeKit Beat Amazon's Alexa? (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Nokia Corp (ADR) (NOK) Stock Is Still Hobbling;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK) is quintessentially Finnish - beautiful
column3: rugged
column4: quirky and a bit tragic. Once considered the preeminent mobile phone platform
column5: its reign was challenged briefly byBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY)
column6: then permanently byApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL). Today
column7: NOK stock is more than just a phone company
column8: but will Wall Street care?makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler / Grid Engine via Flickr (Modified)Its fourth quarter of fiscal year 2016 earnings report is set for release before the opening bell on Feb. 2.Would-be buyers and traders have a tough call to make. We all love stories of the great comeback
column9: and Nokia stock is a candidate. Shedding its legacy image as a boxy-cell-phone manufacturer
column10: NOK stock has been extremely acquisitive.We're not just talking about the buyout ofAlcatel-Lucent
column11: although that is a big part of the story. It's also the procurement of lesser known assets that will assert Nokia's new role as apublic networksprovider.At the same time
column12: we're talking about NOK stock here. Recently
column13: InvestorPlacecontributor Will Ashworth slammed Nokia stock as still being ""a dog with fleas
column14: borrowing a line from the iconic movieWall Street.It's a fitting description of a company which has ""delivered a scintillating annualtotal returnover the past 15 years of -7.14%
column15: more than 11 percentage points worse than theS&P 500.""7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018Whatever management has up their sleeves
column16: they better get to it. The markets are many things
column17: but patient usually isn't one of them.The Nitty Gritty of Nokia EarningsLet's take a deeper look at the Nokia earnings. The average consensus estimate for earnings per share is 8 cents - smack in the middle of the forecast spectrum. For the top line
column18: analysts are predicting sales to come in a range of $6.8 billion at the low to $7.6 billion at the high
column19: with a $7.2 billion consensus.To say that the Nokia earnings environment is challenged is putting it mildly. First off
column20: recent performances by NOK stock leave a lot to be desired. Fiscal 2016 is mostly a disappointment
column21: with two misses and a narrow beat.Unless Nokia is planning to pull the proverbial rabbit out of the hat
column22: I'm not sure what they can do. The financials for Nokia stock aren't exactly inspiring.Not surprisingly
column23: Zacks Equity Research prospects for Nokia earnings are dim. Their analysts rank NOK stock as a ""sell
column24: citing a litany of problems. Chief among them is the patent war that Nokia finds itself embroiled in with Apple. After losing the mobile phone business to Cupertino
column25: NOK has devolved into whatInvestorPlacecontributor Dana Blankenhorn calls a""patent troll.""That's all fun and games when you pester from your home turf. But Nokia seemed to forget the first rule of trolling: don't troll those that can beat the crap out of you. Mighty Apple has had enough
column26: and they're going to leverage their 22:1valuation disparityagainst Nokia.Again
column27: as Blankenhorn states
column28: that forces NOK stock into a weak hand.NOK Stock Is Wickedly UnpredictableClick to EnlargeStepping aside from the granularity of Nokia earnings
column29: trading the shares based on its financial reports has a dubious history. Since Q4 of fiscal 2013
column30: the average performance of Nokia stock quarter-to-quarter is a pretty sad -1.9%. Really
column31: you just have to pull up the chart from the fall of 2014. It's just like ""Stairway to Heaven
column32: only in the opposite direction.What that tells you is that if you do intend to trade Nokia earnings
column33: do so quickly and firmly. Trying to make up for losses usually results in an extension of those losses. And the markets do not make it easy. In the last three reports
column34: Nokia stock was positive heading towards the earnings release. On the day of
column35: NOK fell to an average of 6%.Can GoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Escape Its Bearish Dogma?For those who want to try their hand at a little Wall Street Russian roulette
column36: a tip of the hat to you! For everybody else
column37: I would just stay away from NOK stock. There are deep-seated fundamental challenges with the company that have yet to be adequately addressed.Until that day comes
column38: Nokia stock remains a liability.As of this writing
column39: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsThe postNokia Corp (ADR) (NOK) Stock Is Still Hobblingappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: What Apple's (AAPL) Earnings Say About The Future;2/1/2017;"When you regularly give your opinion on something as unpredictable as financial markets
column2: gloating when you get something right is rarely a good idea. That is especially true when those opinions arearchivedfor all to see; it's too easy for a reader to check out that archive and find examples of when the market and hindsight combine to make even logical arguments seem foolish. I am fully aware of that
column3: but when it comes to yesterdayâ€™searnings release from Apple(AAPL)
column4: I will still say""told you!""What really matters about the Apple release to investors is certainly not that I got it right
column5: nor is it even that the tech giant returned to growth in revenue for the first time in a year
column6: nor that the already great margins at Apple increased. Those last two are important
column7: but necessarily backward looking
column8: as all hard data in an earnings release are by definition.What matters most is what the report tells us about the future and there the message was somewhat mixed.makeArticleAd();The official guidance for Q1 2017 contained in the release fell just short of Wall Streetâ€™s expectations
column9: which would normally be enough of a negative to more than offset the good historical results. In this case
column10: though
column11: a look at where Apple succeeded in Q4 2016 suggests that that guidance may just be another example of Appleâ€™s past tendency to err on the side of under-promising and over-delivering when it comes to guidance. That is why
column12: even though growth stalled last year
column13: AAPL has beaten EPS expectations in three of the last four quarters.First and foremost
column14: iPhone sales hit another record. That is particularly significant as not that long ago many were predicting that Google parent Alphabet (GOOG:GOOGL)â€™s move into the phone business would do Apple some serious harm. It looks now as if those saying that were about as accurate as those that maintained that the Windows phone from Microsoft (MSFT) or the Amazon (AMZN) Fire phone would be the next big thing.The fact is that the iPhone has an iconic status that looks almost impossible to challenge. Even phones that are objectively better in some ways
column15: such as memory capacity
column16: camera resolution
column17: or speaker quality for example
column18: cannot take market share. As Apple advances the iPhone with each release
column19: beating them on those and other fronts becomes harder
column20: but remains
column21: according to the evidence so far
column22: a pointless exercise. As long as that dynamic remains
column23: holding Apple stock and adding to holdings at times of weakness still makes sense for investors.The weakness in this release was mainly in one area; iPad sales declined for the twelfth successive quarter. That
column24: however
column25: was offset to some extent by strong sales of Macs and Apple Watches. For the latter we are reliant on the word of Tim Cook as Apple doesnâ€™t release a breakdown of watch sales
column26: but
column27: as I pointed out in the article referenced above
column28: anybody who tried to buy a Series Two watch as a Christmas gift is probably aware that sales were at least more than Apple expected. None were available in any of the five states where I tried and most stores have just now received inventory.That shortage of watches
column29: combined with Cookâ€™s admission that they seriously underestimated demand for the iPhone 7 Plus
column30: means that the record sales reported yesterday were achieved with a background of supply constraints. Given that and the fact that there was considerable growth in areas such as services and enterprise operations that still have lots of room for Apple to expand
column31: the message underlying yesterdayâ€™s earnings is that
column32: despite conventional wisdom
column33: growth can still be achieved."
