column1: Apple, Inc. Earnings: Why the "Most Accurate" Apple Analyst Blew It;2/1/2017;"On Tuesday afternoon
column2: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) posted strong earnings results for the first   quarter of its 2017 fiscal year. Revenue beat analysts' forecasts   and the company's own guidance range. Earnings per share   comfortably beat the average analyst estimate as well. Finally
column3: iPhone sales rose 5% year over year
column4: to 78.3 million units; most   analysts had been expecting a smaller increase -- or even a   decline.Apple posted strong iPhone sales for the critical holiday     quarter. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();One of those analysts wrongly expecting an iPhone sales   decline was Ming-Chi Kuo of Taiwan's KGI Securities. In the past   few years
column5: Kuo has gained a reputation among many investors for   being the ""most accurate Apple analyst."" The fact that he whiffed so badly on his iPhone sales forecast   is an important reminder to investors not to rely too much on   analysts' forecasts.Understanding the ""most accurate"" Apple analystMing-Chi Kuo has very good sources -- either in Apple's supply   chain or at the company itself -- giving him advance warning of   new product features and production plans. He isn't perfect
column6: but   he's one of the best sources out there for news about Apple's   future products.Ming-Chi Kuo correctly predicted many features of the iPhone     7 and iPhone 7 Plus. Image source: Apple.For example
column7: Kuocorrectly predictedmost of the key features of the iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus prior   to those models being officially unveiled last September. That   included obscure details like the fact that there wouldn't be   32GB versions of the new jet black iPhones.Kuo also has a pretty good track record for short-term   shipment forecasts. A few days before Apple's Q1 earnings report   two years ago
column8: he predicted that Apple had sold 73 million   iPhones during the holiday quarter
column9: when most analysts still   expected a shipment number well below 70 million. In fact
column10: Apple   reported that it had shipped 74.5 million iPhones.However
column11: Kuo's competitive advantage appears to be limited to   picking up supply chain rumors. When it comes to estimating   demand for Apple's products
column12: his record is far less pristine.Underestimating iPhone sales by a mileFor the past several months
column13: Ming-Chi Kuo had stuck to a   forecast that Apple would ship 70 million-75 million iPhones in   the first quarter. At the midpoint of that range
column14: iPhone sales   would have been down 3% year over year
column15: whereas iPhone sales   actuallyincreased5%.This doesn't fully capture how far off Kuo's expectations   were
column16: though. Prior to late September
column17: he had expected Apple to   ship just 65 million iPhones in Q1
column18: down 13% year over year.The further you zoom out
column19: the worse Kuo's predictions have   been. Back in April
column20: he stated that in a best-case scenario
column21: Apple would ship 205 million iPhones for the full 2016 calendar   year. (His worst-case scenario was 190 million shipments.) Apple   actually shipped 215.4 million iPhones for the full year.Don't trust analysts too muchInvestors who soldApple stocklast year -- or decided not to buy it -- based on Kuo's   relatively bearish projections have missed out on a big rally.   Since bottoming out around $90 last May
column22: Apple stock has come   roaring back
column23: reaching $125 in after-hours trading on Tuesday   afternoon. This shows the danger of relying too much on analysts'   forecasts.Apple Stock Performance
column24: data byYCharts.Following top analysts for a stock you own is a good way to   stay up to date on the latest trends and the general outlook for   the next few quarters. However
column25: while Wall Street analysts may in   theory be the ""experts
column26: even the best ones can make some big   mistakes. For individual investors
column27: it's important to understand   when to trust an analyst's predictions.For Apple
column28: Ming-Chi Kuo is an important analyst to follow for   learning about potential new products and early production plans
column29: because of his supply chain connections. However
column30: Apple's sales   results ultimately depend on demand.Being plugged in to the supply chain doesn't help much in   forecasting demand. Perhaps Kuo can accurately estimate how many   components Apple's suppliers are building. That shows how many   devices Apple plans to build -- and
column31: by extension
column32: how much   demand Apple expects to see. But build plans are fluid and   routinely change based on actual demand.Thus
column33: while Kuo is great at calling the play-by-play of what   Apple is doing now
column34: his analysis is less reliable looking further   into the future. Investors who have followed his advice over the   past several quarters just learned that lesson the hard way.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column35: it can pay to listen. After all
column36: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column37: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column38: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column39: 2017Adam Levine-Weinbergowns shares of Apple and is long January 2018 $90 calls on     Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Apple. The     Motley Fool is long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short     January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Advanced Micro (AMD) Q4 Loss In Line
column2: View Disappoints;2/1/2017;"Advanced Micro DevicesAMDreported loss of 4 cents per share in fourth-quarter 2016
column3: which matched the Zacks Consensus Estimate.Revenues increased 15.4% year over year to $1.11 billion primarily driven by higher GPU sales. However
column4: revenues decreased 15.4% sequentially
column5: primarily due to seasonally soft sales figures for its semi-custom System on Chips (SoCs). Notably
column6: revenues were well above the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.07 billion.AMD's shares rose 1.2% in after-hour trading. We note that shares have outperformed the ZacksElectronics Semiconductorsindustry over the last one year. While the industry gave a positive return of 67.2%
column7: AMD gained a whopping 384.6%.The company benefited from strong demand for its graphics products. However
column8: AMD's first-quarter 2017 will be impacted by seasonal weakness.RevenuesAdvanced Micro has two reportable segments -Computing and Graphics(focused on the traditional PC market) andEnterprise
column9: Embedded and Semi-Custom(focusing on adjacent high-growth opportunities). The details of these segments are discussed below:Computing and Graphics includes desktop and notebook processors and chipsets
column10: discrete GPUs and professional graphics. This segment accounted for 54.2% of revenues and was up 27.1% sequentially and 27.7% year over year to $600 million.Notably
column11: this segment's revenues grew on an annualized basis for the first time since 2011 as AMD's increased efforts to strengthen this particular segment paid off.Also
column12: the segment posted the highest revenue in the last two years. Client revenues were the highest in the last seven quarters. Graphics processor revenues were also the highest in the last 11 quarters.During the reported quarter
column13: strong adoption of the company's seventh generation notebook accelerated processing units (APUs) drove growth for the company. While desktop processor sales improved on a sequential basis
column14: it declined on a year-over-year basis.The company also won a number of high-end design deals with global original equipment manufacturers over its Ryzen desktop processor that is expected to be launched in early Mar 2017.AMD's Polaris line of GPUs witnessed increased adoption in the fourth quarter. Also
column15: Radeon Pro 400 mobile GPUs were launched
column16: which are used in Apple'sAAPLpremium segment notebooks.The Enterprise
column17: Embedded and Semi-Custom segment includes server and embedded processors
column18: dense servers
column19: semi-custom SoC products
column20: engineering services and royalties. This segment brought in the remaining 45.8% of revenues
column21: down 39.4% sequentially but up 3.7% year over year to $506 million.The year-over-year increase was driven by higher sales of embedded processor sales and game consoles by MicrosoftMSFTand Sony that are powered by AMD's chips.The segment witnessed increased adoption in targeted markets. Notably
column22: the company continues to gain traction in Naples
column23: Italy.Advanced Micro Devices

As more and more devices become interconnected

These developments are expected to help the company gain more traction in the GPU space and close in the market share gap with NVIDIA. (Read:AdvancedMicro Scales New Highs

column40: it will translate to 18% growth in revenues on a year-over-year basis.Gross margin is likely to be 33% while non-GAAP operating expenses are estimated to be $360 million.On the other hand
column41: interest expense
column42: taxes and others will amount to $30 million. Inventories are expected to remain flat on a sequential basis.Our TakeThe decent fourth-quarter results reflected AMD's improving position in key markets with the introduction of several APUs and GPUs. Moreover
column43: partnerships with the likes of Google for the supply of Radeon Pro GPUs and FirePro server GPUs are positive in our view.Notably the company trails NVIDIA as the second-largest manufacturer of graphics chips for high-end computing and is gradually gaining traction in the space.Additionally
column44: upcoming products like Ryzen and Zen are expected to drive the top line going ahead.Zacks RankAdvanced Micro has Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 (Strong Buy) Rank stocks here.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above

column1: Amgen
column2: Inc. (AMGN) Q4 Earnings Preview;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAs it's customary withAmgen
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMGN)
column5: the biotech giant topped analysts' expectation in each of the first three quarters of 2016. Chances are that it'll top expectations once more when it reports its fourth-quarter and full-year 2016 figures on Feb. 2. So if you're following AMGN stock
column6: you don't need to worry about Amgen's profits.makeArticleAd();Source:Richard Masoner via FlickrInstead
column7: you'll want to watch the following items Thursday when Amgen reports its fourth-quarter results:#1: Enbrel Sales TrendCompared to the third quarter of 2015
column8: Amgen reported flat product sales in Q3 2016. This was mostly due to its top-selling drug
column9: Enbrel
column10: losing ground. Sales for the drug had increased 24% in Q1 and 10% in Q2
column11: but in the third quarter
column12: total Enbrel sales were $1.452 billion
column13: versus $1.459 billion in the year-ago period.The problem doesn't seem to be seasonal fluctuation
column14: considering that Enbrel sales grew by 30% in Q3 2015
column15: compared to Q3 2014.7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayThe problem is that competition is catching up. Amgen usually says
column16: ""offset partially by the impact of competition"" when giving details about Enbrel sales. However
column18: ""partially"" was conspicuously absent. Did someone just forget to copy-and-paste? Maybe. Maybe not.AMGN stock holders should pay attention to see if Enbrel will resume growth through increased volume
column19: as opposed to price hike.Enbrel faces three major growth barriers.First
column20: it competes againstAbbVie Inc's(NYSE:ABBV) Humira and Johnson & Johnson's Remicade. This leads to the second challenge.Stiff competition necessitates incremental rebates to payers to maintain its formulary position.The third challenge is the biosimilar availability. For instance
column21: the FDA has approved Erelzi
column22: an Enbrel biosimilar byNovartis AG (ADR)(NYSE:NVS).Put simply
column23: further lackluster Enbrel growth would weigh on AMGN stock.#2: Amgen's Drug PricingInvestors also should look closely at how fast Amgen is hiking prices.I raised concerns about Amgen stockgrowing sales by increasing drug prices
column24: instead of higher volumes
column25: after the company reported its Q2 2015 earnings. Almost two years on
column26: the trend of growing sales with price hikes is still commonplace at AMGN.From a business perspective
column27: it's smart to try to squeeze out every possible dollar from your inventions. However

column1: Apple
column2: Inc. Can Still Set Records;2/1/2017;"Image source: Apple.It's been a while sinceApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) posted a bona fide blowout quarter
column3: but I think   it's safe to say that last quarter qualifies.makeArticleAd();The Mac maker set an all-time record high with quarterly   revenue
column4: which came in at $78.4 billion. That's a few billion   higher than the $75.9 billion in sales that Apple generated a   year ago
column5: and above the high end of Apple's own guidance ($78   billion). Naturally
column6: that was driven by strong iPhone sales
column7: another record at 78.3 million. This all comes as the iPhone 7   was arguably the most incremental model update in years
column8: keeping   the same overall industrial design with no clear must-have   feature. Combined with the perennial supply constraints
column9: it's   rather impressive that the company was able to move that many   smartphones.Other quarterly records set in Q4 were earnings per share   ($3.36)
column10: services revenue ($7.2 billion)
column11: Mac revenue ($7.2   billion)
column12: Apple Watch units (who knows?!)
column13: and Apple Watch   revenue (your guess is as good as mine). Four out of Apple's five   geographical operating segments also set fresh highs (all but   Greater China). That's what I call comprehensive performance.Two cameras are better than oneAs usual
column14: the iPhone was the star of the show
column15: comprising   nearly 70% of sales. While sales were up 5%
column16: sell-through was up   8% thanks to robust demand. In line with CFO Luca Maestri'sprediction in October
column17: average selling prices (ASPs) bounced back sequentially with a   vengeance. ASPs were depressed for a few quarters in 2016   following the launch of the $400 iPhone SE
column18: but have now   rebounded to $695 -- pretty comparable to last year's $691.Data source: SEC filings. Chart by author. Calendar quarters     shown.This tells investors a few things
column19: some obvious and others   less so. Clearly
column20: the iPhone 7 Plus is a hit
column21: likely due to the   dual-camera system that is the most notable differentiating   feature. On the earnings call
column22: CEO Tim Cook noted that the mix   was skewed toward the Plus models more than in any prior cycle   (this is the third year that Apple has had Plus models with   5.5-inch displays). Cook even acknowledged later in the call that   Apple did not predict iPhone 7 Plus demand very well
column23: which   adversely affected production plans.Additionally
column24: Apple finally increased the entry-level storage   to 32 GB in 2016
column25: at long last addressing an increasingly   prominent customer complaint. The financial risk to that move was   removing the upsell incentive
column26: and the $100 to $200 that goes   with it. If 32 GB of storage is sufficient
column27: a larger proportion   of customers may opt for the base model instead of upgrading; 16   GB has long been woefully insufficient
column28: virtually assuring strong   upgrade activity. The good news is that Apple has maintained a   relatively comparable mix of upgrades
column29: as evidenced by the strong   ASP.Macs and iPadsThe fact that Mac revenue hit a new all-time high shows that   Apple still has tricks up its sleeve. We're talking about a   business that's over 40 years old
column30: after all. The new MacBook   Pros with Touch Bar were significantly constrained during the   quarter
column31: but the related price increase appears to have been able   to help Mac ASPs by quite a bit. Mac ASPs jumped sequentially   from $1
column33: 348; this is the first time in nearly three   years that this figure was above $1
column34: 300.There wasn't a whole lot of news on the iPad front
column35: in part   because Apple didn't update its tablet lineup in the fall. Apple   sold 13.1 million units
column36: down 19% from a year ago. iPad revenue   fell more than that due to declining ASPs ($423). The more   affordable iPads continue to prove rather popular. Cook said the   company has some exciting things in the pipeline for iPad
column37: potentially referring to the rumors around other display sizes or   the Apple Pencil 2.Services to $50 billionApple's services business has just officially become a $25   billion business on a trailing-12-month basis. Management   ambitiously hopes todoublethis business within the next four years
column38: targeting $50 billion   in annual revenue in 2020. That's an aggressive goal
column39: but also in   line with the company's efforts to shift investor attention   toward recurring revenue sources.CFO Luca Maestri noted that the App Store continues to be the   main driver of growth
column40: thanks to increased buying activity within   the installed based as well as new users coming to the platform.   The music business
column41: including both downloads and streaming
column42: has   started growing again over the past three quarters. iCloud   storage upsells are also growing ""very quickly
column43: as is AppleCare.   Simply put
column44: the plethora of services that Apple offers are all   faring well.Wrapping upShare repurchases came in at $11 billion
column45: which included $5   billion in open market purchases and a $6 billion accelerated   share repurchase (ASR) program. That's the ninth ASR for those   keeping score at home. The company retired 65.3 million shares   during the quarter thanks to these aggressive repurchases
column46: which   contributed to the record EPS due to its accretive effects.That puts cumulative share repurchases at $143.7 billion out   of the current $175 billion authorization. Apple updates its   capital return program every spring
column47: typically alongside its   April earnings release. There's plenty of room to accommodate   Apple's typical level of repurchases
column48: and investors can look   forward to an update next quarter.In terms of fundamentals
column49: the results were a blowout. Investor   reaction
column50: on the other hand
column51: is another topic. Shares jumped over   4% in extended trading
column52: and Apple hasn't traded around $125 since   mid-2015. I still have doubts about Apple enjoying any semblance   of multiple expansion
column53: but the business is as strong as ever.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column54: it can pay to listen. After all
column55: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column57: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them! column4: 2017makeArticleAd();Payroll processing giant ADPADPhas released its January private sector jobs report before the bell this morning
column5: posting a far-better-than-expected 246K new jobs for the month. Consensus expectations had been for 164K. December's total was revised downward by 2000 jobs to 151K
column6: which is the range in which the U.S. labor market had been settling prior to this morning's number.The Services group still rules the roost
column7: with 201K new January jobs in the private sector
column8: whereas Goods brought in 46K. Manufacturing and Mining totals
column9: while not incredibly strong
column10: at least have swung to the positive - 15K and 6K
column11: respectively. Healthcare put up a strong 49K
column12: but the top two sectors were in Professional/Business Services at 71K and Trade/Transportation/Utilities at 63K.Good weather in January can likely take some of this credit. Medium-sized companies (between 50-499 employees) brought in the lion's share with 102K
column13: followed by large companies (500+ employees) at 83K
column14: with Small firms (under 50) picking up the remaining 62K. For years
column15: at least seemingly
column16: it had been small-business hiring which had kept the labor market strong. This looks to be shifting.The ADP report serves as somewhat of a forward indicator toward the monthly non-farm payroll results from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS)
column17: which also includes Government jobs and will be released Friday. However
column18: the analyst consensus for the BLS total is 174K as of now
column19: down considerably from today's private-sector results. Historically
column20: the ADP and BLS numbers don't always gibe in the near-term
column21: but upon revisions in future months they tend to track each other pretty consistently.What some economists predict going forward
column22: though
column23: is a labor market that shows increasing difficulties with filling open job positions. This is part of what it means to have an Unemployment rate at around 4.7%. This results in wage growth picking up
column24: which we've also seen some evidence of lately. So the potential problems with finding employees with the skill-sets to fill certain positions - which may be exacerbated by the Trump administration's rather draconian policies regarding immigration reform
column25: in that immigrants traditionally absorb many jobs on the lower levels of the pay-scale - may manifest in a stagnating labor market going forward.Earnings UpdateAppleAAPLput up Q1 2017 earnings numbers after the bell that were reminiscent of the tech giant's late-era Steve Jobs years

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL): The Cheapest $800 Stock I Know;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsDisruption is everywhere.Amazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) disrupts how we shop
column4: whileAirbnbdisrupts where we stay.Tesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) disrupts what we drive
column5: andUbereven disruptswhetherwe drive. If a teen with 2 million Instagram followers can disrupt how billion-dollar businesses find customers
column6: the rest of us need to dive in and start swimming â€¦ or at least buy the one stock which has its hands in all of the above:Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL).makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockSimply put
column7: GOOGL stock is the most innovative
column8: most disruptive and cheapest $800 equity I know.Let me explain.Silicon Valley money manager Michael Moe and his team at GSV Asset Management produce a provocative weekly newsletter dedicated to highlighting where they think the world is going. While doing research for myBullseye Brief
column9: one of their recent pieces got me thinking about innovation in more tangible terms. The team ranked eight global technology companies based on their involvement across 22 cutting-edge categories. Hands down
column10: Alphabet ranks No. 1
column11: capturing 21 of 22.Innovation LeadersCuriously
column12: all eight GSV-highlighted companies have dedicated efforts in the areas of artificial intelligence
column13: big data and cloud services
column14: making these three the Holy Grail of innovation.The first two come as no surprise
column15: as data gathering and analysis are critical to predicting behavior
column16: enabling companies to target consumers accordingly. Web services
column17: which is now the fastest-growing segment for Amazon
column18: is less obvious but nonetheless a clear indicator these innovators want to get bigger by serving as the backbone for other companies.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThis is key

column20: I'll bet on GOOGL.MoonshotMuch of Google's innovative efforts happen at its off-site research center called Google X
column21: aka the Moonshot Factory. It's run by a futurist named Astro Teller
column22: and I highly recommend hisTED Talkexplaining how Google X approaches innovation:Identify a problem affecting millions of people.Find or propose a radical solution for solving that problem.Move full speed ahead if there's reason to believe technology for such a radical solution could actually be built.He says Google X people spend most of their time ""breaking things and trying to prove they're wrong"" but believes that's their secret â€¦ what makes Googlers different. By ""killing"" more projects than they approve
column23: their success rate rises. Alphabet spent $13.8 billion last year on research and development - the second highest number of any company in the world behind Amazon
column24: and second highest as a percentage of sales among the eight innovation leaders.R&D as % of RevenueAlphabet invests a staggering amount of money to fund R&D
column25: both because it can and because it has to. With three times more online advertising than its next closest competitor
column26: GOOGL is a cash cow.By the same token
column27: it has significant overlap with all seven competitors in the most obvious categories - like robotics and AI- and each of these companies is hungry to dominate.There's no letting up in this crowd. Innovate or die.What's GOOGL Stock Worth?Ultimately
column28: the question is value: What do we pay?I like to compare the growth we're getting (earnings) with the price we're paying (price-to-earnings
column29: or P/E). This is called a price/earnings-to-growth ratio (PEG)
column30: and it's an intuitive way to compare apples to apples.Using 2017 consensus estimates tracked by Bloomberg
column31: GOOGL stock is tucked right in the middle of the pack. Its PEG ratio is 1.08. PEGs below 1 are cheap
column32: and PEGs approaching 2 are expensive.PEG ratios are revealing.First of all
column33: no one should buyMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT). It's neither a growth stock nor a value play.Alibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) is a tad expensive
column34: but not excessively so
column35: especially since many consider ittheChinese consumer trading vehicle.Amazon is attractive
column36: so areApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) andFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column37: both of which I have written up as longs and currently own.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!Samsung(OTCMKTS:SSNLF)
column38: I admit is a mystery. It'ssocheap. I can only surmise its limited German and S. Korean listings deter U.S. investors
column39: as does the $1

column41: I'm assigned shares and become a buyer. If Google continues making new highs
column42: I pocket the premium. I am content either way. Google's chart indicates initial technical support around $780
column43: and significant long-term support $700-$725.The reason I'm selling puts rather than buying the stock is because GOOGL stock has recently risen to a new all-time high. I know new highs tend to beget new highs (momentum traders buy strength)

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) reported its fiscal first-quarter earnings on Tuesday after the bell
column3: and it kicked the year off the right way. Apple set an all-time quarterly revenue record - snapping its streak of declines - and broke its previous iPhone sales record. AAPL stock is up strongly Wednesday morning as a result.makeAd('4'
column5: 'mktsnews'
column6: 'vanguard'
column8: '');Source: AppleBut the star of yesterday's show wasn't the iPhone. It was the Services division
column9: which includes the App Store
column10: Apple Pay
column11: iTunes
column12: AppleCare and Apple Music. Services didn't just set another record - it also posted the strongest year-over-year growth of any AAPL division.Services Is on Fire
column13: Led by the App StoreApple reported that the quarterly revenue for its Services division topped $7.17 billion for Q1
column14: an increase of 18% compared to the previous year. If that sounds like a lot of money for what is largely made up of mobile payment transaction fees and digital content
column15: it is. In comparison
column16: Netflix
column17: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) experienced its largest-ever subscriber growth in the final quarter of 2016
column18: leading it to post revenue of $2.48 billion.During the AAPL earnings conference call
column19: CEO Tim Cook noted that he expects the Services division to bethe size of a Fortune 100 company by the end of the year. Other key information about the Services division from that earnings call includes:App Store revenue for December alone was a record-setting $3 billionThere are now 2.2 million apps in the App Store
column20: and AAPL paid out over $20 billion to developers in 2016The number of Apple Pay users has tripled over the past year
column21: with transaction volume up over 500% year-over-yearAppleCare and storage services (iCloud) both set all-time recordsApple's music business grew for the third straight quarterWhy Services Revenue is ImportantYou might not know it based on Apple's record-setting iPhone sales this quarter
column22: but selling hardware is tough.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryOnce a consumer has an iPhone in his or her hands
column23: it becomes very difficult to convince them to spend a minimum $649 to ditch that smartphone for a new one. In one sense
column24: a huge installed user base - which AAPL has
column25: withmore than 1 billion iOS devices in active use- works against the company. When the iPhone first began to take off
column26: AAPL was selling to people who'd never owned one before. Now
column27: that pool of easy sales is dwindling. And Apple is left in the tougher position of convincing its installed user base to upgrade.Thus the hand-wringing about slowing iPhone sales.Apple's Services division largely benefits from that huge installed user base
column28: though. True
column29: AAPL only gets one shot at selling these customers AppleCare. But once they own an iPhone
column30: iPad
column31: iPod
column32: Mac
column33: Apple Watch or AppleTV
column34: they begin to explore Apple's other services. They are increasingly adopting Apple Pay. They are in a prime position to buy movies on their Apple TV. They are perfect candidates to subscribe to Apple Music. There are plenty of hooks for storing data on iCloud. And of course
column35: there is the App Store and the lure of its millions of apps.Apple's Services revenue doesn't come in big chunks like selling an iPhone. It's $9.99 a month here
column36: 99 cents for an app there
column37: a few cents for a transaction. But it adds up
column38: especially when over a billion customers are generating it.More importantly
column39: that revenue doesn't drop off the same way hardware revenue does when people stop buying new iPhones.Some services - like iCloud and Apple Music - are subscription-based. AAPL keeps automatically billing the customer's card every month regardless of whether their iPhone is brand new or five years old. Apple Pay revenues are increasing as more countries and businesses accept it and iPhone owners grow more accustomed to using it.Bottom Line for AAPLPeople never stop buying apps. They may slow down after the initial rush of a new device
column40: but developers keep bring enticing new games and other apps to the App Store. That means the 1 billion users continue to download.Trade of the Day: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock No Longer a Home RunJust look at the 40 million-plusSuper Mario Rundownloads from the App Storein only four days.How many iPhones will AAPL sell two years from now? No one knows for sure
column41: but odds are it won't be many more than it does now. On the other hand
column42: Apple is confident its highflying App Store
column43: Apple Pay and other services will see Services division revenue double in that time.The iPhone may have driven Apple stock growth over the past decade. But Services revenue is increasingly important as AAPL stock searches for that elusive next hardware hit.As of this writing

(AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: Inc.'s Record Quarter Returns the Company to Growth;2/1/2017;"After market on closed on Tuesday
column3: tech giantApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) put to rest any doubts about the company's ability   to post strong holiday results. Shares moved a few percentage   points higher immediately after the company released its figures   for its Dec. 31-ending first fiscal quarter of 2017. Apple's   revenue and earnings exceeded both management's own forecast for   the quarter and analysts' consensus estimate.Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Here's a look at some of the biggest takeaways from the   results.Financial resultsMetricQ1 2017Q1 2016Year-Over-Year ChangeRevenue$78.4 billion$75.9 billion3.3%Earnings per share$3.36$3.282.4%Gross profit margin38.5%$40.1%(160 basis points)Data source: AppleQ1 2017 press release. Table by author.Apple's revenue reached an all-time high of $78.4 billion
column4: up   3.3% from the year-ago quarter and above the company's guidance   for $76 billion to $78 billion. In addition
column5: Apple's EPS of $3.28   easily exceeded the midpoint of its guidance range for about   $3.17.Segment resultsThe iPhone remained crucial to Apple's overall results
column6: accounting for nearly 70% of total revenue during the quarter.   With a 5% year-over-year increase in iPhone revenue
column7: the product   segment played a key role in Apple's better-than-expected   financial results.But the tech giant's services segment
column8: which accounts for   sales from the App Store
column9: iTunes
column10: Apple Music
column11: iCloud
column12: Apple Pay
column13: licensing
column14: and other services
column15: was also important. Services   revenue was up 18% year over year
column16: accounting for 9.1% of the   quarter's total results -- up from 8% in the year-ago quarter.   Apple CEO Tim Cook commented specifically on Apple's services   segment performance
column17: saying the growth was ""led by customer   activity on the App Store.""Data source: Apple Q1 2017 press release. Chart by     author.Another bright spot from Apple's segment results was Mac. With   the help of its new MacBook Pro
column18: the segment's revenue increased   7% year over year.However
column19: not all of Apple's product segments were on the rise   during the quarter. Apple's iPad revenue continued its downward   trend
column20: with revenue falling 22% year over year. Other products   revenue
column21: which includes sales of Apple TV
column22: Apple Watch
column23: Beats   products
column24: iPod
column25: and accessories
column26: saw its revenue decline 8% year   over year. But Apple was careful to note in its first-quarter   press release that despite the decline in other products revenue
column27: Apple Watch revenue hit an all-time high.GuidanceApple also notably said it expects revenue growth to continue   in the company's second quarter -- an important guide
column28: considering the company reported three straight quarters of   year-over-year revenue declines in fiscal 2016. Apple guided for   second-quarter revenue to be in the range of $51.5 billion to   $53.5 billion
column29: up from $50.6 billion in the year-ago quarter.Looking beyond the financial results for Apple's second   quarter
column30: Cook said the Apple team is ""excited"" about the products   in its pipeline.The strong quarter for the tech giant
column31: along with a nice   return to growth for the current quarter and for expected revenue   in Q2
column32: reinforces the company's ability to drive results for   shareholders even in a post hyper-iPhone-growth era.Cook was pleased with the company's performance: ""Our team   executed extremely well in the face of strong macroeconomic   headwinds. We are very happy with the continued strong growth in   revenue from services

column1: Tuesday Apple Rumors: Future Version of iOS May Not Support 32-Bit Apps;1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is bad news for 32-bit iOS apps . Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Tuesday.makeArticleAd();32-Bit Apps:A notification in the iOS 10.3 beta warns that 32-bit apps are on their way out
column4: reportsMacRumors. The notifications pops up when the user goes to open a 32-bit app in the beta. It states that the app will not work on future versions of iOS. It's unknown is this means that iOS 11 won't support 32-bit apps. As it is now
column5: the iOS 10.3.2 beta still supports the apps. AAPL started forcing developers to make 64-bit apps in February 2015
column6: but some apps not updated after that haven't been affected by this change.Colonge Store:Apple is reportedly preparing to open its second store in Colonge
column7: Germany
column8: AppleInsidernotes. The tech company has announced that it is opening a second store in the city. However
column9: photos taken of a building show a lit AAPL logo hidden behind tarps. Inside work on the building can't be seen due to tarps blocking the way. Current rumors claims that the store will open its doors to customers for the first time in the second half of February.Nintendo Games:Nintendo Co.
column10: Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY)is preparing to release more games on iOS devices
column11: reports9to5Mac. Nintendo will be releasingFire Emblem Heroeson the iPhone and iPad on Feb. 2
column12: 2017. It is also planning to release the mobileAnimal Crossinggame to iOS devices in the near future. However
column13: there has been a delay. This delay has the game not coming out until the company's next fiscal year
column14: which starts in April. NTDOY previously planned to release the game during its current fiscal year.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postTuesday Apple Rumors: Future Version of iOS May Not Support 32-Bit Appsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 ETFs For True Total Market Coverage;1/31/2017;"ETF investors often spend an inordinate amount of time trying to find the best spot in the market.  They love focusing on specific sectors
column2: factors
column3: or tactical strategies that are showing a promising edge.  However
column4: there is often a fundamental need for simple and diversified stock exposure at the lowest possible cost.This type of core foundation is the essence behind total stock market funds.  They allow you to stay correlated with the broadest possible indexes and charge expenses that are so fractional as to be almost non-existent.  They embody the true spirit of the ETF philosophy in their liquidity
column5: tax efficiency
column6: and transparency.The largest and most well-known of this group is theVanguard Total Stock Market ETF(VTI).  Over the years
column7: Iâ€™ve lost track of how many awards and commendations this fund has received.  Its true value proposition is the simplicity of a single vehicle for complete U.S. stock market coverage with the lowest possible tracking error.makeAd('4'
column9: 'mktsnews'
column10: 'vanguard'
column12: '');VTI owns a basket of 3
column13: 592 publicly traded securities across the large
column14: mid
column15: and small-cap verticals.  You canâ€™t get much more diversified than that.  The fund is market-cap weighted to give the largest stocks a greater share of its $70 billion asset base.  Nevertheless
column16: the top holding
column17: Apple Inc(AAPL) only accounts for 2.5% of the total portfolio.  That leaves a large swath of exposure to be distributed through the thousands of remaining holdings.One of the highly touted advantages of VTI is its ultra-low expense ratio of 0.05%.  Thatâ€™s just $50 for every $100
column18: 000 invested on an annual basis.  The minimal expenses ensure this fund is appropriate as a long-term position in virtually any type of equity portfolio.The next largest fund by size is theSchwab US Broad Market ETF(SCHB)
column19: which has $7.7 billion under management.  This ETF tracks a basket of 2
column20: 000 stocks domiciled in the U.S. through all market-cap segments.SCHB claims one of the lowest industry expense ratios at just 0.03% annually.  This fee has been incrementally lowered multiple times over the years
column21: which adds to its attractiveness for long-term investors.  Itâ€™s even conceivable that one day this ETF will charge as low as one basis point per year for access to its diversified stock portfolio.Last
column22: but certainly not least
column23: is theiShares Core S&P Total U.S. Stock Market ETF(ITOT).  This fund shares traits of both VTI and SCHB in its overall makeup.  It charges an expense ratio of 0.03% and contains more than 3
column24: 600 underlying holdings.  ITOT has $6.7 billion in assets under management and has been in place since 2004.While all three of these funds have minor differences in their structure
column25: they must ultimately be judged on their results. The 5-year price chart below shows that the returns for all three are almost indistinguishable from each other.That level of correlation is a dependable statistic for those that are agonizing over which is the best fund to pick.  There really is no wrong answer here.  Although
column26: the decision may be made easier if one of these options is available transaction-free from your brokerage platform.  That would truly minimize total costs and allow you to scale in or out of any shares with the lowest possible friction.The Bottom LineTotal market ETFs are solid tools for both experienced investors and those who are just starting out on this journey.  They provide a truly simple path to a diversified stock allocation without having to agonize over various investment styles.  Removing complexity from the equation can result in better execution and a much greater chance for long-term success.Disclosure: At the time this article was written
column27: the author owned shares of ITOT."

column1: Intel Corporation Gets an Apple Inc. iPhone 7 Boost;1/31/2017;"Finally
column2: microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) has managed to achieve a real degree of success in   the market for chips that go into smartphones. A while back
column3: it   was revealed thatApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) had chosen to use Intel as a second source for the   LTE modems that power its iPhone.Apple's iPhone SE. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();Now
column4: while some investors may have worried that Intel might be   ""giving away"" these cellular modems -- in a move similar to what   the company did with its Bay Trail tablet processors (i.e.   providing platform cost offsets valued more than the selling   prices of the chips) -- the company's most recent financial   results show that this is very clearly not the case.The big modem boostIntel's modem sales fall under its Client Computing Group   (CCG)
column5: which derives the bulk of its revenue from sales of   processors and other components that go into personal   computers. When Intel reports financial results for CCG
column6: it   gives investors two numbers to chew on: platform revenue and   ""other"" revenue. Platform revenue is made up of processor and   accompanying chipset (also known as a PCH) sales
column7: while ""other""   revenue refers to a smorgasbord of other complementary   technologies
column8: including cellular modems.We can see that Intel is seeing a very large boost in cellular   modem sales because Intel's revenue from ""other"" went from $356   million in the fourth quarter of 2015 -- when Intel sold   precisely zero modems to Apple -- to $773 million in the fourth   quarter of 2016 -- when Intel is known to be selling modems to   Apple.Of course
column9: it's likely that not all of that increase is due to   the ramp up in cellular modem shipments -- Intel did take the   time to highlight that it enjoyed record Wi-Fi chip shipments   last quarter -- but there's really nothing else that can explain   the substantial majority of that increase.What does this revenue increase tell us?The bad news is that we can't deduce too much about the   profitability of these modems solely from these results -- though   Intel did indicate later in the call that cellular modem   shipments during 2017 would serve as a headwind to the company's   gross profit margins. So we know that the modems are sold at   lower than corporate average margins.What we can deduce is this
column10: however: Intel isn't providing   excessive ""contra-revenue"" payments to get these modems into the   iPhone because Intel is generating positive revenue -- and   significant revenue at that -- from its modems. (Although we   already knew this because Intel would almost have certainly   disclosed to investors in advance that a ramp of its modem   shipments would detract from operating profit.) If that were the   case
column11: some investors may have wanted to see the financial   evidence before believing it.Looking aheadIf we assume that Intel is going to continue to supply Apple   with modems beyond the iPhone 7 -- and the odds of this look good   -- then there are some interesting financial   implications. First
column12: Intel's share at Apple may be set to   grow in the coming product cycle. Right now
column13: Intel is in some   portion of the iPhone 7 models
column14: but is completely absent from the   iPhone SE
column15: iPhone 6s
column16: or iPhone 6s.Once Apple releases new models and waterfalls the iPhone 7 and   iPhone 7 Plus to serve as its mid-range offerings -- and if we   assume that Intel and Qualcomm get roughly equivalent order   allocations during the next iPhone cycle to what we're seeing   with the iPhone 7 series -- then Intel's share will necessarily   go up. I also wouldn't be surprised to see Intel inside of a   future iPhone SE
column17: as well.It's reasonable to expect that Intel will see some nice   year-over-year growth in the ""other"" portion of CCG over the   course of 2017
column18: with acceleration happening in the second half of   the year
column19: due to the launch of the new iPhone models.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip
column20: it can pay to listen. After all
column21: the newsletter     they have run for over a decade
column22: the Motley Fool Stock     Advisor
column23: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are theten best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Wal-Mart wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12
column24: 2016The author(s) may have a position in any stocks       mentioned.Ashraf Eassaowns shares of Intel. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the following options:     long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95     calls on Apple. The Motley Fool recommends Intel. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Is Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Resurrecting the Cursed Windows RT?;1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsDon't look now
column3: butMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) looks to be taking another run atAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column4: NASDAQ:GOOG) Chrome operating system. References have begun popping up in builds of the Windows 10 Creators Update (which is due to arrive in April) to Windows 10 Cloud.makeArticleAd();Source: MicrosoftSpeculation is growing that Windows 10 Cloud is in fact a new simplified version of Microsoft's operating system
column5: designed to run on devices powered by inexpensive ARM chips fromARM Holdings plc (ADR)(NASDAQ:ARMH).In other words
column6: it appears that Microsoft is preparing to take on the threat of Chromebooks - the cheap
column7: popular laptops running Google's Chrome OS. And it seems to be doing so by resurrecting the idea of Windows RT.Windows 10 CloudWindows 10 Creators Build is the next major revision of the Microsoft Windows PC operating system. It's due to begin rolling out to users around April 17.The 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsBut developers have been testing pre-release builds of Microsoft's software and recently some of them began to notice something strange: The code references different variations of the operating system. For example
column8: Windows 10 Pro for Workstation and Windows 10 for Enterprise are spiked out. Nothing unusual there. But then
column9: references to Windows 10 Cloud began to appear. And that started raising eyebrows - what is Windows 10 Cloud?ZDNet'sMary Jo Foley put the pieces together yesterday. Quoting unnamed sources
column10: she says that the mysterious Windows 10 Cloud is a new
column11: simplified version of Microsoft Windows that will run only Unified Windows Platform (UWP) apps. In other words
column12: it's a""simpler
column13: safer
column14: cheaper"" version of Windows 10.You might also think of it as another crack at Windows RT â€¦Windows RT? But Why?Everyone remembers the mess that wasWindows RT. The attempt to shoehorn a version of Windows onto a consumer tablet running ARM chips -the ill-fated Surface RT - very nearly dealt MSFT's tablet aspirations a fatal blow.However
column15: despite the failure of Windows RT
column16: Microsoft has never given up on the idea of Windows on ARM chips. By doing so
column17: it can get Windows onto mobile devices that can't use the more powerful and expensive chips fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC). The company has already been showing offWindows 10 running in emulation on high-end ARM chips. As part of that effort
column18: it could also be working on a ""lite"" version that can deliver much of the Windows 10 experience on less expensive
column19: lower powered ARM hardware.So why
column20: why
column21: whywould Microsoft risk falling flat on its face again with what essentially amounts to another crack at Windows RT? There are two reasons.The first is that dream of ""Windows everywhere."" Having the full Windows 10 experience on high-powered ARM chips is great
column22: but only flagship smartphones and tablets can afford to use those chips. Windows 10 Cloud would get Microsoft Windows (and Bing) onto a whole lot more mobile hardware.The second is Google's Chrome OS and Chromebooks. These cheap laptops have been under Microsoft's skin for years. They've become extremely popular in the education sector thanks to low cost
column23: ease of use and built-in security. And Chromebooks have just kept selling
column24: to the point where last year they passed evenApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL)MacBooks in sales.Microsoft has tried fighting back by helping manufacturers put out cheap Windows 10 laptops
column25: but that hasn't stemmed the Chromebook flood. Windows 10 makes for a sluggish experience on inexpensive Intel hardware
column26: it's far more complex than Chrome OS to use and lacks the drop-dead easy security of Chromebooks.Cash Out of Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Before EarningsWindows 10 Cloud running on laptops with ARM processors would compete head-to-head with Chromebooks running Chrome OS: simpler
column27: safer and cheaper than Windows 10.Microsoft refused to comment on theZDNetpost
column28: but the pieces pointing to Windows 10 as a Chrome OS-fighting
column29: second crack at Windows RT make sense. Naturally
column30: MSFT is going to avoid all references to Windows RT - that's poison - and the Windows 10 Cloud name could end up being a code name.It could also be an attempt to steal some of the Chrome OS ""cloud"" thunder. Expect to get the final answer on Windows 10 Cloud from Microsoft prior to that April 17 Windows 10 Creators Build release.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 ""Golden"" Ammo Stocks to Buy for Big 2017 Returns3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionThe postIs Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Resurrecting the Cursed Windows RT?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Intel Corporation's Personal-Computer Business Beats Expectations;1/31/2017;"On Jan. 26
column2: microprocessor giantIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) announced its financial results for the fourth   quarter of 2016 and
column3: by extension
column4: the entirety of 2016.A rendering of an Intel seventh-generation Core processor.     Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();The company had previously guided to $15.7 billion in revenue   for the quarter and gross profit margin of 61%
column5: representing   sequential declines from $15.8 billion and 63.3%
column6: respectively.Intel's actual financial results were much more impressive;   the company reported $16.4 billion in revenue for the quarter and   a gross profit margin percentage of 61.7%
column7: up from $14.9 billion   and down from 64.3% in the prior year
column8: respectively.For the full year
column9: Intel raked in $59.4 billion at 60.9% gross   profit margin -- a little above the midpoint of its long-term   gross margin range of 55% to 65%
column10: though down 170 basis points   year over year.This upside appears to have been driven
column11: ironically enough
column12: by   the company's Client Computing Group (CCG) business
column13: which   derives the bulk of its revenues from sales of components into   personal computers
column14: generally viewed as a declining market.Let's take a closer look at the company's revenue and profit   performance in this segment.Solid improvements in revenue and     profitabilityIntel reported that total CCG revenue hit $9.13 billion in the   most recent quarter
column15: up from $8.76 billion in the same quarter a   year-ago -- a respectable 4% year-over-year boost.Operating income vastly outpaced revenue
column16: though
column17: with this   figure growing from $2.72 billion in the year-ago quarter to   $3.52 billion in the most recent quarter -- up almost 30% year   over year. Management attributed this to lower operating   expenses
column18: a ""richer product mix
column19: and improved product margins as   14-nanometer chip manufacturing yields improved. The same story   has been playing out all year in CCG.Now
column20: it's worth noting that Intel reported that the ""platform""   portion of its CCG revenue
column21: which consists of sales of processors   and chipsets
column22: were roughly flat
column23: at $8.36 billion in the prior   year compared with $8.4 billion in the most recent quarter. But   its ""other"" segment -- which includes complementary products
column24: such as wireless chips -- saw revenues more than double to $773   million
column25: from $356 million a year-ago.It is likely that this large boost in ""other"" revenue within   CCG was due primarily to the ramp-up of the company's XMM 7360   cellular modem in theApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus devices.Good full-year resultsFor the full year
column26: Intel reported that CCG revenue was up 2%
column27: while expectations going into the year were for a decline
column28: with   operating profit up a smidgen more than 30%. Platform revenue was   roughly flat
column29: at $30.75 billion versus $30.68 billion
column30: with   ""other"" revenue surging from $1.54 billion in 2015 to $2.16   billion in 2016.The iPhone win clearly contributed to a large part of the   ""other"" segment growth here
column31: but the driver of the increased   platform revenue is a little bit subtler.Indeed
column32: Intel reported that shipments of its notebook computer   processors declined by 1% year over year and that shipments of   its desktop computer processors dropped by 6%. Key to keeping   platform revenues flat was a 2% increase in notebook platform   average selling prices
column33: as well as a 2% increase in desktop   platform average selling prices.What's happening
column34: then
column35: is that computer makers are selling   fewer computers than they were before
column36: as evidenced by the   notebook and desktop platform unit shipment drops
column37: but the   computers that they do sell
column38: on average
column39: contain more expensive   processors.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column41: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: 5 Reasons I Don't Buy MeetMe's Growth Story;1/31/2017;"Last December
column2: I highlightedMeetMe(NASDAQ: MEET) as apotentially undervaluedgrowth play in a frothy market. The social networking app maker   posted eye-popping numbers last quarter -- 32% annual growth in   monthly active users (MAUs)
column3: 20% growth in total revenues
column4: and   30% non-GAAP earnings growth.Analysts expect MeetMe's revenue and non-GAAP earnings to   respectively rise 38% and 16% next year. Yet the stock trades at   just 7 times trailing earnings and 10 times forward earnings.   Let's take a look at the five key reasons investors aren't buying   MeetMe's growth story
column5: despite its high growth figures and low   valuations.MeetMe's mobile app. Image source: Google Play.makeArticleAd();1. A troubling history with sexual predatorsMeetMe lets users find new people in their area to chat with
column6: similar toMatch's(NASDAQ: MTCH) Tinder. While there's nothing inherently   sinister about the app
column7: there have been multiple reports of   MeetMe being used by sexual predators.In 2014
column8: the City of San Francisco sued MeetMe for the   unlawful publication of minors' profiles
column9: photos
column10: and geolocation   data
column11: and claimed that  the app ""enabled"" sexual predators   to find their victims. The city cited several cases involving   adult men and minors in which MeetMe was used. MeetMe settled the   case for $200
column12: 000 the  following year
column13: agreeing to clarify   and simplify its user agreements and settings
column14: and reducing the   amount of data displayed on minors to their city and state.But the cases involving MeetMe didn't cease -- last February
column15: a Buffalo man was  charged with multiple counts of child   pornography after using MeetMe to find minors. MeetMe's troubles   raised red flags at Tinder
column16: which hiked its age limit from 13 to   18 last June. Yet MeetMe still hasn't followed suit
column17: presumably   because it would lose a large portion of its users.2. The potential loss of ad revenuesYou'd think that big companies would be reluctant to advertise   on MeetMe
column18: but plenty of big brands still advertise on the app.   That's because MeetMe generates most of its ad revenues from   programmatic ads delivered byTwitter's(NYSE:TWTR) MoPub.This means that MoPub's customers simply pick a demographic --   in MeetMe's case
column19: younger users and Millennials -- and the   platform feeds the ads to various apps. This means that many   companies probably don't realize that their ads are appearing on   MeetMe.Therefore
column20: a common bear thesis is that MoPub could decide to   drop MeetMe due to violations of its terms of service
column21: or   advertisers could ask MoPub to pull their ads from the   controversial app. There's no evidence either of these scenarios   will occur
column22: but it raises a troubling question -- if MeetMe's   reputation worsens
column23: can it still keep growing its ad   revenues?3. Being booted from the app storesIn its 10-K filing for fiscal 2015
column24: MeetMe admits  that   its business will suffer if it is ""unable to maintain a good   relationship"" withAppleandAlphabet's Google. It notes that its app could be pulled from their app   stores ""if we violate"" or the companies believe ""that we have   violated"" their terms and conditions.The bulls might believe that's just a typical ""risk factor""   warning
column25: but MeetMe admits in the same filing that ""on more than   one occasion
column26: Apple rejected its app ""because of user generated   content and other concerns."" This indicates that another   high-profile lawsuit could knock MeetMe out of the app stores and   kill its business.4. Tinder is crushing MeetMeMeetMe arrived before Tinder
column27: which was initially launched in   2012. But over the past five years
column28: mainstream interest in MeetMe   waned in correlation with Tinder's growth
column29: as seen in this chart   from Google Trends:Image source: Google.That decline also explains why MeetMe acquired its competitor   Skout last  October. That move boosted the company's MAU   count from about 5 million to  8.5 million
column30: and greatly   inflated MeetMe's top and bottom line growth for fiscal 2016.5. The lack of insider confidenceIf MeetMe is as undervalued as the fundamentals suggest
column31: you'd   expect insiders to be loading up on shares. However
column32: MeetMe CEO   Geoffrey Cook just  sold 250
column33: 000 shares (16% of his entire   position) at an average price of $5.02.Including Cook's sales
column34: insiders sold  1.96 million   shares over the past 12 months
column35: but only bought 334
column36: 000 shares.   It's understandable that MeetMe's insiders would sell after the   stock's 50% rally over the past 12 months
column37: but it also indicates   that its upside potential could be limited.The key takeawayThe main lesson here is to always look beyond the valuations   and growth forecasts. On the surface
column38: MeetMe looks like a rapidly   growing social app maker trading at a discount to its peers. But   dig deeper
column39: and you'll see an app that's struggling to prove that   it's not a tool for criminals while remaining relevant against   Tinder
column40: which dominates the space with  over 50 million   active users.10 stocks we like better than MeetMeWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column41: it can pay to listen. After all
column42: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column44: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and MeetMe wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Why Expedia Inc Will Profit From This Global Market Trend (EXPE);1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAs an analyst who spends every day looking at numbers
column3: I have a tendency to try and quantify everything. We humans
column4: as a species
column5: tend to do this all the time.makeArticleAd();For the most part
column6: it serves us well. But it can also sometimes be a trap
column7: diminishing the value of what is simply unquantifiable.I learned this lesson a few years ago on a trip to the green highlands and snow-capped mountains of Peru.During the planning phase
column8: I contemplated every detail of the trip
column9: from number of hours spent on flightsâ€¦ nights spent in hotelsâ€¦ how many sites I could see within a certain amount of time. Everything had to be just perfect.But even during the early phases of the journey
column10: I found myself countingâ€¦There were four grueling days of hiking. At about 20.5 miles in total length
column11: it took four days to complete. Each night
column12: we camped at about 13
column13: 000 feet. And at the summit of our hike
column14: we would reach 14
column15: 928 feet.Strenuous hiking at such a high elevation for such an extended period of time meant that every breath
column16: every step
column17: was a laborious effort. But we pressed on
column18: young and old
column19: encouraged each other and offered a helping hand until we reached the end of our journey. And best of all
column20: we knew that each painstaking step meant that we were just that closer to seeing one of the most truly remarkable sights in the world: the ancient Incan city of Machu Picchu.It was only during those little moments when I was able to move past this tendency to quantify everything that I truly lost myself in the mystery and wonder the world has to offer.Hopefully
column21: you've had the chance to have experiences like this at some point in your life
column22: too. All too often
column23: we in the developed world tend to take for granted the fact that most of us have the means to do these kinds of things.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018But there are hundreds of millions of people who don't - but they soon will.The World's Burgeoning Middle ClassGlobal demand for travel is surging. Hundreds of millions of people are entering the global middle class right now and in the years to come. One of the first things these people will look to do is travel.By 2030
column24: two-thirds of the global middle class will be residents of the Asia-Pacific region. That's up from just under one-third in 2009. And China alone is expected to have a staggering one billion members of the middle class by then.China's budding middle class is already traveling in greater numbers than ever before. A United Nations tourism report showed that the number of Chinese citizens traveling overseas has surged from 10 million in 2000 to more than 83 million in 2013.This is a huge opportunity for the online travel business. Consumers in the Asia-Pacific region currently book only about 27% of their travels online
column25: while Latin America lags even further at 21%. In China
column26: only about 15% of consumers currently book their travel online. This is compared to rates over 50% in the United States and Europe.It's not hard to imagine that the rest of the world will quickly catch up to the United States and Europe in terms of booking their travel online. And that sets up a tremendous opportunity.That's where my colleague Jimmy Butts comes in with one of his most recent picks in his premium newsletter
column27: Top Stock Advisorâ€¦How To Profit From This TrendIn last month's issue of his newsletter
column28: Jimmy reported on the incredible growth of the online travel market. Citing much of the information I referenced above
column29: he went on to recommend two publicly-traded online travel companies.I don't like to make a habit of giving away too many picks from our premium publications
column30: since our subscribers pay good money for this information (to learn how to subscribe
column31: go here). But I can reveal that one of them isExpedia Inc(EXPE)
column32: the world's largest online travel company.Surging industry growth is reflected in Expedia's gross bookings. In 2015
column33: the company booked a staggering $60 billion worth of flights
column34: hotels
column35: rental cars and cruises. It's on track to crush those figures in 2016
column36: already racking up gross bookings of more than $56 billion through the first nine months of this year
column37: which is 23% more compared with the first nine months of 2015.Expedia has made major strides in the international market. In 2005
column38: international revenue made up only 22% of its portfolio; last year that soared to approximately 45%. But that's just the tip of the iceberg in terms of potential for growth. Despite being the largest player in online travel
column39: the company still has only a 4% share of the global market.This speaks to the highly-fragmented nature of the market
column40: but also for the potential to grow through acquisitions
column41: which Expedia has been doing for some time now already. Between the growth in the global middle class and growth in the online travel market
column42: Jimmy thinks Expedia should benefit greatly over the next 5-10 years.As such
column43: it's a good long-term holding to consider adding to your portfolio.3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 EarningsJimmy's other pick
column44: however
column45: may have even more potential. I won't give away the name here (to get it
column46: you'll have to subscribe toTop Stock Advisor.) But it has a hold on 50% of the online travel market in China - which by all accounts should be the prime growth market in in the years ahead.While the real value of travel may not be quantifiable
column47: investors who back this company now could be counting sizeable gains within a few years. If you'd like to get the name and ticker symbol of this pick
column48: as well as the rest of Jimmy's top picks for 2017 and beyond
column49: simply visit this link.StreetAuthority's mission is to help individual investors earn above-average profits by providing a source of independent
column50: unbiased - and most of all
column51: profitable - investing ideas. Unlike traditional publishers
column52: StreetAuthority doesn't simply regurgitate the latest stock market news. Instead

Visit us atStreetAuthority.com.Next Page7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in 2017The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksThe postWhy Expedia Inc Will Profit From This Global Market Trend (EXPE)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alphabet Employees Protest Against Trump's Immigration Ban;1/31/2017;"Protests against Donald Trump's anti-immigration policy are gaining steam and the technology sector appears to be leading the way.  More than 2000Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle employees staged protests against Trump's immigration ban by walking out of eight offices worldwide including the company's headquarters in Mountain View on Monday. Photos and videos of the walkouts have been tweeted using hashtag #GooglersUnite.Google co-founder Sergey Brin and CEO Sundar Pichai have extended their full support to the opposition.Concurrent with the protest
column2: Google created a $4 million fund to support immigrant rights groups like the Immigrant Legal Resource Center
column3: the American Civil Liberties Union
column4: the U.N. Refugee Agency and the International Rescue Committee.The protest was particularly against Trump's executive order to ban nationals of seven Muslim majority countries - Iraq
column5: Iran
column6: Somalia
column7: Libya
column8: Syria
column9: Sudan and Yemen - from coming to the U.S. Pichai denounced the order and stated that the ban affects about 187 Google employees.We note that not quite long ago
column10: Trump had called up technology leaders and urged them to create and retain jobs within the U.S. to which most of them had given their nods. However as the immigration ban order rolled out
column11: the sector is sending clear indications that it will not create jobs at the cost of preventing entry to external talent.Alphabet Inc. Free Cash Flow (TTM)Alphabet Inc. Free Cash Flow (TTM)|Alphabet Inc. QuoteProtests Across the Technology IndustryTrump's immigration restrictions have faced the flak of tech leaders in the form of tweets
column12: memos and statements. Chief executive officers of MicrosoftMSFT
column13: AppleAAPL

column1: 3 Questions for Apple
column2: Inc. CEO Tim Cook Today;1/31/2017;"After the market closes today
column3: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) will report results for its first fiscal quarter   of 2017. Ending Dec. 31
column4: the quarter includes the important   holiday period
column5: raising the stakes for the company's performance.   Thanks to seasonality and the timing of Apple's latest iPhone   launch
column6: the quarter is expected to include record-high   revenue.Apple CEO Tim Cook. Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();While Apple's earnings release will give investors a useful   window into the company's financial performance
column7: the tech giant's   earnings call will likely provide investors with some useful   nuggets
column8: too. Ahead the earnings call
column9: which will take place   shortly after Apple releases its financial results for the   quarter
column10: here are three topics Apple CEO Tim Cook will hopefully   address.1. How confident is management in its product pipeline?Recently
column11: Apple's iPhone business has not only leveled off
column12: but it has also been in decline. In Apple's fourth fiscal quarter   of 2016
column13: for instance
column14: iPhone revenue and unit sales were down   13% and 5% year over year
column15: respectively. While some investors may   be hoping the iPhone can return to growth in Apple's first   quarter
column16: investors -- or Apple -- shouldn't count on the iPhone   to be a major growth driver for the company in the future.Since iPhone accounts for about 60% of Apple's total sales
column17: the segment's headwinds make the health of the tech giant's   product pipeline more important than ever. Of course
column18: given the   company's tendency to keep things secret
column19: investors shouldn't   expect to get any specific information on new products from Cook   during Apple's earnings call
column20: but investors can still look for   the CEO to talk about his level of confidence in the company's   upcoming products.2. What could Apple's services revenue growth look like in   2017?As Apple's iPhone
column21: iPad
column22: Mac
column23: and other products segments   turning to year-over-year revenue declines recently
column24: the   company's services segment
column25: which includes sales from iTunes
column26: Apple Music
column27: the App Store
column28: iCloud
column29: Apple Pay
column30: licensing
column31: and   other services
column32: has continued to grow nicely. In Apple's most   recent quarter
column33: services revenue increased 24% year over   year.During Apple's earnings call
column34: investors should look to see if   Cook discusses how the company expects this segment to fair in   2017 and beyond. This question could come in many forms
column35: including:Does Apple expect Apple Music to evolve into a significant     driver for the company?Is growth for Apple Pay accelerating? Or has it leveled     off?Are there new services Apple could launch to continue     building out its services ecosystem?How significant of a role does Apple expect services to     play in the long-term?3. If there's a tax break for repatriation
column36: does Apple plan   to take advantage of it?Considering President Donald Trump's plan to offer a one-off   tax holiday for U.S. companies to repatriate their overseas funds   at a lower tax rate
column37: investors are interested in whether Apple   plans to take part in such a tax break
column38: and
column39: if it does
column40: to what   extent.Image source: Getty Images.Of Apple's enormous $238 billion cash hoard reported in the   company's fourth quarter
column41: a whopping $216 billion is held outside   of the Unite States. If Apple has aggressive plans for taking   advantage of this tax break
column42: the company could significantly   increase its dividend
column43: boost its share repurchase program
column44: pay   out a special dividend
column45: or even do all three.Investors can listen online to Apple's live conference call
column46: which can be found on the company's investor relations website
column47: on Tuesday
column48: Jan. 31
column49: at 2:00 p.m. PT.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column51: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column3: App Store on Display;1/31/2017;"Apple iPhone (Shutterstock photo)Apple (AAPL) is set to report first quarter fiscal 2017 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday. The Cupertino-based tech giant
column4: which has beaten Wall Street earnings per share estimates in two straight quarters
column5: is expected to break its streak of declining revenue at three. And the revenue increase will be driven by the barrage of new products Apple launched in the past three months.Notably
column6: Appleâ€™s iPhone 7 and 7 Plus devices. Beyond the new line of MacBooks and iPads
column7: analysts may get a glimpse of the degree of demand Apple enjoyed for its wireless AirPods
column8: of which CEO Tim Cook in December hinted that Apple couldnâ€™t make them fast enough. Investors are also eager to learn how well Appleâ€™s services business has performed.makeArticleAd();Apple earlier this month disclosed its App Storeexperienced a 40% year-over-year surgein revenue in 2016. Apple says on New Year's day alone
column9: customers spent nearly $240 million on apps and in-app purchases
column10: marking the App Store's largest single-day of sales ever. For that matter
column11: the App Store in December logged its highest-grossing month in its history
column12: generating some $3 billion in revenue. How much of that total trickled to the bottom line during the quarter remains to be seen.The company also said it posted a 74% surge in billings from subscription services like Netflix (NFLX)
column13: popular dating app Tinder and Time Warner's (TWX) HBO Now
column14: reaching to $2.7 billion.Why is all of this important? Apple has increasingly emphasized the cash flow generated from its Services segment. The Services business
column15: which includes the App Store
column16: revenues from Apple Pay and Apple Music
column17: rose 24% in the fourth quarter
column18: posting revenue of $6.3 billion. This was preceded by a 19% rise in the third quarter.In other words
column19: Apple realizes it can not live by iPhones alone. Can it maintain the uptrend? On Tuesday analysts will scrutinize just how much closer Apple is to that reality. But for now
column20: the iPhone remains Appleâ€™s cash cow. And
column21: beyond the headline earnings and revenue numbers
column22: thatâ€™s where the focus will be. Despite fears about longer upgrade cycles
column23: increased competition and slow growth in emerging markets
column24: analysts are generally positive about the recantation the iPhone 7 has received.In the three months that ended December
column25: analysts expect Apple to report earnings per share of $3.23
column26: down from $3.28 in the year-earlier on revenue of revenue of $77.4 billion. This compares to Apple's guidance range of $76 billion to $78 billion when it last reported earnings in October. Analysts expect Apple to have sold 78 million iPhones
column27: which would be a 4% rise from the 75 million sold a year ago.Average selling prices
column28: meanwhile
column29: are projected to be $687 per unit
column30: down $735 a year ago. However
column31: thanks to prospect of higher shipments
column32: iPhone revenues are expected to rise 3% to $53.1 billion. Meanwhile
column33: data compiled by FactSet suggests Services revenue will reach $6.9 billion
column34: up 13% year over year. To the extent Apple can beat on both the top and bottom lines
column35: exceeds iPhone unit salesandprovide confident guidance

column1: Amazon (AMZN) Film Division to Premiere Patriot on Feb 24;1/31/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Amazon.com Inc.'sAMZNfilm production division
column2: Amazon Studios

column4: Patriot

column7: UK
