column12: at no additional cost to prime membership.Over the last one year
column13: shares of Amazon have been steadily treading higher. The stock has returned 44.46% compared with the Electronic Commerce industry's gain of 41.77%.About the SeriesPatriot is based on the life story of intelligence officer John Tavner who makes efforts to prevent Iran from going nuclear. In the story
column14: Tavner will forgo all safety nets and assume a mid-level employee at a Midwestern industrial piping firm to complete his mission. However
column15: the federal government's incompetence and his own day job in an industrial piping company will put his mission in danger.The start cast includes Michael Dorman
column16: Terry O'Quinn

column21: Charles Gogolak and Gil Bellows.Our TakeThe increasing popularity of tablets

column23: like AlphabetGOOGLand Apple Inc.AAPL.Therefore
column24: Amazon is leaving no stone unturned to boost its digital media sales and attract new viewers
column25: by adding varied series and movies to its content lineup and making Prime Video more attractive.With intense competition in online video content
column26: majors such as Netflix
column27: Inc.NFLX
column28: Hulu and HBO
column29: are seeing substantial success. It is natural for Amazon to compete against them with successful acts of its own. These new shows are expected to help Amazon penetrate further into the growing streaming market

column1: 15 Best Short-Term Stock Investments;1/31/2017;"As any stock trader can tell you
column2: the market can be volatile. That's why investment professionals typically recommend investors take a long-term approach to investing to reduce the risk of losing principal. If you invest at the wrong time
column3: you could lose a significant amount of your money overnight
column4: so keep in mind that stocks are not always the best short-term investments.That said
column5: stock prices work both ways. A prudent â€” or lucky â€” investor could make a great deal of money just as rapidly as he could lose it. If you have a tolerance for risk and are willing to do the research
column6: short-term trading might be a solution for at least part of your portfolio.If you decide to go this route
column7: don't hesitate to contact a financial professional if you need assistance. Most important
column8: if you're looking for stocks to buy now
column9: do your homework to find good ones in which to invest. You can begin here with this list of 15 stocks to buy that might be thebest short-term investments for your portfolio.makeArticleAd();1. Apple:AAPLApple is one of the best-known companies in America
column10: thanks in no small part to the iPhone. It's also the largest U.S. company in terms of market capitalization â€” the value of a company that's traded on the stock market â€” a number you can calculate by multiplying a company's stock price by the number of its outstanding shares. In the case of Apple
column11: this number topped $618 billion as of late December 2016
column12: coming in ahead of competitors Alphabet at $548 billion
column13: Microsoft at $494.6 billion
column14: Amazon at $366 billion and Facebook at $343.1 billion.Apple stock is positioned to move even higher in 2017. The company is aggressively buying back stock
column15: which reduces the number of outstanding shares and increases earnings per share. Its latest iPhones
column16: the 7 and 7 Plus
column17: are the best-selling phones in its history. Apple also holds roughly $200 billion in overseas cash
column18: which might move home this year if corporate taxes on repatriation are lowered. To top it all off
column19: the stock is trading at just about 10 times earnings.2. Gilead Sciences:GILDIf you're looking for a short-term stock that had a rough go of it in 2016
column20: Gilead Sciences might be your pick. The biotechnology company's sales of its hepatitis C drug declined and the stock fell 29 percent in 2016.Gilead could turn out to be one of the best stocks for 2017
column21: however. The company trades at the compelling valuation of 6.99 times estimated earnings over the next year. It's bought back 14 percent of its stock over the past three years
column22: and with its $32 billion cash hoard
column23: the company might continue to buy more or make strategic acquisitions. Gilead also uses its cash to pay out a 2.5 percent dividend to shareholders. The stock could very well hit $101 in 2017
column24: according to analysts at JP Morgan.3. Alphabet:GOOGAlphabet
column25: formerly known as Google
column26: is one of the world's great businesses
column27: according to Barron's. The company owns numerous products and services including Google Maps and Google Play
column28: YouTube
column29: Nest
column30: Chrome
column31: Android
column32: and Gmail. Analysts project 2017 revenues for the company in excess of $103 billion
column33: which would represent a growth rate of more than 18 percent.Given the current political climate
column34: Alphabet might see a short-term boost in the form of repatriated cash. The company currently holds about $80 billion in cash overseas
column35: which translates to around $115 per share. Additionally
column36: it has a lot of room for cost cutting because it spends freely on noncore businesses. Some analysts are estimating $41 per share in earnings this year
column37: which would be huge since the company currently trades at just 18 times earnings.4. Facebook:FBEven if you don't use Facebook at home or on your smartphone
column38: it's hard to avoid its presence in store windows or on advertising asking you to ""like"" something. The key to Facebook's financial success is its monetization of its enormous customer base. It has 1.79 billion monthly active users â€” and that number continues to rise. Lately
column39: Facebook's stock price has gone up and exceeded analyst earnings estimates by an average of 21.11 percent.Facebook is still investing in ways to grow its earnings even more
column40: with mobile ads and video revenues currently doing the heavy lifting. The company is also expecting big things out of its virtual reality investments. With a long-term growth rate of 27.6 percent
column41: the company is expected to continue its rise.5. Citigroup:CCitigroup could benefit from a number of factors in 2017
column42: including rising interest rates. TheFederal Reserve raised interest ratesfor just the second time in a decade in 2016. The Fed indicated that it expects to hike rates an additional three times in 2017. In response
column43: the two-year Treasury note hit its highest rate since 2009. When interest rates rise
column44: banks can charge more money on loans and credit cards
column45: potentially increasing their profitability.Citigroup's stock has lagged compared with its peers' so far in 2017
column46: which gives it room to catch up. The stock trades at just about 11 times its expected earnings for next year â€” and it trades at the widest discount-to-book value of the major banks. This means the stock is discounted more than 25 percent compared with the price-earnings ratios of its peers
column47: making it a possible value play.6. IBM:IBMIBM is another turnaround candidate for 2017. The company used to dominate the computer hardware and services business sector but has been surpassed in recent years by its competitors. However
column48: its slow turn toward the more modern businesses of artificial intelligence
column49: cloud computing
column50: mobility and security is showing signs of bearing fruit.The company spent more than $5 billion in acquisitions in 2016 alone
column51: and its new product lines now account for more than 40 percent of firm revenues. Its analytics division showed revenue growth of 16 percent
column52: and its cloud business jumped by 42 percent â€” both hopeful signs for future growth. IBM's artificial intelligence business has generated positive buzz thanks to its Watson cognitive system
column53: which is known for beating two human ""Jeopardy!"" contestants. The stock trades at a 12.19 price-earnings ratio based on expected 2017 earnings.7. Norwegian Cruise Line:NCLHNorwegian Cruise Line is poised to benefit from the rapidly growing cruise segment and could be one of the best stocks to buy now. With the core demographic of aging baby boomers on the rise
column54: cruise lines are a growing market. The company doesn't pay dividends to shareholders but reinvests its cash flow into building more ships and expanding its routes. Norwegian has already won approval to sail to Cuba
column55: and it has repositioned its calendar to deploy ships into the fast-growing Asian market for the first time in 15 years.Norwegian boasts the newest fleet among its major North American competitors
column56: making it attractive to customers looking for the latest and greatest offerings. The company owns a diversified portfolio of maritime brands including Oceania and Regent Seven Seas. Analysts estimate the stock will grow earnings by more than 18 percent in 2017 â€” the stock trades at just 14 times 2017 estimates.8. Amazon:AMZNAmazon has grown from an online bookseller to the eighth-largest retailer in the world
column57: and it hasn't shown any signs of slowing down. Amazon will become the largest apparel seller in the U.S. by 2021
column58: when it will be selling $62 billion in apparel annually â€” more than TJ Maxx and Macy's combined â€” according to analysts at Cowen Group.Amazon is firing on multiple fronts: It's poised to capitalize on streaming media's popularity via its Amazon Prime subscription service. Additionally
column59: its Web Services business is more advanced than competitors Microsoft and Alphabet's cloud offerings
column60: thanks to it being first to market. Analysts at Evercore ISI Institutional Equities cite Amazon as the best internet stock for 2017. Excitement is also brewing over Amazon's latest foray into the grocery business
column61: Amazon Go. In true disruptor fashion
column62: Amazon's take on the grocery store is to use sensors rather than grocery clerks.9. Restoration Hardware:RHRestoration Hardware is a well-known
column63: luxury home furnishings brand that suffered through 2016. Its earnings fell and triggered a stock sell-off in which shares lost more than half their value. However
column64: the company has shown some signs of being a possible candidate for short-term traders. In its most recent quarter
column65: revenue actually rose 3 percent and beat analysts' estimates by more than $20 million. Earnings also beat Wall Street expectations by 4 cents per share.In addition to rebounding sales and earnings
column66: Restoration Hardware conducted an image makeover. Going forward
column67: the company will be called simply ""RH."" Additionally
column68: the company has launched a new
column69: RH Modern line. In an attempt to capitalize on a more current type of revenue stream
column70: RH is now offering annual memberships. As a result
column71: analysts peg the company's five-year earnings growth rate at 20.33 percent
column72: with earnings for the upcoming year jumping 61.27 percent.10. Toll Brothers:TOLToll Brothers is a leading luxury home builder
column73: a business that's been hit hard on many fronts. Although risks remain
column74: the fear of rising interest rates dampening homebuying activity has sent Toll Brothers stock to a bargain price. The company now trades at less than 10 times its anticipated 2017 earnings
column75: which are expected by some to rise 20 percent.Some concerns over the luxury condo market in New York City also hang over the stock
column76: but company reps indicate that earnings will hold up. With the stock seemingly priced for a worst-case scenario
column77: its valuation of about 1.2 times book value is compelling. If housing markets hold firm or interest rates don't rise dramatically
column78: Toll Brothers stock could prove surprising to those anticipating the worst.11. Deutsche Telekom:DTEGYDeutsche Telekom is a German stock that many investors might recognize as the former parent of U.S. T-Mobile. The company still owns a 65 percent stake in the independently traded T-Mobile â€” and that stock has been skyrocketing. Deutsche's core European telecom business trades at a discount compared with its peers â€” it fell by 13 percent in 2016 â€” even though it's the leading wired and wireless operator in Germany. Sporting a nearly 4 percent yield
column79: some analysts describe the stock as undervalued.A takeover play might happen in 2017: Comcast has had its eye on T-Mobile as a potential purchase. T-Mobile might also make another attempt to merge with Sprint
column80: which could end up being a catalyst for Deutsche's stock. If everything falls into place
column81: a share price of $20 isn't inconceivable.12. Sprouts Farmers Market:SFMSprouts Farmers Market flies under the radar of many investors because it's not really a headline-making stock. This lack of publicity might work to its advantage
column82: however
column83: as more investors become aware of its potential. Sprouts is drawing customers from the growing natural and organic food segment â€” and it prices its goods below that of its notable peer
column84: Whole Foods Market. As a result
column85: some analysts see the company generating mid-teens earnings and revenue growth in the foreseeable future.The company is growing out of its base in the American Southwest and moving east
column86: growing 14 percent in square footage every year. Coupled with its favorable market segments
column87: Sprouts is generating positive cash flow and returning cash to shareholders via a stock buyback program. At 20.5 times estimated 2017 earnings
column88: the stock could be ready to move.13. Delta Air Lines:DALDelta Air Lines has greatly improved its financial performance but still trades at a typical airline multiple of about nine times estimated 2017 earnings. Since 2009
column89: Delta has worked to cut its debt in half. As a result
column90: it now has an investment grade rating from independent ratings service Moody's. To further entice shareholders
column91: Delta pays a 1.7 percent dividend and has aggressively repurchased stock.Delta management feels the stock should be valued more like a diversified industrial company
column92: which would dramatically raise its multiple
column93: and
column94: therefore
column95: its share price. If you need another short-term catalyst
column96: look at the company's free cash flow. Delta is a cash-flow machine â€” it generated $4.1 billion in cash flow in the last 12 months alone and put just 9.8 percent of that into dividend payments
column97: according to Forbes.14. Novartis:NVTSAnother value play for 2017 could be Novartis
column98: a Swiss diversified drug company and the world's biggest prescription drugmaker. The company's share price had a difficult 2016 but now trades at about 15 times next year's earnings. With a yield of about 3.75 percent
column99: Novartis has an analyst consensus price target of $87
column100: some $15 north of its current price.Part of what held Novartis back in 2016 was fear over the slow start of Entresto
column101: its heart-failure drug
column102: but some analysts think sales will soon accelerate and could go as high as $3 billion. Novartis also gets 25 percent of its sales from high-growth
column104: which makes it less dependent on the more mature U.S. drug market. The company's recent purchase of Encore Vision should also shore up its vision sales and further enable it to diversify its holdings.15. General Motors:GMGeneral Motors has been an integral part of the global auto industry for more than 100 years and has recently faced headwinds. Some market participants feel that global auto sales have peaked
column105: and concerns over themovement to electric vehicleshave held back GM stock. Whatever the reasons are
column106: General Motors currently trades at a low price-to-earnings ratio of 4.3. Even industry competitors â€” like Ford
column107: which trades at a ratio of 6.6
column109: which trades at 9.7 times â€” trade at higher multiples
column110: and GM's average price-earnings ratio over the past five years is 12.2.GM could move higher as the market appreciates its emerging electric and hybrid portfolio. Some analysts feel GM has the bankroll and technology to undersell rivals such as Tesla and perhaps even compete on quality at some point. GM stock began rallying at the end of 2016
column111: which leads some analysts to predict it could double in price over the next one or two years.Data is accurate as of Jan. 25

column1: 3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 Earnings;1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEven ifApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) weren't the biggest company in the world (as measured by market cap)
column3: its quarterly earnings reports would still arguably be the most-watched reports for any given earnings seasons. Not only are a wide swath of many other companies linked to Apple's success
column4: but AAPL stock itself is something of a barometer for the broad market.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleYet
column5: the last few quarterly earnings announcements have also raised questions
column6: not the least of which is whether or not iPhone-mania has run its course. The growth pace has been undeniably tapering off.That's going to be the hot button on Tuesday
column7: after the close
column8: when the Apple earnings report for its fiscal first quarter is due.Apple Earnings PreviewAs of the most recent look
column9: Apple isexpected to post earnings of $3.22 per shareon revenue of $77.42 billion for the quarter ending in December. The company itself had guided for Q1 revenue of between $77 and $78 billion. That bottom line would be a tad lower than the $3.28 per share of AAPL stock reported for the same quarter a year earlier
column10: though the top line would be up just a bit from the prior year's first fiscal quarter tally of $75.87 billion.Apple needs a strong showing on Tuesday. Although it has been a strong growth machine since unveiling the first iPhone a little over a decade ago
column11: per-share profits have been lower on a year-over-year basis in each of the prior three quarters. Ditto for revenue.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatAAPL stock investors have been patient thus far
column12: giving CEO Tim Cook time to adjust to a maturing market. A shortfall and/or another quarter of shrinking numbers
column13: however
column14: may push those traders' patience over the edge.3 Things to Watch for AAPLNot that Apple doesn't have a myriad of things going on at any given time
column15: but for the most part
column16: investors tend to focus on what they perceive as the biggest three. The three items that will be doing most of the driving for AAPL stock after Tuesday's report are (in no particular order)â€¦iPhone 7 salesIt's the 800-pound gorilla in the room. Strong sales of the company's flagship device can cure all other ills
column17: but if sales of the company's most recent iteration of the iPhone fall short
column18: little else matters.Expectations are widely varied on this front too. Cowen & Co.thinks Apple sold 58.5 million units of the iPhone 7 last quarter
column19: while Drexel Hamilton believes Applesold 76 million iPhones- not just the iPhone 7 - during its fiscal Q1. The overall consensus
column20: though
column21: isan average of 77.3 million units. Presumably most of those are the 7 and 7 Plus models.Apps and Digital ContentWhile Apple used to be a hardware company that also happened to facilitate the purchase of smartphone apps
column22: music and video media
column23: digital content is increasingly becomingan important part of the revenue mixas saturation becomes a real issue.The company doesn't offer much in the way of expectations for how its revenue breaks down
column24: but we do know that in the previous quarter
column25: Apple enjoyed revenue of $6.3 billion for its ""Services"" division
column26: which is mostly made up of its video
column27: audio and apps arms. That was a 24% year-over-year improvement. That makes it thesecond-biggest category of product for Apple
column28: though it's still well behind the biggest - the iPhone.Facebook Inc (FB) Stock: New All-Time Highs or New Problems?AAPL is even mulling the creation ofits own original television shows and movies
column29: following in the footsteps of on-demand video rivalsNetflix
column30: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) andAmazon.com
column31: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).Donald Trump AgendaIt remains to be seen to what extent
column32: if any
column33: it will be discussed within the Apple earnings report and conference call. Maybe it won't come up at all
column34: but there's no denying AAPL is one of the more vulnerable companies to President Donald Trump's policy plans.Not only might a strict foreign worker and immigration policy limit Apple's access to technical talent
column35: but much-discussed tariffs on Chinese-made imports could start a trade war that leaves Apple right in the middle of it. Not only does Apple sell products to Chinese consumers
column36: it relies on China to make many of the iPhone's key components.Bottom Line for AAPL StockWith a trailing P/E of 14.5
column37: Apple shares are priced fairly â€¦ maybe even undervalued. That's apt to be a large part of the reason the pros are collectively rating AAPL a bit better than a ""Buy"" right now (leaning toward a ""Strong buy."") That optimism
column38: though
column39: is a bit suspicious in light of the lackluster results we've seen for the prior three quarters. Apple is going to have to outperform most expectations if the stock's to build any further on the 34% gain it has mustered since May of last year.As of this writing
column40: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still Bargains7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeThe post3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 Earningsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Isn't Qualcomm's Pain Intel's Gain?;1/30/2017;"Shares ofQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) recently plunged to a multi-month low after the   chipmaker was hit by an FTCantitrust lawsuitin the U.S. andadditional lawsuitsfrom its longtime customerApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . Apple
column2: which exclusively used Qualcomm's   baseband modems in its iPhones between 2011 and 2016
column3: claims that   Qualcomm withheld $1 billion in rebate payments (compensation for   that deal) after it cooperated with Korean FTC regulators
column4: which   were probing Qualcomm.Image source: Qualcomm.makeArticleAd();This strained relationship between the two tech giants sounds   like great news forIntel(NASDAQ: INTC)
column5: which started supplying Apple with modems for   the iPhone 7 after its exclusive deal with Qualcomm ended. The   reason is simple -- Apple could potentially buy all of its modems   from Intel if it severs its relationship with Qualcomm.But Intel shares barely budged after Apple sued Qualcomm
column6: and   only recently rallied following its fourth quarter earnings beat.   Let's take a closer look at why investors don't seem convinced   that Qualcomm's pain can generate significant gains for   Intel.Understanding Intel's mobile strategyIntel doesn't report its modem sales separately. They're   included in its massive Client Computing Group
column7: which includes PC   and mobile chips. The group was created in 2015 to divert   attention from the ongoing losses at its mobile division
column8: which   previously reported its results separately. Those losses were   caused by its generous subsidization of OEMs
column9: with co-marketing   agreements
column10: steep discounts
column11: and financial aid for using its   mobile Atom chipsets.By the timeIntel killed offmost of its mobile Atom chips last year
column12: the unit had spent   billions of dollars to capture just 1% of the market. Intel's   fatal mistakes are easy to see in retrospect -- it sold off its   ARM-based Xscale unit in 2006 to focus on x86 chips in 2006
column13: then   rejected Apple's offer to produce application processors for the   first iPhone.Since much of the Android market uses Qualcomm SoCs
column14: which   bundle baseband modems together with ARM-based processors
column15: Intel   realized that the Atom couldn't gain much ground in the mobile   market. Instead
column16: it had to develop modems for OEMs like Apple
column17: which developed their own ARM-based processors without integrated   modems.Image source: Apple.Why Intel investors aren't excitedThe problem with Intel is that it was likely negotiating terms   with Apple from a position of weakness
column18: due to its need to stay   relevant in the mobile market. Since Intel has a long record of   taking losses to gain market share in the mobile market
column19: it's   reasonable to assume that Intel sold its modems to Apple at very   favorable prices for the hardware maker.Last year
column20: Cowen & Co. analysts estimated that the deal   could  generate $1.5 billion in revenues for Intel -- which   would only equal 2.5% of its projected revenues this year. Even   if Apple dropped Qualcomm and doubled its orders from Intel
column21: that   growth wouldn't significantly offset Intel's sluggish growth in   PC and data center chips. Moreover
column22: those modems would likely   only generate low-margin revenues
column23: which wouldn't significantly   boost its bottom line growth.To make matters worse
column24: Apple throttled the speed of    Qualcomm modems in the iPhone 7 to match the slower speed   of the Intel modems. This indicates that Apple didn't choose   Intel chips because they could match Qualcomm's -- it likely only   did so to reduce Qualcomm's negotiating power. This means that   other OEMs that use stand-alone Qualcomm modems won't likely   switch over to Intel modems anytime soon. This misstep mirrors   Intel's failure in mobile application processors -- several OEMs   initially gave the Atom a chance
column25: but it was doomed by its   inability to match the power efficiency of ARM-based designs.What Intel investors should expectIntel investors shouldn't assume that Apple's battle with   Qualcomm indicates that the two longtime partners will part ways   anytime soon. Apple andSamsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) have been suing each other for years
column26: yet the   Korean tech giant is still one of its top suppliers. Therefore
column27: Apple is likely trying to get Qualcomm to lower its chip prices   and licensing fees instead of completely parting ways with the   chipmaker.Even if Apple abandoned Qualcomm
column28: investors shouldn't assume   that Intel will inherit the entire modem business. Apple often   splits component orders from multiple manufacturers
column29: and it has   enough resources to develop its own modems -- which would cut   both Intel and Qualcomm out of the loop.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column30: it can pay to listen. After all
column31: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: How Much Can Apple's Services Drive Profit Growth?;1/30/2017;"Image source: Apple.Much has been made ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) services revenue over the last year or so. After   it was clear Apple would struggle to continue growing iPhone   sales following the outstanding success of the iPhone 6
column2: CEO Tim   Cook commented that a ""growing portion of our revenue is directly   driven by our existing install base."" That is
column3: sales of apps
column4: content
column5: iCloud
column6: Apple Care
column7: and other Apple Services will   account for an outsized portion of Apple's revenue growth going   forward.makeArticleAd();To be clear
column8: Apple is still very much a hardware company.   Apple's services revenue accounted for just 11% of Apple's total   sales in fiscal 2016. The iPhone
column9: by comparison
column10: made up 63% of   revenue. But services revenue grew 22% last year
column11: faster than any   other segment.With stalling hardware sales growth
column12: investors may be   wondering if growing services revenue is enough to move the   needle on Apple's bottom line.All about the marginsDespite its relatively small size
column13: Apple's services business   generates higher margins than its hardware sales. That's simply   the nature of software
column14: which sees wider margins as products   reach scale. And very few companies have the scale of Apple; the   company has over 1 billion devices in use.Apple's App Store sales have a gross margin of about 90%
column15: according to estimates from Macquarie Securities analyst Ben   Schachter. Overall
column16: he estimates the rest of Apple's services   have a gross margin of 65%. That means Apple's services revenue   has a gross margin about twice as large as its hardware   sales.Importantly
column17: the App Store -- Apple's highest-margin product   -- is one of the fastest-growing pieces of Apple's services. Last   year
column18: App Store revenueclimbed over 33%. Schachter expects it to climb 28% on average over the next five   years while non-App Store services grow just 10% annually. That   means Apple's services margin will continue to expand.How it all impacts Apple's gross profitEven if hardware sales remain flat
column19: that won't prevent Apple   from expanding its install base. As Cook mentioned in the   company's first-quarter earnings call last year
column20: ""Because of the   enduring value of the device
column21: their replacing is likely higher to   be given or sold to someone who will also love and use it often.""   In other words
column22: even if Apple isn't selling more devices directly   to consumers
column23: the user base can grow through third-party resales   or gifting.A growing user base combined with growing service sales per   unit ought to continue driving revenue growth for the segment for   several more years.A dollar in sales growth from services will carry twice the   gross profit
column24: on average
column25: as a dollar in sales growth of Apple's   hardware. So
column26: even though services is a relatively small business   right now
column27: it outpunches its weight class
column28: providing   approximately 21% of gross profits in 2016. That number is set to   expand as more of Apple's sales growth comes from services.As an illustration of the impact of Apple's service revenue   growth
column29: a 20% increase in services revenue in fiscal 2017 would   result in about a 4% increase in the company's total gross profit   and a 70 basis point expansion in gross margin if all else   remains equal. Considering the size of Apple
column30: that's pretty   significant growth. Schachter estimates Apple's gross margin will   expand as much as 400 basis points over the next five years.Gross margin expansion combined with modest revenue growth and   share buybacks should continue to boost Apple's earnings per   share at a fairly steady pace. Analysts expect 13.8% EPS growth   over the next five years
column31: but there could be even more upside   depending on how much margins expand. With shares trading at a   price-to-earnings ratio of just 14.4
column32: shares may still be   undervalued if Apple can maintain hardware sales and continue   growing services revenue as expected.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column33: it can pay to listen. After all
column34: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: Is the Bar Higher for the Q4 Earnings Season?;1/30/2017;"Even as Earnings growth appears to have improved notably relative to the last couple of years
column2: positive surprises appear hard to come to by. This becomes evident from looking at the proportion of companies beating EPS and revenue estimates in the ongoing Q4 earnings season. You can see that in the comparison chart below that compares the proportion of Q4 companies beating EPS and revenue estimates with what this same group of companies reported in the preceding quarter
column3: as well as the 4-quarter and 12-quarter averages.With results from 171 S&P 500 index members already out or 34.1% of the index's total membership
column4: positive surprises are tracking below historical periods
column5: particularly with respect to EPS surprises. If we see this trend continue in the coming days as the rest of Q4 reports come in
column6: then it would mean that estimates likely hadn't dropped enough ahead of the start of this earnings season. In other words
column7: the bar may have been bit higher this time around relative to other recent quarters.makeArticleAd();With respect to the Q4 earnings season scorecard
column8: we now have results from 171 S&P 500 members that have reported as of January 30th. Total earnings for these 171 index members are up +6% from the same period last year on +3.1% higher revenues
column9: with 64.3% beating EPS estimates and 54.4% beating revenue estimates. We discussed earlier how the proportion of companies beating EPS and revenue estimates has been tracking below historical periods. But we don't have that issue on the growth front
column10: with both earnings and revenue growth tracking above other historical periods for the same group of 171 index members.The chart below shows how the Q4 earnings and revenue growth rate for these 171 companies compare with other recent periods.The Finance sector is a big contributor to the aggregate growth picture at this stage. For the Finance sector
column11: we now have Q4 results from 57.9% of the sector's total market cap in the S&P 500 index. Total earnings for these Finance sector companies are up +11.3% from the same period last year on +3.1% higher revenues
column12: with 67.5% beating EPS estimates and 45% beating revenue estimates. Excluding the Finance sector from the results thus far
column13: total earnings for the rest of the S&P 500 companies that have reported would be up +3.9% from the same period last year on +3% higher revenues. This is still better growth than we have seen from the same group of ex-Finance S&P 500 members
column14: as the comparison chart below shows.Looking at Q4 as a whole
column15: combining the actual results from the 171 index members that have reported results with estimates from the still-to-come 329 companies
column16: total earnings for the S&P 500 index are expected to be up +5.3% from the same period last year on +4% higher revenues. Excluding the Finance sector
column17: the Q4 earnings growth drops to +1% on +4.2% higher revenues.For the Technology sector
column18: total Q4 earnings are expected to be up +5.9% from the same period last year on +4.4% higher revenues.Apple(AAPL)
column19: which alone brings in roughly a quarter of the sector's total earnings
column20: is expected to report -7.8% lower earnings on +0.4% higher revenues as it comes out with its quarterly results after the close on Tuesday January 31st. Excluding the Apple drag
column21: total Q4 earnings for the rest of the Tech sector would be up +11.4% on +5.5% higher revenues.Facebook(FB)
column22: which reports after the market's close on Wednesday February 1st
column23: doesn't carry as much weight in the sector as the iPhone maker. But Facebook's Q4 earnings are expected to be up +91% from the same period last year on +44.5% higher revenues.Amazon(AMZN) isn't technically a Technology stock (it's a retailer)
column24: but it is also expected to show strong growth in its quarterly report that comes out after the close on Thursday February 2nd.Looking beyond Q4
column25: the growth pace is expected to ramp up notably in the current and following quarters
column26: as the chart below shows.As you can see
column27: total 2017 Q1 earnings for the S&P 500 index are currently expected to be up +8.7% from the same period last year. The chart below shows Q1 earnings growth expectations have evolved over the last few weeks.It is not unusual for 2017 Q1 estimates to be coming down at this stage of the 2016 Q4 reporting cycle
column28: but a lot will depend on the pace and magnitude of these negative revisions in the coming days. At this stage
column29: Q1 estimates aren't falling by as much as has historically been the case. This should add to confidence in market expectations for the following quarters when growth is expected to really ramp up.Note: Note: Sheraz Mian regularly provides earnings analysis on Zacks.com and appears frequently in the print and electronic media. His weekly earnings related articles includeEarnings TrendsandEarnings Preview. If you want an email notification each time Sheraz publishes a new article

column1: 3 Stocks That Could Move Big This Week;1/30/2017;"This week
column2: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column3: Facebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column4: andAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) are all scheduled to report results for their most   recently ended quarter
column5: making this one of the most interesting   weeks of this earnings season. With Apple on deck
column6: here's why   these stocks could be big movers.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Searching for growthScheduled to report results for its fiscal first-quarter of   2017 on Tuesday
column7: Jan. 31
column8: investors will likely be watching a   number of key items closely. But Apple's top line for the current   quarter
column9: and the company's guidance for revenue in its second   fiscal quarter of 2017
column10: will likely be the main drivers behind   any moves in the stock price after the results go live.For its first quarter
column11: Apple guided for revenue of $76 billion   to $78 billion
column12: up from $75.9 billion in the year-ago quarter.   Investors will be looking for Apple to meet or exceed its   guidance range
column13: particularly since Apple has reported   year-over-year revenue declines in the last three quarters.   Revenue in this range would mark an all-time high for the   company.For Apple's second-quarter revenue guidance
column14: the number for   Apple to beat will be its fiscal second-quarter revenue in 2016   of $50.6 billion. Anything less than this figure would mean the   tech giant expects to return to year-over-year decline.Can this tech giant keep up its momentum?For Facebook's fourth-quarter earnings release on Wednesday
column15: Feb. 1
column16: investors will also likely be honing in on the company's   reported revenue
column17: though expectations for Facebook's growth are   far more optimistic than what investors expect from Apple these   days. While it's unrealistic to expect Facebook to report the   same 56% year-over-year revenue growth it reported in Q3 given   the company's tough year-ago comparison of 44% year-over-year   revenue growth
column18: investors will likely look for any deceleration   in revenue growth to be modest. I'll be looking for   fourth-quarter revenue growth of about 45%.Image source: Amazon.Beyond Facebook's revenue growth
column19: another area that could move   the stock is the company's reported user metrics. While any   surprises on user metrics are unlikely considering the company's   consistent upward march in monthly active users and user   engagement
column20: a sudden pullback in user growth or engagement could   spook some investors. Investors should look for the social   network's monthly active users to increase about three to four   percent sequentially and its user engagement
column21: or daily active   users as a percentage of monthly active users
column22: to be 66% or   better -- figures that would maintain recent user performance   trends.Can holiday sales live up to big expectations?Going into Amazon's Feb. 2 fourth-quarter report
column23: management   didn't provide a very narrow guidance range for expected revenue   growth. Amazon said it expected revenue to increase anywhere   between 17% to 27% year over year. column1: 3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great Recession;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTheS&P 500has more than tripled since it hit its low point of the Great Recession on March 9
column3: 2009. There were plenty of stocks to buy back then that offered incredible value. For investors that weren't old enough or didn't have the resources to invest back then
column4: it may seem like you've missed the boat. After all
column5: the old investing adage is to buy low and sell high.makeArticleAd();Source:PixabayAlmost every stock worth owning has a much higher share price now than it did on the day the S&P 500 bottomed in 2009
column6: but just because share prices were lower back in 2009 doesn't necessarily mean that buyers were getting a better deal.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatAs the stock market has risen
column7: so have corporate earnings. Even though investors are now paying more for each share of stock
column8: they are also getting more earnings bang for their buck. Here's a look at three stocks that are a better value today than they were on March 9
column9: 2009.Stocks to Buy: Goldman Sachs Group Inc (GS)Source:Erik DrostGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS) was right in the eye of the Great Recession storm. The company even received a $10 billion bailout from the government during the meltdown.In the years since the crisis
column10: new regulations and capital requirements severely hindered bank earnings. For GS stock
column11: the heaviest weight has been the Volcker Rule. The Volcker Rule is a provision in the Dodd-Frank Act that prevents banks from performing certain types of speculative trading.Despite the regulatory headwinds
column12: GS has found a way to ramp up its earnings in recent years. Goldman's net income is up more than 180% since 2009
column13: making GS stock an even better value today than it was back then. Goldman's current price-to-earnings ratio is only 14.2
column14: 19% lower than it was on March 9
column15: 2009.Looking ahead
column16: Donald Trump has pledged to eliminate many of the regulations that have been holding back the big banks. Goldman stock is in an even better position and it is a better value today than it was in the years following the Great Recession.Stocks to Buy: Visa Inc (V)Source:K rlis Dambr ns via FlickrThe market forVisa Inc(NYSE:V) is dramatically changing. While mobile competition fromPayPal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ:PYPL)
column17: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) and others may certainly disrupt the traditional payment business
column18: Visa should be just fine. A recentBI Intelligencereport concluded that merchant service providers (MSPs) are much more threatened by mobile payment competition than the credit card companies themselves.The proof is in the pudding. Even with the emergence of platforms like Apple Pay
column19: Visa's profits have exploded more than 400% since 2009. BMO Capital analystPaulo Ribeiroexpects Visa's double-digit earnings growth to continue in the long-term. He believes V stock will continue to benefit from the slow death of cash and check payments.7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeEven though V stock has been a top performer in the market since the Great Recession
column20: that incredible earnings growth means Visa's P/E ratio is down 60% from where it was when the market bottomed in 2009. In other words
column21: V stock is a much better value today than it was back then.Stocks to Buy: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. ( BRK.B)Source:Pete Souza via Wikimedia (Modified)If you're looking for stocks to buy in the market today that would make 2009 investors envious
column22: it doesn't get much better thanBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column23: NYSE:BRK.B). The holding company of the most iconic and successful value investor of all time is currently trading at a better value than it was during the Great Recession.Warren Buffett's BRK.B stock now has a P/E of 17
column24: which is down roughly 21% since March 9
column25: 2009. Buffett and Berkshire have done very well since the Great Recession. But thanks to BRK.B's 823% income growth
column26: investors now get a better value for Berkshire shares than they did at the market bottom.If anyone can find value in the stock market after it climbs 235% in eight years
column27: it's the Oracle of Omaha. Instead of losing sleep over stocks to buy with the market at an all-time high
column28: why not just invest in Buffett? Unlike high school
column29: there's no penalty for cheating off of the smart kid's paper.As of this writing
column30: Wayne Duggan did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.The post3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great Recessionappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc. Gets Extra Help From the Dual Camera iPhone 7 Plus (AAPL);1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) first introduced its new
column3: big and bigger smartphones - the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus - the company opted to offer a few minor features for buyers of the largest model. The 6 Plus had longer battery life
column4: and an image stabilized camera. That basic strategy continued with the 6s Plus in 2015. But last year with the iPhone 7 Plus
column5: AAPL included a more significant carrot in the signature Dual Camera feature.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleThe move of making a key feature exclusive to its larger phones appears to have paid off with a big increase in iPhone 7 Plus sales compared to regular iPhone 7 sales.Having more of the costlier iPhone 7 Plus models in the mix means AAPL can generate more revenue
column6: even if overall unit sales are soft.Differentiating Between Big and BiggerHistorically
column7: the larger-sized iPhone hasn't sold nearly as well as the ""standard"" 4.7-inch model.When AAPL first introduced the two model strategy in 2014
column8: the iPhone 6 Plus had an immediate bump in demand from Apple fans who were hungry for a phablet. It was also very popular in Asian markets
column9: where phablets
column10: which can take the place of both smartphone and tablet
column11: are often preferred. However
column12: overall the bigger and more expensive iPhone 6 Plus only accounted foraround 20% of overall iPhone salesglobally.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatIn 2015
column13: AAPL added a little more appeal to the bigger iPhone
column14: adding increased RAM to the optically image stabilized camera for the iPhone 6 Plus. However
column15: that saw just a small uptick in sales of the bigger model.Last year
column16: Apple rolled the dice: It decided to release a dual camera smartphone
column17: a premium upgrade that it heavily promoted as a must-have feature. With this advanced camera system
column18: users could take DSLR-like portraits and optically zoom in on subjects. AAPL made this key feature an iPhone 7 Plus exclusive
column19: at the same time boosting the price of its larger iPhone. Previously
column20: it had charged $649 and $749 respectively for the two sizes. In 2016
column21: the company still started the iPhone 7 at $649
column22: but to get the dual camera smartphone feature required shelling out at least $769 for the iPhone 7 Plus.iPhone 7 Sales See Big Increase in iPhone 7 Plus AdoptionTheWall Street Journalis reporting that Apple's iPhone 7 Plus strategy appears to have paid off. Citing numbers from Cowen & Co. UBS
column23: Cowen and Creative Strategies Inc.
column24: theWSJsays that in AAPL's first quarter (ending in December)
column25: theiPhone 7 Plus is estimated to have accounted for 40% of total iPhone 7 sales
column26: globally.Breaking the numbers down regionally
column27: it's estimated that 52% of Chinese iPhone buyers opted for the more expensive iPhone 7 Plus
column28: while in the U.S. it accounted for 47% of total iPhone 7 sales.Why Increased iPhone 7 Plus to iPhone 7 Sales MatterThe difference between the two iPhone models is material to AAPL's bottom line.Apple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party (AAPL)It's likely that the iPhone 7 Plus costs Apple more to manufacture than previous Plus versions - it does have more RAM
column29: a larger battery and that dual camera system - but at least some of the additional cost is offset by the boost from $749 to $769.The profit margin for Apple on the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus probably remains roughly the same. However
column30: with a base price that's $120 higher
column31: having more Plus models in the mix means that even if overall iPhone 7 sales are soft
column32: the average selling price of a new iPhone goes up. As a result
column33: iPhone revenue could get a boost
column34: despite sales that may not meet expectations.And
column35: as theWSJarticle points out
column36: there's another positive point for AAPL in the iPhone 7 Plus numbers. The fact that pricing the iPhone 7 Plus so high still resulted in big gains for the premium smartphone bodes well for later this year when the company will release the10th anniversary iPhone 8. The iPhone 7 sales numbers indicate that AAPL has additional room to price the iPhone 8 as an ultra-premium
column37: special edition model if it chooses.As of this writing
column38: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in 2017Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postApple Inc. Gets Extra Help From the Dual Camera iPhone 7 Plus (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Monday Apple Rumors: AAPL Is Taking Down Apps from Iranian Developers;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of apps from Iranian developers being taken down. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Monday.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleIranian Apps:Apple has started taking down apps from the App Store that are made by developers in Iran
column4: AppleInsidernotes. The tech company doesn't operate an App Store in Iran
column5: but it has been allowing citizens in the country to use the American version of the app. This resulted in several apps from Iranian developers making it onto the American App Store. However
column6: the company is now pulling those apps from the App Store. This is likely due to Iranian Transactions Sanctions Regulations (31CFR Part 560)
column7: which limits trade with the country.watchOS 3.2 Beta:AAPL is now letting developers play with the first watchOS 3.2 beta
column8: reportsMacRumors. This new beta includes features that will likely be coming to the device when watchOS 3.2 gets a final release. The beta includes the new Theater mode that previous patch notes from AAPL have mentioned. This feature silences the device for movie watch. It also includes SiriKit
column9: which lets users have Siri perform tasks without taking out their connected iPhone devices.UltraFine Display:There are problems with the new LG UltraFine 5K Display that Apple recommends to MacBook Pro users
column10: 9to5Macnotes. The problem affecting the LG UltraFine 5K Display has to do with routers. When the device is within a 2 meters of a router
column11: it will become unstable. This problem can cause the display to flicker and not work properly. AAPL andLGworked together on the monitor. LG is aware of the issue and is advising customers not to use the displays within 2 meters of a router.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postMonday Apple Rumors: AAPL Is Taking Down Apps from Iranian Developersappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Earnings Reports You Need to Watch This Week;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe markets started last week off hot
column3: but ended with a couple slight down days thanks to the one-two punch of not-so-hot corporate earnings and worse-than-expected GDP growth.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockStill
column4: despite the softness
column5: theS&P 500has enjoyed a more or less steady upward trend over the past year or so
column6: tallying around 20% gains over the past 12 months. And there are plenty of individual stocks that could break the downtrend.For instance
column7: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column8: Advanced Micro Devices
column9: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) andUnder Armour Inc(NYSE:UAA) are all reporting their latest quarterly numbers this week - and all investors should be paying attention.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatLet's take a look at what's in store for these picks.Earnings to Watch:Apple (AAPL)Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrApple
column10: which has more or less risen in tandem with the S&P 500 over the past year
column11: will report earnings on Tuesday after the market close.The tech giant is looking to notch its third straight earnings beat-although a beat would still translate to an earnings decline. Wall Street is expecting $3.22 per share compared to last year's $3.28 per share
column12: and that fall is despite expectations for a slight uptick in revenue.Apple has suffered several straight quarters of falling sales
column13: but analysts expect a strong holiday season driven by the iPhone 7 to return the company to organic growth. Even if that growth is meager and earnings shrink slightly
column14: I expect investors to be pleased.Remember
column15: Apple is no longer the growth darling it once was. But 20% gains over the last year plus a solid dividend make a pretty strong case for the stock. I think investors will be reminded of the new Apple's appeal when earnings are released tomorrow.Earnings to Watch:Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrAdvanced Micro Devices is another company that doesn't have too much growth in its near-term forecast despite sales growth. Oftentimes
column16: companies fail to grow sales
column17: but still manage to grow earnings thanks to cost savings or accounting tricks.But in the case of AMD
column18: the loss per share is expected to be a penny worse than it was a year ago due to higher costs and despite double-digit sales growth.The pain isn't expected to end after this quarter either; the full-year earnings forecast is also in the red. But I do like AMD's long-term prospects
column19: as it's introduced new products and inked new partnerships and deals
column20: including one withAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column21: NASDAQ:GOOGL.7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayIf AMD happens to get battered after its earnings report Tuesday
column22: I wouldn't hesitate to buy some shares on the cheap.Earnings to Watch:Under Armour (UAA)Source: ShutterstockUnder Armour is the only stock on this list that has earnings growth on-tap for the current quarter. And while the 4% growth Wall Street expects isn't that mind-blowing
column23: it's a fraction of the growth that's expected down the road.Full-year earnings are expected to enjoy 13% year-over-year growth
column24: while the five-year average is expected to top 20%. Meanwhile
column25: sales growth is also expected to come in north of 20% and stay there in quarters to come.So far
column26: UAA stock has been battling some headwinds: Shares are currently right at their 50-day moving average and are under the 200-day. A good earnings report could be the catalyst needed to turn that long-term average to a floor instead of a ceiling.Under Armour stock also reports on Tuesday.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column28: High Octane Trader

column30: equity research
column31: trading
column32: and risk management. She has extensive expertise in global financial management
column33: asset allocation
column34: investment banking and private equity ventures
column35: and is regularly sought after to provide her analysis on Bloomberg
column36: CNBC
column37: Fox Business Network and other media.The post3 Earnings Reports You Need to Watch This Weekappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: What to Expect When Cirrus Logic Inc. Reports Earnings This Wednesday;1/30/2017;"Image Source: Cirrus LogicWhen audio codec supplierCirrus Logic(NASDAQ: CRUS) releases its fiscal 2017 third quarter results on   Feb. 1
column2: investors can expect another period of rapid growth from   the company. Cirrus Logic has benefited fromApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) decision to remove the headphone jack from the   latest generation of iPhones
column3: leading to strong sales of its   wireless headset solutions. This should drive a strong quarterly   performance at Cirrus
column4: but the company's over-dependence on Apple   for 78% of its revenue could be a deal-breaker as far as the   broad investor outlook is concerned.makeArticleAd();Apple will drive strong growth for Cirrus in the third     quarter . . .Cirrus expects to post third quarter revenue of $475 million   to $515 million with a gross margin of 48%. The midpoint of this   guidance puts its year-over-year growth at an impressive 42%
column5: which is not surprising given the content gains that Cirrus has   witnessed in the iPhone 7.A teardown of the latest smartphone by Chipworks revealed that   the device uses three audio amplifiers from Cirrus
column6: as compared   to two in the iPhone 6S. Now
column7: the actual device is not the only   place where Cirrus is going to make money. iFixit's X-ray of the   Lightning-to-3.5mm adapter
column8: used to connect legacy headphones to   the iPhone 7
column9: reveals the presence of audio codecs from Cirrus as   well.What's more
column10: Cirrus has also supplied digital-to-analog   converter chips for the Lightning EarPods
column11: according to a   teardown of the device by the Vietnamese site Tinhte. All of this   indicates that Cirrus has received a serious bump in its chip   content at Apple. In fact
column12: Pacific Crest Securities forecasts   additional content gains of $2.50 for Cirrus Logic with the   iPhone 7
column13: including the Lightning EarPods and the second stereo   speaker.Encouraged by the booming business
column14: Cirrus seems to have   directed most of its manufacturing capacity toward making chips   for the iPhone and related accessories. This is why revenue from   its largest customer shot up to 78% of total sales in the July to   September quarter
column15: when iPhone production was being ramped up
column16: as   compared to 63% in the year-ago period.iPhone orders from suppliers for the December quarter   reportedly stood at 89 million units. Now
column17: the iPhone 7 and 7   Plus won't account for 100% of Apple's device sales. To provide   some perspective
column18: sales of these two models reportedly made up   72% of total iPhone sales in the U.S. in the fourth quarter
column19: according to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners.Assuming that 72% of the 89 million iPhone unit orders Apple   placed in the fourth quarter were for the two new devices
column20: that   would account for approximately 64 million units. Multiplying   this estimated unit count by additional content gains of $2.50   for each device
column21: Cirrus revenue would increase by $160 million   from the prior-year period when it reported total revenue of $348   million.This alone puts Cirrus revenue at about $508 million for the   fiscal third quarter
column22: which falls at the higher end of its   guidance range. But apart from the dollar content gains
column23: Cirrus will also benefit from the production of an additional   nine million iPhone units as compared to the Dec. 2015 quarter
column24: when estimated volume stood at 80 million. Therefore
column25: Cirrus is   poised to outperform even the higher end of its guidance   range.. . . but hurt its longer term outlookHowever
column26: Cirrus Logic's outlook could prove to be a problem as   iPhone production in the first calendar quarter of 2017 is   expected to decline to about 42 million units
column27: as indicated by aUBSreport. Earlier
column28: Apple was expected to produce 43 million iPhones   during the period
column29: but it has reportedly downsized production in   order to avoid an inventory glut.Assuming the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus maintain a 72% share of   overall production
column30: these two devices will account for   approximately 30 million units in the current quarter. With the   $2.50 per unit of additional content
column31: the new devices will add   $75 million to Cirrus' top line in the fiscal fourth quarter.To factor in the lower production volume
column32: iPhone builds in the   year-ago quarter stood at an estimated 55 million units. This   puts the anticipated year-over-year decline in volume at 13   million units. Assuming that the production cut pertains to the   older iPhone 6S
column33: Cirrus' revenue could drop by as much as $45   million since it was making $3.50 on each unit of the prior   generation device.Therefore
column34: the revenue gains from the iPhone 7 will be reduced   to just $30 million after accounting for the decline in overall   production. This indicates that Cirrus could post sales of   approximately $262 million in the fiscal fourth quarter as its   revenue in the prior-year period was $232 million. Barring major   gains in other business areas
column35: Wall Street analyst estimates   of between $312 million and $350 million in fiscal fourth   quarter revenue will be tough to beat.This tough outlook could lead to a potential sell-off since   investors will consider booking profits as Cirrus Logic shares   have already doubled in the past year. Investors can find out   more when the company reports after the close this Wednesday.10 stocks we like better than Cirrus LogicWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column36: it can pay to listen. After all
column37: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column38: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column39: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Cirrus Logic wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool     recommends Cirrus Logic. column5: one standout is the SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average ETF (Symbol: DIA) where we have detected an approximate $602.2 million dollar inflow -- that's a 3.8% increase week over week in outstanding units (from 79

column10: in trading today Boeing Co. (Symbol: BA) is down about 1.9%
column11: Apple Inc (Symbol: AAPL) is down about 0.7%
column12: and McDonald's Corp (Symbol: MCD) is lower by about 0.2%.For a complete list of holdings
column13: visit the DIA Holdings page Â»The chart below shows the one year price performance of DIA
column14: versus its 200 day moving average:Looking at the chart above
column15: DIA's low point in its 52 week range is $155.26 per share
column16: with $200.97 as the 52 week high point - that compares with a last trade of $199.02. Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average Â».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column18: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column19: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column20: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings

column1: Can Apple (AAPL) be a Suitable Value Pick at the Moment?;1/30/2017;"Value investing is easily one of the most popular ways to find great stocks in any market environment. After all
column2: who wouldn't want to find stocks that are either flying under the radar and are compelling buys
column3: or offer up tantalizing discounts when compared to fair value?makeArticleAd();One way to find these companies is by looking at several key metrics and financial ratios
column4: many of which are crucial in the value stock selection process. Let's putApple Inc.AAPLstock into this equation and find out if it is a good choice for value-oriented investors right now
column5: or if investors subscribing to this methodology should look elsewhere for top picks:PE RatioA key metric that value investors always look at is the Price to Earnings Ratio
column6: or PE for short. This shows us how much investors are willing to pay for each dollar of earnings in a given stock
column7: and is easily one of the most popular financial ratios in the world. The best use of the PE ratio is to compare the stock's current PE ratio with: a) where this ratio has been in the past; b) how it compares to the average for the industry/sector; and c) how it compares to the market as a whole.On this front
column8: Apple has a trailing twelve months PE ratio of 14.75. This level compares favorably with the market at large
column9: as the PE ratio for the S&P 500 comes in at about 20.11.If we focus on the long-term PE trend
column10: Apple's current PE level puts it slightly above its midpoint over the past five years
column11: with the number having risen rapidly over the past few months. Hence
column12: this does not provide us with a conclusive direction as to the relative valuation of the stock in comparison to its own historical trend.Meanwhile
column13: the stock's PE compares favorably with the Zacks classified Computer & Technology sector's trailing twelve months PE ratio
column14: which stands at 22.08. At the very least
column15: this indicates that the stock is relatively undervalued right now
column16: compared to its peers.We should also point out that Apple has a forward PE ratio (price relative to this year's earnings) of just 13.70
column17: so it is fair to say that a slightly more value-oriented path may be ahead forApple stockin the near term too.P/S RatioAnother key metric to note is the Price/Sales ratio. This approach compares a given stock's price to its total sales
column18: where a lower reading is generally considered better. Some people like this metric more than other value-focused ones because it looks at sales
column19: something that is far harder to manipulate with accounting tricks than earnings.Right now
column20: Apple has a P/S ratio of about 3.05. This is a bit higher than the Computer & Technology sector's average
column21: which comes in at 2.96 right now. In fact
column22: over the last year
column23: Apple's figure has been quite close to the sector's average
column24: as we can see in the chart below:However
column25: the current level lies near to the median of the stock's own historical trend (which stands at 2.93). This again does not provide us with any conclusive direction as to the relative valuation of the stock in comparison to its own trend.Broad Value OutlookIn aggregate
column26: Apple currently has a Zacks Value Style Score of 'B'
column27: putting it into the top 40% of all stocks we cover from this look. This makes Apple a solid choice for value investors
column28: and some of its other key metrics make this pretty clear too.For example
column29: the PEG ratio for Apple is just 1.20
column30: a level that is far lower than the industry average of 5.06. The PEG ratio is a modified PE ratio that takes into account the stock's earnings growth rate. Clearly
column31: AAPL is a solid choice on the value front from multiple angles.What About the Stock Overall?Though Apple might be a good choice for value investors
column32: there are plenty of other factors to consider before investing in this name. In particular
column33: it is worth noting that the company has a Growth grade of 'D' and a Momentum score of 'F'. This gives AAPL a Zacks VGM score-or its overarching fundamental grade-of 'D'. (You can read more about the Zacks Style Scoreshere >>)Meanwhile
column34: the company's recent earnings estimates have been trending downwards slightly. The current quarter has seen one estimate go higher in the past sixty days compared to three lower
column35: while the full year estimate has seen one upward revision and eight downward revisions in the same time period.This has had just a small impact on the consensus estimate though as the current quarter consensus estimate has inched lower by 0.3% in the past two months
column36: while the full year estimate has declined nearly 2%. You can see the consensus estimate trend and recent price action for the stock in the chart below:Apple Inc. Price and ConsensusApple Inc. Price and Consensus|Apple Inc. QuoteThis somewhat dull trend is why the stock has just a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) and why we are looking for in-line performance from the company in the near term.Bottom LineApple forms a part of the Zacks Computer-Mini industry. The industry is highly competitive and thus Apple faces significant competition in most of its operating markets from respective segment leaders like Hewlett-Packard
column37: Google
column38: Samsung
column39: etc. Moreover
column40: the demand for high-end devices has been soft recently
column41: owing to global macroeconomic weakness
column42: especially with currency volatility and declining commodity prices in some key regions across the globe.In fact
column43: over the past two years
column44: the Zacks Computer-Mini industry has clearly underperformed the broader market
column45: as you can see below:Apple is an inspired choice for value investors
column46: as it is hard to beat its incredible lineup of statistics on this front. However
column47: with a sluggish industry rank (Bottom 14% out of more than 250 industries) and a Zacks Rank #3

column2: Apple
column3: Amazon
column4: Alphabet and Intel;1/30/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - January 30
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeMicrosoft(NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report)
column7: Apple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column8: Amazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)
column9: Alphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) andIntel(NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:The Cloud Drives Technology Stocks This QuarterAnalysts and experts have talked at length about the importance of cloud computing and how it would transform the technology sector. But the sense of waiting that underpinned such discussions is now giving way to a sense of arrival.Several factors are making cloud computing a reality today
column11: the most important of which are an awareness of the resultant cost reductions
column12: awareness of the economic value of processing ever-increasing volumes of data
column13: and recognition of the advantages of sharing resources and having anytime anywhere access to data and information.Of course
column14: along with all these advantages comes concerns related to privacy and security
column15: which have been further exacerbated by government snooping
column16: gag orders and orders to turn over data in private individual devices or in servers on foreign soil that have in turn made individuals and corporations wary about adopting the cloud.But technology companies are fighting it out. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report) for one has strongly resisted government demands as have Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report). Alphabet's (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) Google has also been vocal in its opposition. It makes perfect sense when you consider that these are some of the biggest cloud computing stocks that also offer computing and other devices. So they have vested interests at both ends of the networks.Other players with similar interests are chip makers like Intel (NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report); networking companies like Cisco and Juniper; and software/service companies like IBM and Oracle.Here's a brief glimpse of three cloud companies that just reported December quarter results:IntelIntel's results this quarter were driven by both the PC and data center businesses. The PC strength was seasonal and unlikely to be sustained.Although non-volatile memory had the strongest growth rate of 24.8% and will grow even stronger this year
column17: it currently contributes a lower share of revenue
column18: which equates to fewer incremental dollars. Also
column19: the business is poised to benefit from Intel's strength in the server market.Data center revenue growth of 8% year over year was helped by platform volume growth of 3% and platform price increase of 4%. Intel has new products in the pipeline and will also be integrating some technology it acquired through Altera
column20: so this year may be less disappointing than the last when enterprise softness skewed expectations.MicrosoftMicrosoft has become a cloud-focused company
column21: impressing analysts and investors alike. The company is making the most of legacy workloads that use its software and its all-new Windows OS
column22: while leveraging Office productivity software and enterprise relationships to post record growth in cloud revenue.The company reported solid cloud results
column23: with Azure revenue growing 93% (95% in constant currency) and compute usage doubling year over year. Its cloud productivity business also saw strong growth: Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% (49% in constant currency) with seat growth of 37% and monthly active iOS and Android devices more than doubling to 65 million
column24: Office 365 consumer revenue grew 22% (21% in constant currency) with seat growth of 20.9%.Dynamics 365 paid seats also more than doubled. Nadella promised commercial cloud annualized revenue runrate of $20.0 billion in 2018 and last quarter's $14.0 billion means that Microsoft is definitely on track to beat or exceed the target.AlphabetAlphabet doesn't break out its cloud revenue separately although independent market research data indicates that it is well behind market leader Amazon and even runners up Microsoft. In fact after the December quarter results some analysts have started saying that Microsoft has also started pulling away from the pack in its chase of Amazon.Alphabet's growth should not be discounted however because while cloud and hardware are lumped together right now
column25: its common knowledge that most of its new hardware has been unavailable for a lot of the time. So the 62% growth in this segment seems to be less on account of hardware sales and more of an indication of strength it is seeing in the cloud.CFO Ruth Porat has said that cloud
column26: hardware and YouTube subscriptions will be ""major revenue drivers for Google in the next several years."" This will of course require capital investment
column27: something the company can afford given the way the search business continues to rake in cash. Capex was around $3.08 billion last quarter
column28: that's nearly up by a billion dollars and will mostly be spent on data centers to support its cloud business.Now See Our Private Investment IdeasWhile the above ideas are being shared with the public

(AAPL)Apple is in the midst of a controversial move that will limit the number of apps available to consumers in Iran.The company has reportedlybeen pulling Iranian appsfrom the App Store. The App Store was first opened in the Middle Eastern country a few months ago in September 2016.7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayAt first

column10: but Apple was slowly removing these. However

column12: but many companies manage to sell their apps to consumers in Iran by registering their app as being outside the country.The country has about 40 million smartphones in use
column13: which amounts to roughly half of the 82 million population using devices.AAPL shares have risen 5.3% year-to-date.BlackBerry Ltd (BBRY)BlackBerry is looking for one last hurrah in the smartphone industry with its Mercury device.The company has managed to survive going under by slowly transitioning from a hardware maker to a software provider. column17: but it is unclear if the decision to use it on the show was his idea or a decision made by one of the producers.BBRY shares have slipped 5.4% over the past six months.Delta Air Lines
