column1: Facebook Inc (FB) Stock: New All-Time Highs or New Problems?;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) enters this week's fourth-quarter earnings report in a peculiar position: Despite the fact that FB stock is trading near all-time highs
column3: Facebook absolutely has something to prove.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's because FB has spent the past three months recovering from a rough Q3 report that sent the stock to one of its biggest dips since coming public in 2012. While the company reported a strong earnings beat
column4: Facebook CFO warned about a slowdown in revenue growth for Q4
column5: and said ad load might ""come down meaningfully"" in the second half of this year.The news sparked a selloff from which Facebook wouldn't really recover until the start of 2017. But recover it has - FB stock is up roughly 15% in the past month to trade near all-time highs around $113.So
column6: what's in store for Facebook this time around?If you believe Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald
column7: FB could be sitting on the powder keg that sends Facebook through the price ceiling.Fitzgerald believes Instagram and mobile ad revenues will drive the business forward
column8: and expects Q4 revenues to grow 46% year-over-year to $8.54 billion - slightly ahead of Wall Street's broader estimates for $8.5 billion. He also projects GAAP profits of $1.05
column9: which are a penny higher than the consensus mark.""We remain particularly optimistic around Instagram
column10: bottom-funnel ad units like DPAs
column11: and Live video
column12: says Fitzgerald
column13: whose $175 price target represents 33% upside from here. ""While expense growth is a potential concern
column14: FB has a history of under-promising and overdelivering in this area.""10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatIndeed
column15: mobile is king for Facebook
column16: which crossed the 1 billion mark for ""mobile only"" active users in Q3. In fact
column17: 84% of the company's $6.82 billion in ad revenues came from mobile - up from 78% in the year-ago period. At about $5.7 billion
column18: mobile ad sales came in more than 30% higher thantotalFacebook ad sales in Q3 2015.Still
column19: if Facebook matches Wall Street's projections for 45.6% sales growth
column20: that would be down both sequentially from Q3's 59% revenue expansion
column21: and last Q4's 52% increase in sales. Which means investors will be looking for other areas of growth.They could get it in Facebook Live
column22: the company's somewhat controversial live streaming service that has unwittingly exposed users to real-time torture and suicide videos. Still
column23: CEO believes images and video are the future of Facebook - and the expansion and advertising of Live's services reflect that plenty.Facebook will need to show Wall Street something exciting
column24: though
column25: or FB could be in for its second straight quarterly tumble.Facebook shares reached all-time highs just above $133 in late October. They then dropped but rebounded to the $132 area
column26: but were rejected following the Q3 earnings report. FB then was sent packing to the $114 level
column27: which it fought several times before rebounding into the current rally.Now
column28: Facebook stock finds itself challenging the $132-$133 area once more
column29: but this time with an overbought Relative Strength Index (RSI) reading in the low 70s.And from a fundamental perspective
column30: Facebook's forward price-to-earnings ratio of 25 isn't nearly on par with the likes of pricey Big Tech stocks such asNetflix
column31: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX)
column32: but it's still a little lofty.At the very least
column33: it'll be on investors' minds - especially if Facebook lays an egg Wednesday.More Earnings in FocusApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

However
column42: if one believes that iPhone units can grow with iPhone 8 and then be roughly stable going forward

column1: Hereâ€™s How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Reclaim Its Throne;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has its day of reckoning fast approaching. Tim Cook has turned out to be a game manager for AAPL stock. That's not a slight against him
column3: but a game manager comes in when your first-string QB is out for a quarter or two. The problem is that Apple needs a visionary. There's no replacing Steve Jobs
column4: and being a game manager in a sector that moves like lightning is not what the company needs.makeArticleAd();Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrAAPL stock generates almost 70% of revenue from the iPhone
column5: and that product is seeing increasing competition.The good news is that Apple has well over $200 billion in cash and investments. It can literally do anything it wants. The problem is that most of that cash is stuck overseas - although that may change under Trump - and what Cook might do with that cash is a mystery.Without a vision
column6: Apple would probably have to make acquisitions in rapidly growing companies. However
column7: there is one other area that AAPL stock can venture into
column8: one that I've been saying it must get into: original content.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018News has surfaced that AAPL is finally looking seriously at creating original TV and film content. For years
column9: Apple has begged off of this direction. It seemed content to play around with music streaming
column10: and licensing content from other providers for iTunes.TheWSJreported:""The technology giant has been in talks with veteran producers in recent months about buying rights to scripted television programs. It also has approached experienced marketing executives at studios and networks to discuss hiring them to promote its content
column11: said people with knowledge of the discussions. In addition to TV
column12: Apple indicated to these people that it is considering offering original movies
column13: though those plans are more preliminary. Executives at Apple have told people in Hollywood they hope to start offering original scripted content by the end of 2017.""The apple is ripe for AAPL to get involved
column14: and in a very big way. We've seen thatNetflix
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) has shifted its model toward original programming and is producing really great stuff. So isAmazon.com
column16: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). YouTube Red
column17: though
column18: is kind of floundering right now.One thing people want is not only more content
column19: but good content. Because Apple is so flush with cash
column20: it can literally do anything in this arena. There is a ton of talent out there
column21: and so many models to play with for AAPL stock.Obviously
column22: Apple would want to create high quality TV and film
column23: and could do so across all genres. It wouldn't even have to be an issue of streaming content alone. If Apple wanted
column24: it could produce feature films
column25: and buy out any of the existing movie theatre chains and rebrand it as an Apple Theatre experience
column26: and drop in all manner of synergies like this.The concept of the ""long tail"" is still very much in play
column27: so creating independent work for a price
column28: or returning to a version of the old studio system might also yield rewards. Yet there are other models
column29: such as mining new talent from film schools and user-generated genius that's all over the place.The emerging technology of VR is another place to stretch. The ability to curate fully engaging experiences via VR
column30: and developing technology that allows players to wear bodysuits permitting them to actually experience touch in these games is the next frontier.Can Apple Inc. (AAPL) Afford a War With Qualcomm
column31: Inc. (QCOM)?And Apple has the money for it. It could become a multi-platform creator of content
column32: and be able to engage people from all over the world.Is this is a blockbuster revenue generator for Apple stock? It's way too early to tell. However
column33: having a vision that extends the concept of ""content"" to things like VR and more ""experiential"" content
column34: could mean becoming the first mover in a whole new generation of entertainment. That is priceless.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column35: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column36: has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column37: and has written more than 1
column38: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.More From InvestorPlace5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in February10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsThe postHere's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Reclaim Its Throneappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: LM Ericsson Sets Sail With a New Captain;1/30/2017;"Telecom-equipment makerTelefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson(NASDAQ: ERIC) reported fourth-quarter results on Thursday   morning. Share prices rose more than 3% that day.Ericsson's fourth-quarter results: The raw numbersMetricQ4 2016makeArticleAd();Q4 2015Year-Over-Year ChangeRevenue$7.2 billion$8.7 billion(17%)Net income($177 million)$823 millionN/AOperating cash flow$2.1 billion$2.6 billion(17%)Adjusted EPS (diluted)$0.07$0.29(76%)Data source:Ericsson. Financial results reported in Swedish crowns
column2: converted to   average exchange rates of $0.11 USD per SEK in Q4 of 2016 and   $0.12 USD per SEK in the 2015 period.What happened with Ericsson this quarter?This was a tumultuous quarter for the Swedish telecom   infrastructure veteran.Borje Ekholm took the CEO office shortly after the end of     the fourth quarter. Interim CEO Jan Frykhammar stepped down
column3: but will remain on Ericsson's board of directors. Frykhammar's     team of advisors
column4: including interim CFO Carl Mellander and     executive vice president Magnus Mandersson
column5: will stay in place     to give Ekholm guidance and continuity. That's the end of the     aftermath of former CEO Hans Vestberg's seven-year reign.A large chunk of the sales decline came from a tough     comparison against the year-ago period. In that quarter
column6: Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) signed a patent licensing agreement with     Ericsson that settled all litigation between the companies --     and temporarily added nearly $500 million to Ericsson's top     line.On top of the Apple effect
column7: all three of Ericsson's     reportable segments delivered lower sales and smaller operating     profits on a year-over-year basis. However
column8: network hardware     sales increase 33% sequentially and drove global service     revenues 15% higher
column9: thanks to strong order volumes in several     key markets.Image source: Ericsson.Ericsson's management did not provide firm guidance targets   for the coming quarter or fiscal year. Instead
column10: they said that   markets would stay ""tough"" in 2017
column11: putting pressure on sales   expectations. Gross margins are expected to improve in the second   half of 2017
column12: ending a negative streak that started in the spring   of 2016.What management had to sayIn aconference callwith Wall Street analysts
column13: Ekholm provided a reminder of what   Ericsson is all about. Investors might see this note as a call to   arms
column14: getting back to the nuts and bolts of running a   multinational technology business. Ekholm said:We are in a technology industry. We need to be technology     leaders and stay at the forefront of the technology     development. Ericsson has a unique set of assets with our     products but we also have services and solutions
column15: and that     package creates a unique position for us to compete in the     market. That's something we need to leverage
column16: but it's also     something we continuously need to invest in and develop.Looking aheadWith degrees in electrical engineering and economics and 10   years of service on Ericsson's board of directors
column17: Ekholm seems   exceptionally qualified for his new job. Vestberg is moving   on to lead Sweden's Olympic committee
column18: including efforts to host   the Winter Games in 2026.Ekholm is widely expected to restructure Ericsson around the   next generation of mobile technology
column19: known as 5G
column20: alongside   support for cloud computing and the Internet of Things. It's less   obvious where he will start slashing Ericsson's efforts and   expenses in order to achieve that sharper focus. Ekholm   reportedly started making the rounds among Ericsson's top   customers in North America
column21: Asia
column22: and Europe as soon as he was   selected
column23: giving him a three-month head start.Starting in the first quarter of fiscal year 2017
column24: Ericsson   will report results in three new segments: networks
column25: media
column26: and   IT and cloud.10 stocks we like better than Telefonaktiebolaget LM     EricssonWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Ericsson wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column31: 2017Anders Bylundhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the     following options: long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and     short January 2018 $95 calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: How Skyworks Solutions Inc Is Growing Beyond Apple;1/29/2017;"Image source: Skyworks Solutions.Skyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS) investors couldn't have asked for a better start   to its fiscal 2017. A first quarterearnings beatand a stronger outlook for the ongoing quarter sent its stock   soaring to new 52-week highs
column2: as it rose over 13% in a single   day.makeArticleAd();For the fiscal second quarter
column3: Skyworks believes that its   revenue will grow 8% year-over-year to $840 million
column4: exceeding   the consensus forecast of $818 million
column5: while earnings of $1.40   per share should significantly outpace analyst estimates of $1.24   per share.Skyworks also delivered some solid long-term takeaways in its   latest quarter. The company is now boasting of design wins at   high-volume smartphone companies in China
column6: as it is growing its   revenue outside ofApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . Still
column7: Apple reportedly contributed 40% of   Skyworks' top line in fiscal 2016.However
column8: the company has been gradually working toward winning   more business from other clients
column9: and it has found some   success.Growing beyond AppleSkyworks' business outside of Apple increased 8% in the last   fiscal year
column10: as Vivek Arya of Merrill Lynch pointed out on the   latest conference call. Though this might not seem really big   right now
column11: the fact that overall revenue fell 1.3% year-over-year   in the first quarter makes the growth beyond Apple a crucial   factor for long-term success.In fiscal 2015
column12: Apple wasreportedly44% of Skyworks' business. Thus
column13: it can be assumed that of   Skyworks' total revenue of $927 million in the first quarter of   2016
column14: Apple contributed about $408 million of that. By   comparison
column15: the smartphone giant should have contributed $366   million to Skyworks' revenue (40% of $914 million) in the most   recently reported quarter. This indicates that revenue from Apple   fell about 10% year-over-year.That indicates Skyworks' growth from other clients powered its   revenue and earnings beat last quarter. This is why Skyworks   needs to aggressively pursue client diversification if it wants   to mitigate the slowdown in business with Apple.Diversifying in the right areasSkyworks Solutions is building an army of clients in China.   One of the most prominent names is Huawei. The company has been   supplying its SkyBlue technology to the Chinese smartphone maker   for its flagship Mate 9 smartphone. In fact
column16: according to   Skyworks CEO Liam Griffin
column17: Huawei is now the company's second   biggest client.This is a big deal for Skyworks since Huawei is now a   formidable name in the smartphone industry. According to the   latest data available from IDC
column18: Huawei's smartphone market share   stood at 9.3%
column19: trailingSamsung's 21% share and Apple's 12.5% share in the third quarter of   2016. More importantly
column20: the Chinese smartphone giant has been   selling more of its high and mid-range phones
column21: which account for   57% of its total shipments.With a higher share of Huawei's sales being driven by premium   and mid-range devices
column22: it has been able to increase the average   selling price of its phones. When the company had released its   2015 results
column23: its average selling price of smartphones was up 17%   to $204 per unit. Though the company has not released 2016   numbers yet
column24: Huawei is capable of increasing its selling prices   once again as it has been introducing its flagship phones in   global markets.The higher average selling price
column25: along with higher volumes
column26: is good news for Skyworks since it will be able to enhance its   dollar content in Huawei devices
column27: which are in turn enjoying   higher selling prices. Market research firm TrendForce   points out that smartphone production will increase 4.5% this   year to 1.4 billion units. Chinese smartphone companies will   account for 634 million units of this production
column28: with Oppo
column29: Vivo
column30: and Huawei being the biggest names. As Skyworks counts all   three of them as clients
column31: it will witness a rise in chip sales   this year as the top Chinese smartphone companies are expected to   sell 39% more phones in 2017 as compared to 2016.Therefore
column32: higher component demand by Chinese companies to   make more smartphones will push up Skyworks' average selling   prices
column33: since it should be able to charge a premium in the wake   of tight supply. Skyworks can also make up for the volumes that   it is losing due to Apple's slowing iPhone sales
column34: as it can now   sell more components to Chinese smartphone makers.Moving beyond mobileSkyworks' opportunities beyond mobile. Image Source:     Skyworks Solutions.The great thing about Skyworks is that it is pursuing   opportunities beyond mobile as well. The Internet of Things
column35: or   IoT
column36: is one such opportunity where the company is aggressively   enhancing its presence by launching new offerings.Skyworks released new front-end connectivity modules for   machine-to-machine connectivity and IoT operations a few weeks   ago. With its latest IoT product
column37: Skyworks should be able to   accelerate the deployment of IoT applications by encouraging   migration from 2G networks due to its low cost and compact   packaging.This product development move by Skyworks is a smart one
column38: since the number of cellular devices communicating with each   other will rise from 300 million at present to around two billion   by 2020
column39: according to GSMA. As the number of machine-to-machine   connections increases
column40: Skyworks' connectivity modules that enable   the IoT will gain more traction and lead to higher shipment   volumes.However
column41: the company does not single out its revenue or   shipments from the IoT segment
column42: or any segment for that matter.   But the sheer growth in the size of this market
column43: coupled with the   company's product development efforts
column44: should prove to be a   tailwind in the long run.The Foolish takeawaySkyworks revenue is expected to increase 8.7% in the current   fiscal year
column45: followed by stronger growth of 10.5% next year. It   appears to be pulling the right strings to diversify its revenue   away from heavily concentrated clients such as Apple
column46: which seems   to have hit its ownroadblocks. As a result
column47: Skyworks is well-positioned for long-term success   as it focuses on markets that have significant room for growth   versus areas approaching saturation.10 stocks we like better than Skyworks     SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Apple Stock Has a Lot to Prove on Tuesday;1/29/2017;"Image source: The Motley Fool.One of the biggest earnings reports this week will beApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) . The world's most valuable consumer tech company   will be reporting its fiscal first quarter results after the   market close on Tuesday
column2: and it wouldn't be a surprise if the   numbers move bothApple stockand the market in general.makeArticleAd();Apple stock hit a fresh 52-week high on Thursday
column3: and with the   shares trading 36% off their springtime lows
column4: it's easy to see   how proving mortal can trigger a sell-off. The silver lining here   is that just a sliver of its gains have come in the past three   months. Apple shares have risen a mere 3% since its last   quarterly report.Wall Street pros aren't holding out for much. They see $77.38   billion in revenue for the holiday quarter
column5: just 2% more than   what Apple scored during the prior year's holiday quarter.   Analysts are also forecasting a profit of $3.22 a share
column6: just   below the $3.28 Apple delivered a year earlier.Grate expectationsIf a 2% uptick in revenue and a 2% dip in earnings per share   seem uninspiring
column7: keep in mind that three months ago we saw   revenue and earnings slide 9% and 15%
column8: respectively
column9: during   Apple's fiscal fourth quarter. A huge decline in China and a   modest slide in the Americas couldn't be overcome by smaller   gains in Europe and Japan. Apple's 24% surge in services revenue   was the lone bright spot
column10: and no match for selling fewer iPhones
column11: iPads
column12: and Macs.Bulls will argue that Tuesday's report will feature the first   full quarter of availability for the iPhone 7 and Apple Watch   Series 2 after their September debuts
column13: but it was also when the   iPhone 6s came out a year earlier. The prior year was also the   first holiday season of Apple Watch availability.Unfortunately for Apple
column14: Wall Street's gotten better at   forecasting its financial performances. Apple used to routinely   blast through analyst profit targets with ease when the iPad was   new and the iPhone was all the rage during the early years of the   mobile revolution. They're getting closer to the truth these   days. Apple hasn't topped Wall Street profit estimates by more   than 3% over the past year
column15: and that's with the benefit of   aggressive share buybacks propping up profitability on a   per-share basis. Apple's outstanding share count has declined in   each of the past four years.Analysts who have chimed in with updates in the days leading   up to Tuesday's report have been mixed. Mark Moskowitz at   Barclays downgraded Apple from ""overweight"" to ""equal weight
column16: concerned about the upside for all of 2017. He lowered his price   target from $119 to $117
column17: below where the stock is at now.Credit Suisseanalyst Kulbinder Garcha checked in a day later with a more   upbeat take
column18: but his ""outperform"" rating and $150 price goal is   based more on the potential of the hyped-up iPhone 8 that should   be released later this year than anything that we will see in   Tuesday's report.One can argue that the scene is set for Apple to shine.   Analysts are looking beyond the fiscal first quarter
column19: and the   stock hasn't kept up with the market since its last quarterly   report. After three quarters of year-over-year revenue declines
column20: even a token increase could give investors a chance to exhale.   The continuing growth of services revenue could ultimately get   net margins moving in the right direction again. We won't have to   wait long to see what Mr. Market thinks. Tuesday afternoon is   just around the corner.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Will Lawsuits Force Apple
column2: Inc. To Prevent Texting And Driving?;1/29/2017;"Distracted driving is a big and growing problem. In 2014
column4: 179 Americans were killed in traffic accidents involving   drivers diverting their attention to activities like eating
column5: talking on their phone
column6: or texting. It's the third most deadly   factor in modern car accidents
column7: behind only drunk driving and   speeding.You'll be delighted to hear that iPhone makerApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has patented a way to reduce this menace. But the   patented solution is not yet implemented on any of Apple's   devices.What gives? Let's have a look.makeArticleAd();What's new?Last week
column8: a survivor of a distracted-driving incident filed a   class action lawsuit against Apple. The suit is not seeking a big   payout from Cupertino. Instead
column9: it calls for an injunction   against sales of Apple devices in California until the company   implements its patented prevention method against texting and   driving on devices both new and already sold.""If texting and driving is a vessel of trouble
column10: Apple is the   captain of the ship
column11: the court filing states. ""The company   enjoys 40 percent of the smartphone market share -- far more than   the nearest competitor. And its profits are enormous. Fortune   Magazine reports that in the third quarter of 2016
column12: Apple   generated 91% of the smartphone market's profits
column13: equating to a   cool $8.5 billion in net profit -- or about $95 million in profit   per day.""So the suit argues that Apple plays a significant part in the   distracted driving problem
column14: and has both a responsibility and the   financial wherewithal to do something about it. Indeed
column15: there is   a tool on the table. The filing cites an Applepatentfor disabling a mobile device when its motion sensors and other   systems detect patterns consistent with driving a car. Filed in   2008
column16: when the ancientiPhone 3Gwas brand new
column17: and approved by the Patent Office in 2014
column18: Apple   has had an eye on this issue since the very beginning of its   smartphone exploits.But again
column19: nearly three years after that patent got an   official approval
column20: the technology remains unused.This lawsuit is not the first legal challenge to cite Apple's   anti-distraction patent. It's just the first one that primarily   wants to force Apple's hand into doing something with this   allegedly life-saving technology. Others have been more concerned   with cash payments for damage done by iPhone-wielding   drivers.Image source: US Patent and Trademark Office.Why isn't Apple using this patent yet?Many fully granted patents never see the light of day in a   real-world implementation. This particular one could be among   those for a variety of good reasons. For example:Apple could be working on a better solution than the one     described in the '143 patent
column21: but the new and improved solution     isn't ready for a date with the Patent Office yet.The company might have found flaws in its original     technology
column22: which was developed and filed at a time when     smartphones were a poorly understood novelty. Real-world     experience and deeper research could have changed Apple's     design requirements in a hurry.Other companies may have unveiled better solutions for the     dangers of distracted driving
column23: perhaps as part of efforts to     come up with fully automated driving platforms. Nearly every     major auto maker is on board with theautonomous drivingtrend now
column24: alongside plenty of technology experts. I'd be     surprised to learn that Apple's efforts from way back in 2008     provided a better solution than what all of Detroit and Silicon     Valley could whip up nearly a decade later.That's just scratching the surface of about a zillion reasons   not to take a patented technology to market. I'm sure that Apple   will come up with many more if the lawsuit ever hits a   courtroom.Image source: Apple.What's next?No
column25: I don't think that Apple will ever actually implement this   particular deterrent to texting and driving. Lawsuits won't   change that. Halting iPhone sales in California would be a   powerful incentive
column26: but Apple's top-shelf legal eagles can surely   head that threat off at the pass. However
column27: the fact that   consumers are standing up to ask Apple for help with this   conundrum could accelerate Apple's arrival at a more complete   solution.The company must balance the benefits of a life-saving safety   feature against the risk that users might find the new   restrictions too overbearing. If your phone came with opt-in   restrictions on how you can use it in the driver's seat of a car
column28: would you enable them? If not
column29: you'd be part of the problem.   Therefore
column30: this is the kind of feature that needs to be forced on   the user with no obvious way to turn it off. Otherwise
column31: the   change is not likely to make a difference.Apple obviously doesn't want to push any of its loyal users   over to Android and other platforms
column32: where they can continue   their risky behavior unfettered. Ideally
column33: the smartphone industry   would come together and push out protection against texting and   driving. No fuss
column34: no muss
column35: and thousands of lives potentially   saved. Top-down regulations would also do the trick
column36: but that   solution would also elicit pained groans of heavy-handed rules   from every company in the mobile industry.There may not be a real solution to the distracted driving   problem until self-driving cars go mainstream. Until then
column37: lawsuits and concerned users can only hope to turn Apple's   smartphone designs in a safer direction.Don't hold your breath.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Better Buy: Skyworks Solutions Inc. vs. Infinera;1/28/2017;"Investing in the tech sector can be tricky. Competition     tends to be fierce
column2: which makes it difficult to stay one step     ahead. Two companies that have a strong history of maintaining     their edge areSkyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS)  andInfinera(NASDAQ: INFN) . Both of these businesses have been taking     market share in their industries for years
column3: which is     impressive. But which of these two tech companies is the better     investment today? Let's review the bull thesis for each company     so we can make an informed decision.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The case for Skyworks SolutionsSkyworks designs and builds chips that allow devices to   connect to each other. The company's semiconductors are found in   a wide range of products such as routers
column4: tablets
column5: cars
column6: and   smartphones.While this industry is quite competitive
column7: Skyworks' unique   ability to create custom and complex solutions for its customers   has given it a big edge over rivals. In fact
column8: Skyworks chips can   currently be found in nearly all of the top-selling smartphones   in the world
column9: including those made bySamsung
column10: Xiaomi
column11: andApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) .The massive boom in smartphone sales over the last few   years has been a godsend for Skyworks. The company's revenue
column12: margins
column13: and profits have all soared
column14: which has taken long-term   investors on a lucrative ride.SWKSdata byYChartsWith the Internet of Things ramping up and 5G technology set   to deploy
column15: Skyworks looks well positioned to continue delivering   for investors from here. However
column16: Skyworks does have   an Achilles heel that investors should be aware of.   Apple is responsible for more than 40% of Skyworks' total   revenue
column17: which is a blessing and a curse. When iPhone sales are   booming
column18: Skyworks' results soar. However
column19: when the Mac maker   decides to reduce its channel inventory
column20: Skyworks reallyfeels the pain.While Skyworks has been signing deals in recent years to help   reduce its customer concentration
column21: Apple is such a huge component   of Skyworks revenue that these two companies will remain attached   at the hip -- for better or worse -- for the foreseeable   future.The case for InfineraInfinera is a fast growing player in the   optical networking equipment market. The company's products   make internet providers lives easier by allowing them to easily   (and cheaply) move vast quantities of data around the globe.Like Skyworks
column22: Infinera has also benefited from a number of   tech trends. The rise of cloud computing and streaming high-def   video is making it difficult for providers to keep up with   demand. That's forcing them to invest huge sums of money to   expand their networks
column23: which has been a boon to Infinera's   business.Image source: Getty Images.That's a wonderful backdrop
column24: but Infinera hasstruggledover the last few quarters to translate that bandwidth   demand growth into financial success. While there are several   factors to blame
column25: one of the biggest problems is   competition.Ciena-- a much larger rival -- has caught up to Infinera's   technological edge and has been eating the company's lunch as of   late. While Infinera's management is aware of the problem and is   investing heavily to recapture its edge
column26: it might be a long-haul   until the company returns to top-line growth.Of course
column27: those worries have now beenpriced into the company's stock
column28: so investors could be in a position to win big if the company   can grow faster than market watchers expect.The better buyWhile I'm hopeful that Infinera can right its ship
column29: there are   never any guarantees of success. For that reason
column30: I think that   the better choice for investors today is Skyworks. Not only does   Skyworks promise high growth rates ahead
column31: but it is already so   profitable that it pays out a fast-growing dividend and still   has enough cash left over tobuy back boatloads of stock. As long as the company can continue to make progress at fixing   its customer concentration issues
column32: then its future is looking   quite bright.10 stocks we like better than Skyworks     SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The Chronological History of How Qualcomm Became the Most Powerful Apple Supplier Ever;1/28/2017;"Image source: Apple.If you read throughApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) blockbuster lawsuit againstQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)
column2: there's quite a bit of animosity toward how   Qualcomm conducted its business with Apple over the years. This   was not a pleasant relationship -- at least according to   Apple.makeArticleAd();Instead
column3: this relationship was skewed significantly in favor   of Qualcomm
column4: and there wasn't a whole lot that Apple could do   since the iPhone fundamentally relies on cellular connectivity.   This is easily the only time that Apple has not had the upper   hand with a supplier relationship. Look no further than Apple's   ownnegotiating tacticswith now-defunct GT Advanced to see how hard Apple could squeeze   its suppliers. Yet Qualcomm was able to become the most powerful   Apple supplier ever.This story has at least a decade of history that you need to   know to fully appreciate why Apple felt desperate enough to sue.   ""I've always hated litigation and I continue to hate it
column5: said   CEO Tim Cook in 2014
column6: so we know Apple isn't trigger-happy when   it comes to suing. The Mac maker simply had enough. Note that   what follows is largely Apple's side
column7: as laid out in the   complaint. Qualcomm will of course offer a different   perspective.That being said
column8: let's start from the beginning.2007: Apple introduces the original iPhoneMuch of Qualcomm's patent portfolio is considered essential to   cellular standards that enable modern mobile devices to connect   to cellular networks
column9: which is the foundation of its licensing   business. Standards-essential patents (SEPs) must be licensed to   anyone
column10: including competitors
column11: at fair
column12: reasonable
column13: and   non-discriminatory (FRAND) rates.Apple initially sourced baseband modems from Infineon
column14: which   was subsequently acquired byIntel
column15: for the first four years. Even before Apple ever bought its   first Qualcomm baseband
column16: it had to pay licensing fees indirectly   through its contract manufacturers. Apple attempted to negotiate   a direct license with Qualcomm
column17: but was unable to
column18: according to   its complaint:Apple has been indirectly paying Qualcomm licensing fees     since 2007
column19: when it released the iPhone....In 2007
column20: Apple released the first iPhone using Intel (then     Infineon) baseband processor chipsets. Qualcomm required     licensing fees for using these chipsets. Rather than grant     Apple a direct license on FRAND terms
column21: Qualcomm has instead     entered into confidential licenses with specific Apple contract     manufacturers (""CMs"")
column22: the third-party manufacturers who make     and assemble Apple products. The CMs pay the exorbitant     royalties Qualcomm demands and pass the costs along to Apple in     full.As a way to get relief on excessive royalties
column23: Apple entered   into a ""Marketing Incentive Agreement"" with Qualcomm in 2007 that   prohibited it from marketing WiMAX devices
column24: an emerging 4G   standard that would compete with LTE -- and which Qualcomm lacks   meaningful patents for. Obviously
column25: if Apple can't market a   device
column26: it won't make said device. While this was before Apple   became a major player in the smartphone market
column27: this agreement   certainly contributed to WiMAX's death.It was around 2007 that Qualcomm allegedly stopped licensing   its SEPs to rivals
column28: and began charging separately for licenses.   This violated thepatent exhaustion doctrineof patent law.Around 2007
column29: Qualcomm's practice of licensing its     FRAND-encumbered cellular SEPs to competitors changed. In 2006
column30: Qualcomm's 10-K stated that it entered into ""License     Agreements"" with competing chipset manufacturers
column31: and received     royalties thereunder. In Qualcomm's 2007 10-K

column1: This Week in Solar;1/28/2017;"There's a lot to get to this week in solar
column2: so let's dive   right in.The fast and furious progress of solar energyIn 2011
column3: then Secretary of the U.S. Department of Energy   Steven Chu launched the SunShot initiative with a goal of cutting   the cost of installing a utility-scale solar system for $1 per   watt by 2020. At the time
column4: I called the 74% reduction in the cost   of solar in a decade ""an audacious goal.""Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Less than six years later and three years ahead of schedule
column5: I'm here to say that I underestimated the solar industry.   Projects are being built for less than $1 per watt today
column6: and   cost reductions continue to amaze even the most bullish   observers. Everything from solar panels to inverters to   permitting costs have come down in the last six years with the   SunShot program helping with the reductions. And $1 per-watt   solar will lead to a whole new surge in demand
column7: which is very   bullish for solar companies around the world.Apple and NV Energy find common groundBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) subsidiary NV Energy has taken its   share of lumps from the renewable energy industry over the last   few years. Solar advocates helped drive a ballot measure in   November that will give customers more choice than buying energy   from the monopoly. And casino companies
column8: which are its largest   customers
column9: are starting tocut their ties to the utilityand buy energy elsewhere.NV Energy may be learning that it can't take such an   adversarial approach to renewable energy and customers' desires   to buy renewables after agreeing to help Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)   build a 200 MW solar power plant by early 2019. The utility will   buy energy from the solar plant and sell the energy to Apple for   a data center in Reno
column10: continuing Apple's growth in solar   adoption.Corporate customers will likely be big drivers of renewable   energy in 2017
column11: demanding clean energy to power their businesses   around the country. Maybe utilities are finally learning that   it's better to go along with the renewable-energy revolution than   fight it and lose their customers to someone else.Don't freak out about the ITC... yetThe solar industry is abuzz with speculation about the solar   investment tax credit (ITC)
column12: which helps fund every solar project   in the country today. The subsidy was extended at the end of 2015   and is currently set to startstepping down from 30% in 2019to a permanent 10% from commercial projects
column13: and 0% for   residential projects
column14: starting in 2022.It's no secret that most of the new Trump Administration is   less in favor of renewable energy than the past administration
column15: so there's concern the ITC could be in trouble. But comments from   Treasury Secretary nominee Steve Mnuchin in support of wind   subsidies
column16: and Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson in   relation to climate change
column17: have eased some of those   tensions.Keep in mind that the ITC stepdown is current law and would   require an act of Congress
column18: including 60 votes in the Senate
column19: to   be repealed. I think that's unlikely to happen
column20: especially when   you consider the 200
column21: 000+ jobs in solar and extreme popularity of   the energy source. The ITC seems safe
column22: despite the likelihood   that it's unpopular inside the White House. Unless something   changes
column23: solar investors can breathe a sigh of relief.News and notesHere are the other notable items of the week that investors   shouldn't lose sight of.Eos Energy Storage andSiemens(NASDAQOTH: SIEGY)announced a partnershipto integrate
column24: install
column25: and service utility-scale energy-storage   solutions. It's hard to state how big it is that a giant in   electricity-distribution equipment is taking a role in energy   storage
column26: which will help solar provide more value to the grid. We   don't know exactly what will happen with the partnership in terms   of costs or demand for utility-scale storage
column27: but the fact that   it's on the radar of giants of the industry is big for renewable   energy.Pattern Energy Group(NASDAQ: PEGI) announced the closing of $350 million in senior   notes due 2024 with a 5.875% interest rate. The financing will   help the company pay down short-term debt and acquire more   renewable-energy projects. If this is a sign that yieldco   financing is opening up
column28: it would be good for the entire   industry.Canadian Solar(NASDAQ: CSIQ) signed a contract earlier this week with the   Sacramento Municipal Utility District to sell energy from a 60 MW   solar farm over the course of 20 years starting in mid-2017.   There haven't been a lot of big contract signings in the U.S.   over the past year
column29: so any movement in the space is notable
column30: even   if 60 MW is only about 1% of Canadian Solar's annual   manufacturing capacity.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Microsoft's Surface Lineup Is Now a $4.3 Billion Business;1/27/2017;"Surface lineup. Image source: Microsoft.WhenMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) first launched itsSurface lineup in 2012
column2: I had my doubts as to whether or not the company could   successfully jump into hardware. The company has had its fair   share of missteps for the Surface
column3: but it's safe to say at this   point that Microsoft has exceeded most early expectations for its   first-party devices. Microsoft has adapted quickly to flops like   Surface RT
column4: which resulted in a $900 million writedown back in   2013
column5: and pushed forward with expanding the portfolio
column6: most   recently with Surface Studio.makeArticleAd();Surface revenue during the fourth quarter came in at $1.3   billion
column7: representing a sequential increase of over 40% for the   busy holiday shopping season. That's enough to bring full-year   2016 Surface revenue to an impressive $4.3 billion.Data source: Microsoft. Chart by author. Calendar years     shown.It also probably helps that CEO Satya Nadella is a stronger   leader than his predecessor
column8: even though the Surface strategy was   conceived under Steve Ballmer. The push with Surface hardware   created a rift between Ballmer and Bill Gates
column9: and may have also   contributed to Ballmer's ouster.Out with the old
column10: in with the newDuring the earnings call
column11: Nadella noted that Surface has   enjoyed three consecutive quarters of 25%-plus growth. Sales mix   is transitioning toward the newer products like Surface Pro 4 and   Surface Book
column12: and Surface 3 sales are expected to continue   winding down.The customer reception for Surface Studio in particular has   been strong
column13: which is especially impressive for two reasons:   Surface Studio was not widely available during the fourth   quarter
column14: and it's extremely expensive
column15: starting at $3
column16: 000.   Inventories for the new all-in-one should start improving this   quarter as production ramps up.Taking a bite out of AppleMore broadly
column17: Surface is but part of a bigger push among the   Windows PC crowd to take a bite out ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) turf: the premium PC market. Surface is doing   well
column18: but it was never expected to comprise a large chunk of the   Windows ecosystem; that's what original equipment manufacturers   (OEMs) are for.CFO Amy Hood said that Microsoft's ""OEM non-pro performance   should grow ahead of the market
column19: due to strength in the premium   device category."" In other words
column20: high-end consumer-oriented PCs   made by Microsoft's partners are gaining traction in the market
column21: at a time when Apple lost PC market share for thefirst three quartersof 2016 (Apple reports fourth-quarter results next week). OEM   non-pro revenue grew 5% last quarter
column22: outpacing the broader PC   market.Surface is profitable
column23: tooIt's also worth pointing out that Surface is now profitable on   a gross margin basis (up 6% last quarter in dollar terms)
column24: so   those revenue gains are starting to enjoy some operating   leverage.Unfortunately
column25: currency headwinds are adversely impacting   profitability
column26: as Surface gross margin was up 17% on a constant   currency basis in dollar terms. There's a big discrepancy between   the currency impacts on revenue (2 percentage points) compared to   gross margin (11 percentage points)
column27: which is due to the fact   that Surface devices are manufactured in Asia and the Surface   cost structure is more vulnerable to currency fluctuations.Still
column28: you have to give Nadella credit for being able to take   a struggling segment conceived under Ballmer and turn it into a   profitable $4.3 billion business within just a couple of   years.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Great;1/27/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmidst the bombast
column3: braggadocio and fact-free claims of the 2016 presidential campaign
column4: perhaps the most effective was the subtext contained in President Trump's incessantly cited mantra
column5: ""Make America Great Again.""makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe implication of this successful sonnet of sloganism is that America is not great
column6: at least not in its current iteration. And while certainly an effectual rhetorical rallying point for the most disaffected voters
column7: the claim fails to hold up to scrutiny when one takes a more lucid view of the corporate and investing landscape.Indeed
column8: there are scores of companies
column9: and scores of stocks to own
column10: that already make America great. These are the companies that make the products and services that Americans organize their lives around. Creators of communication devices
column11: social media networks and information retrieval services are just a few of the brilliant achievements of entrepreneurial Americans that have made the country great through the genius of their ideas.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018They're also among the top companies
column12: and the top stocks
column13: that make our nation great for investors. If you want to feel good about the country
column14: and about the prospects for long-term portfolio performance
column15: here are 10 stocks to own thatalreadymake America great.Stocks to Buy: Boeing (BA)Source:Phillip Capper via FlickrPremier American aircraft manufacturerBoeing Co(NYSE:BA) also is one of the largest defense contractors in the U.S. The company supplies Western military forces with the F-15 and F-18 fighter jets
column16: which also are capable of precision strategic bombing runs crucial to defeating enemies such as the Islamic State.Just check out this footage of an F-18 delivering ISIS fighters a dead-on strike with a500-lb laser guided bomb[Graphic content warning] and you'll be convinced of the efficacy of its fighter jets in the effort against a determined
column17: well-funded and ideologically inspired army.Yet Boeing is far more than just a builder of military hardware. The company's iconic ""7 Series"" passenger jets - the 747
column19: 777 and 787 - have allowed not just Americans
column20: but travelers worldwide to speed off to their destinations safely
column21: and in style. If you want evidence of American corporate greatness
column22: just look to the sky near any major metropolitan airport. You're sure to spot the greatness of Boeing in flight.Stocks to Buy:Amazon.com (AMZN)Source: ShutterstockOnline seller of everythingAmazon.com(NASDAQ:AMZN) has been making America great for nearly 23 years. The brainchild of CEO Jeff Bezos began life as a hub where avid readers could get the latest novels
column23: and discover both new and old works that would appeal to their tastes.That formula worked not only for literature
column24: but for everything from music
column25: film
column26: video games
column27: electronics
column28: clothing
column29: toys
column30: toothpaste â€¦ and just about anything else one can require or desire.Amazon.com's relatively recent foray into the cloud computing business has been an unequivocal success
column31: with the company raking in some $3.2 billion in cloud computing revenue in the third quarter of 2016.3 Fast-Food Stocks That Are Sweating Bullets Thanks to McDonald'sThat figure was up 55% from the same quarter the year prior. Amazon's web services business proves that not only does the company make America great by delivering the products we want right to our door
column32: it also makes possible many of the e-commerce sites the American - and global - economy relies on to function smoothly.Stocks to Buy:Apple (AAPL)Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrPersonal technology giantApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is not only one of the most profitable companies in history
column33: it's alsothe most admired. And why shouldn't it be?The ubiquity
column34: efficacy
column35: ease of operation
column36: quality
column37: sophisticated industrial design and just outright aesthetic beauty of the company's products is a feat of entrepreneurial genius that on its own can be cited as a ""drop-the-mic"" reason why America already deserves the greatness title.The company's iconic products - the Mac
column38: iPod
column39: iPad and iPhone - all have transformed the way not only Americans live
column40: but also the way most of the developed and developing nations live. AAPL stock ran into a slowdown for much of 2016
column41: but since Election Day
column42: Wall Street has made Apple shares great again
column43: with a surge of more than 10%.Investors are clearly betting on the continued upside likely to come with the release of the company's 10th-anniversary iPhone. If you want proof America is already great
column44: just check your iMessages.Stocks to Buy:Facebook (FB)Source: ShutterstockSocial media pioneerFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) is a relatively recent entry into the ranks of companies making America great
column45: and it's done so by the sheer disruptive power of its product.The creation of CEO Mark Zuckerberg is the kind of game-changing invention that comes along infrequently
column46: but when it does it's hard to see how we ever got along without it.From connecting with old friends to staying in contact with relatives; and from discovering new interests
column47: nurturing hobbies and networking with others who share similar worldviews
column48: Facebook has become an essential part of the American (and global) experience.Ironically
column49: Facebook's flap with ""fake news"" and its ranking of certain news stories was an issue in the presidential campaign. Yet Facebook also was cited by President Trump as a key to his victory
column50: as he told CBS'60 Minutesthat thepower of his following on the social media gianthelped him win key races where he was outspent by his opponent.The 3 Best Sector ETFs to Buy for a Profitable 2017So
column51: Facebook not only already makes America great
column52: it also made President Trump's campaign a winner.Stocks to Buy:Goldman Sachs (GS)Source:Erik DrostIf you were asked to compile a list of the ""Big Banks"" that have financed America's growth
column53: as well as her ascension to greatness
column54: it's hard not to start withGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS).The premier investment bank has been at the center of the financial world since the reparative
column55: post-Civil War years
column56: when it helped finance America's rebirth beginning in 1869.Since then the company has had a storied history of providing the capital
column57: as well as the financial framework
column58: that's nurtured the rise of the greatest capitalist experiment in history.In another example ofTrumpianirony
column59: the president criticized the banks - and specifically Goldman Sachs - for transgressions that caused the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008. Yet who did Trump turn to for key positions in his campaign and in his cabinet? You guessed it
column60: numerous Goldman Sachs alumni.The moral of the story here is that when you want your own administration to be great
column61: you turn to those who have done great things at one of the greatest American financial institutions.Stocks to Buy:Alphabet (GOOGL)Source: ShutterstockPerhaps the only thing not great aboutAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column62: NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column63: better known as Google
column64: is its ghastly choice of new moniker. Yet despite its ill-fitting name
column65: Alphabet's core product - the Google search engine - has already made information-seeking America great.Founded by then-Ph.D. students Larry Page and Sergey Brin while they were at Stanford University
column66: the tech entrepreneurs leveraged the PC and internet explosion and created the go-to source for information on just about anything imaginable.Its corporate mission
column67: to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful
column68: has long been accomplished. And though Google has only been in existence for less than 20 years
column69: like Facebook
column70: it also has become an essential part of the American and the international experience.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsJust try to go more than a few days without using Google. It's nearly impossible
column71: especially if you are someone who loves knowing things.Stocks to Buy:Disney (DIS)Source: ShutterstockAnyone who has grown up in America since the 1940s
column72: or who has reared children or grandchildren over the past five decades
column73: knows all-too-well the draw that is theWalt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS).Purveyors of iconic American characters such as Mickey and Minnie Mouse
column74: Donald Duck
column75: Goofy
column76: Snow White and so many others
column77: the company has built a media and entertainment empire by knowing what Americans (and the world) want to see.Disney's relatively recent acquisition of the Star Wars franchise is proof of the company's commitment to remaining the leader in providing entertainment with the broadest appeal.Founded on the genius of Walt Disney the man
column78: the Disney Company was set up to be a dream factory capable of igniting children's imaginations all over the world. It's safe to say that it has done just that
column79: and that it will remain great long after President Trump has completed his tenure in the Oval Office.Stocks to Buy:American Express (AXP)Source:Marcus Quigmire Via FlickrWhen ""American"" is part of your name
column80: it's easy to make the short hop of logic needed to proclaimAmerican Express Company(NYSE:AXP) a company that's already making America great. Indeed
column81: the credit card issuer
column82: andDow Jonescomponent
column83: offers what is arguably the best customer service in the financial services industry.Moreover
column84: it's an aspirational brand that pulls at the capitalist heart strings of nearly every American set on achieving financial prowess. For those who've experienced it
column85: how can you forget being approved for your first American Express card? That grant signifies an arrival of sorts into an honored clubhouse of the financially fit.Here
column86: too
column87: irony and the Trump administration once again collide. If President Trump and the Republican Congress can get personal tax reform passed
column88: American Express shares may be the biggest beneficiary. The reason why is because higher income and higher net worth consumers tend to use American Express more than rival credit cards.3 Dividend Aristocrats to Buy for Income and GrowthAs such
column89: a reduction in marginal tax rates for the nation's top earners would likely translate into increased spending via AmEx - which would funnel down directly to AXP shares.Stocks to Buy:Caterpillar (CAT)Source:Anthony via FlickrThe makers of earth-shaping equipment have literally transformed the American landscape into man's image
column90: a feat that on its own qualifiesCaterpillar Inc.(NYSE:CAT) for a spot on the 10 stocks that already make America great.The unmistakable CAT brand is responsible for helping more builders erect more homes
column91: shopping centers
column92: office buildings
column93: roads
column94: bridges and dams than any government infrastructure project could ever do.In fact
column95: any effort to make America's infrastructure great again would likely start with a whole lot of equipment from Caterpillar
column96: as its heavy machinery is an integral part of massive build outs here at home
column97: and worldwide.The CAT brand also is seen as a sort of badge of honor in the developing world
column98: as developing nations seek to build their infrastructure in the image of the American landscape. To the rest of the world
column99: America is already great â€¦ and they often use Caterpillar equipment to help their own nations look like us.Stocks to Buy:Tesla Motors (TSLA)Source: ShutterstockAmerica is a car culture country
column100: and many of her most iconic brands -General Motors Company(NYSE:GM) andFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) - represent the best of American industrial prowess.While these storied brands could themselves be on any list of stocks that already make America great
column101: one new car company embodies all of the entrepreneurial and innovative genius that's at the heart of what makes America special. That company isTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA).The brainchild of the ceaselessly creative Elon Musk
column102: Tesla has proven that luxury
column103: performance and the lack of an internal combustion engine can be a splendid marriage; one never lacking in operator excitement. In fact
column104: the experience of driving the posh
column105: powerful and eminently smooth Model S through traffic is akin to what it must be like piloting a modern fighter jet through a formation of P-51 Mustangs.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in FebruaryAnd while the World War II fighter helped make America great by vanquishing her enemies in aerial combat
column107: Model X and Model 3 are clearing a new path for automotive technology - technology that could be the American and global standard in decades to come.As of this writing
column110: GS and TSLA stock.The post10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Greatappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The Cloud Drives Technology Stocks This Quarter;1/27/2017;"Analysts and experts have talked at length about the importance of cloud computing and how it would transform the technology sector. But the sense of waiting that underpinned such discussions is now giving way to a sense of arrival.Several factors are making cloud computing a reality today
column2: the most important of which are an awareness of the resultant cost reductions
column3: awareness of the economic value of processing ever-increasing volumes of data
column4: and recognition of the advantages of sharing resources and having anytime anywhere access to data and information.Of course
column5: along with all these advantages comes concerns related to privacy and security
column6: which have been further exacerbated by government snooping
column7: gag orders and orders to turn over data in private individual devices or in servers on foreign soil that have in turn made individuals and corporations wary about adopting the cloud.But technology companies are fighting it out. MicrosoftMSFTfor one has strongly resisted government demands as have AppleAAPLand AmazonAMZN. Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle has also been vocal in its opposition. It makes perfect sense when you consider that these are some of the biggest cloud computing stocks that also offer computing and other devices. So they have vested interests at both ends of the networks.Other players with similar interests are chip makers like IntelINTC
column8: NVIDIANVDA
column9: Qualcomm and Advanced Micro DevicesAMD; networking companies like Cisco and Juniper; and software/service companies like IBM and Oracle.Here's a brief glimpse of three cloud companies that just reported December quarter results:IntelIntel's results this quarter were driven by both the PC and data center businesses. The PC strength was seasonal and unlikely to be sustained.Although non-volatile memory had the strongest growth rate of 24.8% and will grow even stronger this year
column10: it currently contributes a lower share of revenue
column11: which equates to fewer incremental dollars. Also
column12: the business is poised to benefit from Intel's strength in the server market.Data center revenue growth of 8% year over year was helped by platform volume growth of 3% and platform price increase of 4%. Intel has new products in the pipeline and will also be integrating some technology it acquired through Altera
column13: so this year may be less disappointing than the last when enterprise softness skewed expectations.MicrosoftMicrosoft has become a cloud-focused company
column14: impressing analysts and investors alike. The company is making the most of legacy workloads that use its software and its all-new Windows OS
column15: while leveraging Office productivity software and enterprise relationships to post record growth in cloud revenue.The company reported solid cloud results
column16: with Azure revenue growing 93% (95% in constant currency) and compute usage doubling year over year. Its cloud productivity business also saw strong growth: Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% (49% in constant currency) with seat growth of 37% and monthly active iOS and Android devices more than doubling to 65 million
column17: Office 365 consumer revenue grew 22% (21% in constant currency) with seat growth of 20.9%.Dynamics 365 paid seats also more than doubled. Nadella promised commercial cloud annualized revenue runrate of $20.0 billion in 2018 and last quarter's $14.0 billion means that Microsoft is definitely on track to beat or exceed the target.AlphabetAlphabet doesn't break out its cloud revenue separately although independent market research data indicates that it is well behind market leader Amazon and even runners up Microsoft. In fact after the December quarter results some analysts have started saying that Microsoft has also started pulling away from the pack in its chase of Amazon.Alphabet's growth should not be discounted however because while cloud and hardware are lumped together right now
column18: its common knowledge that most of its new hardware has been unavailable for a lot of the time. So the 62% growth in this segment seems to be less on account of hardware sales and more of an indication of strength it is seeing in the cloud.CFO Ruth Porat has said that cloud
column19: hardware and YouTube subscriptions will be ""major revenue drivers for Google in the next several years."" This will of course require capital investment
column20: something the company can afford given the way the search business continues to rake in cash. Capex was around $3.08 billion last quarter
column21: that's nearly up by a billion dollars and will mostly be spent on data centers to support its cloud business.Now See Our Private Investment IdeasWhile the above ideas are being shared with the public
column22: other trades are hidden from everyone but selected members. Would you like to peek behind the curtain and view them? Starting today

You can even look inside portfolios so exclusive that they are normally closed to new investors.Click here for Zacks' secret trades >>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? column1: Fitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Has Quite a Wall to Climb;1/27/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenever high-flying stocks get their wings clipped
column3: they are never the same on the markets.Fitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) ended its recovery of the summer of 2016 when it warned on Nov. 2
column5: that fourth-quarter estimates would miss estimates. Bears are all over the stock: short float stands at 43.5%. And when the company reports results in February
column6: bulls still hope the company's wearables devices sold like hot cakes.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitExpectations Lowered for FIT StockIn its third-quarter report
column7: the company cut the current quarter's estimatessharply:""The company expects revenue between $725 million and $750 million
column8: representing growth of 2%-5%
column9: with non-GAAP earnings per diluted share in the range of $0.14 to $0.18
column10: and a non-GAAP tax rate of approximately 33%.""At a full-year earnings per share of between 55 cents and 59 cents
column11: FIT trades at a forward P/E of up to 13.5 times (Based on Thursday's closing price of $7.41). Investors clearly have low expectations for the company. Trailing quarterly sales grew by 23.1%. Shorts are winning the bearish bet because they understand a company with good products is not necessarily a good stock.Competition Heating UpDespite a record low valuation
column12: low expectations for the quarter and potential growth in Europe and Asia
column13: FIT stock has one big problem: competition. During the holiday season
column14: consumers had the choice of buying many cheaper alternatives at a fraction of a FIT device. In Asia
column15: Xiaomisells similar wearables for a fraction of FIT's price.On the high end
column16: FIT competes with theGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN) Vivosmart HR
column17: which costs the same as Fitbit's Charge 2 (both cost around $149.95) andApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple Watch 1 and 2.If FIT's stock collapses post-earnings
column18: it will be among a long list of fallen fad stocks. This includesGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO)
column19: whose action camera is losing popularity andEtsy Inc(NASDAQ:ETSY)
column20: whose handmade products compete withAmazon.com
column21: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) homemadestore.Fitbit's next phase of growth depends on expanding internationally. Executing on this requires good management. When management said it mishandled the Flex 2 supply chain
column22: few investors should have any confidence on management.On Jan. 12
column23: news broke out that Fitbit may havewantedto acquireJawbonelate last year. This is another example that suggests investors should worry about FIT's management capability.Whole Foods Market
column24: Inc. (WFM) in the Fresh Food WarsThe company needs to preserve its cash
column25: instead of spending it on supply chain managementBottom Line on FitbitFitbit knows that competition will worsen over time. Its (rumored) attempts to buy Jawbone would have eliminated that threat
column26: positioning the company as a stronger foe against Apple
column27: Garmin and the cheap wearable device makers.The stock is still a ""show me"" investment though
column28: especially if holiday sales are underwhelming.As of this writing
column29: Chris Lau had no position in any of the stocks mentioned. Follow him onTwitter.More From InvestorPlace5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in February10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You BackThe postFitbit Inc (FIT) Stock Has Quite a Wall to Climbappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Friday Apple Rumors: Designer Creates Interesting iPhone 8 Concept;1/27/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLeading theApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) rumor mill today is news of an iPhone 8 concept. Today
column3: we'll look at that and otherApple Rumorsfor Friday.makeArticleAd();iPhone 8 Concept:Designer Iskander Utebayev has created an interesting concept of what Apple's next iPhone may look like
column4: reportsBGR. The designer created a sleek looking concept for the iPhone 8 that has a curved display. It's a slim device that has a sleek look to it. One interesting idea that can be seen in the concept is the change for the camera. The concept puts the camera for the iPhone 8 inside of the AAPL logo. It's an interesting idea
column5: but not likely one the tech company will adopt.iPad Anniversary:Today is the 7-year anniversary for the iPad
column6: MacRumorsnotes. Apple founder Steve Jobs introduced the iPad to audiences at a media event in 2010. He called it AAPL's ""most advanced technology in a magical and revolutionary device at an unbelievable price."" The original iPad had a 9.7-inch display with a resolution of 1024 x 768. It came in 16GB
column7: 32GB and 64GB models. The tablet was powered by the tech company's A4 processor.Apple Watch Music:Owners of the Apple Watch have the ability to take music with them on the go without their iPhone
column8: reports9to5Mac. The smartwatch has the ability to store up to 2GB of music. It all has to be in a single playlist first. It also requires an iPhone to get the music on there in the first place. The smartwatch can also be paired with wireless headphones so users can listen to the music through them. All and all
column9: its a bit of a complicated process
column10: but it might be worth it for those that don't want to take their iPhone with them during their morning run.Check out more recentApple RumorsorSubscribe to Apple Rumors:RSSThe postFriday Apple Rumors: Designer Creates Interesting iPhone 8 Conceptappeared first onInvestorPlace."
